column2: The volume of wholesale trade contracted last week from the week before, but compared favorably with last year's poor totals, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in their weekly summary. Developments in Europe tended to depress sentiment, holding back any tendency to do forward purchasing.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, and two chairmen of committees of the Exchange called today on Commissioner Robert E. Healy and Ganson Burcell, director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP).--Frank Hill, Northwestern veteran track coach, believes that Johnny Borican, the "find" of the Winter indoor track season, may "find himself pushed right off the track" should he fail to produce a world indoor record in the 1,000-yard run in the Chicago relays tomorrow night.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 24 --The defending champion University of Michigan team gained a 34-to-30 lead over Ohio State University tonight as the opening night's competition of the two-day National Collegiate A.A. swimming championships ended.

The stock market had yesterday its best rally in more than two weeks, but the volume of business fell to the smallest proportions in about the same period. The European news was relatively unalarming, while at home a distinctly encouraging ...

James J. Hives spent a quiet day in the Tombs yesterday, with one visitor, whose identity was not revealed by prison authorities. His new chief counsel, Martin W. Littleton, went ahead with preparations for the argument on Monday before ...

The improvement of cultural relations between this country and Central and South America will help to promote peace and understanding among all nations, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College declared yesterday at a luncheon given in her honor by the Pan American Society.

ALBANY, March 24.--A bill giving the New York State Racing Commission complete control over the licensing of owners, trainers and jockeys participating at any horse race track in the State was introduced in the Senate today by John J. Dunnigan, Democratic Minority Leader.

The annual report of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., for 1938, released for publication yesterday, showed a net profit of $3,253,176, including $1,651,473 dividends from overseas subsidiaries, and after deductions for depreciation and Canadian and other income taxes.
AINTREE, England, March 24.-- Ireland has won the 101st Grand National lock, stock and barrel.

With gold cargo space booked on every available passenger steamship due to arrive here from European ports between now and April 4, unofficial estimates of the gold to be shipped from the Channel in the immediate Future range upward ...

Two of the games included in tonight's indoor polo championships program assumed added importance yesterday by an announcement from officials of the association in regard to the East-West series, which will close the season ...

TRENTON, March 24.--The joint legislative committee appointed to negotiate with officials of railroads operating in New Jersey on the possibilities of reaching a compromise of a claim of tax arrears of $34,258,834 against the carriers announced today that the negotiations had "collapsed."

The installation of sanitary facilities in 150 buildings at the World's Fair has been halted by the plumbers' strike and all inside construction work on these buildings will have to stop unless the strike is settled soon, Fred Brutschy, president ...

Progress in the reorganization of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was revealed yesterday when Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe signed orders approving payment of certain debts of the company from a fund of $8,500,000, which is held for this purpose, thus releasing merchandise which had been used as collateral.

Advances of 50 to 300 per cent in war-risk insurance rates were announced by underwriters here yesterday, effective Monday, following increases that were put into force yesterday by London underwriters. The underwriters set up separate schedules for exports and imports, and made higher rates for shipments to European ports than for shipments from such ports to the United States.

Trading continued light yesterday in the cotton market pending announcement of plans for releasing some loan collateral for the use of domestic and foreign mills. Execution of Liverpool and Bombay selling orders furnished contracts ...

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The House tabled today a resolution aimed at impeachment of Secretary Perkins and two aides after its Judiciary Committee had reported unanimously that there was insufficient evidence to warrant a conclusion that the officials had conspired to defeat the ends of the immigration laws.

LONDON, March 24.--The stock markets here were quiet today, with a general disinclination to open new commitments, but the recovery of yesterday was well maintained, with further improvement in places.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--All employes of banks and employes other than drivers of private motor carriers and of common and contract carriers engaged in interstate commerce are subject to the provisions of the Wages and Hours Law, according to rulings issued today on behalf of Administrator Elmer F. Andrews by Calvert Magruder, general counsel of the wage and hour division.

CHICAGO, March 24.--Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here closed today 1/8 cent a bushel lower than yesterday after a range of about 5/8 cent. The market was inactive except for a brief period earlier, when there was fairly general selling on weakness in Liverpool and beneficial showers in ...
Sales of the Johns-Manville Corporation thus far in 1939 have been about on a level with those of a year ago, Lewis H. Brown, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.
Every March 21 a troop of Boy Scouts goes on a nature hunt to determine just how long Spring has been here. The process distrusts the calendar designation as man-made, arbitrary and artificial.
The question of additional appropriations to extend the work of the United States Housing Authority in promoting low-rent public-housing projects is now being studied by Congressional committees.
R.H. Macy Co. officially dedicated its new and enlarged sports center last night at an informal ceremony attended by about 150 persons.

ALBANY, March 24.--Eight junior bank examiners in the State Banking Department have been named at salaries ranging from $9.60 to $9.20 a day, according to the official department bulletin issued today. The names were taken from a civil service list.

WARSAW, Poland, March 24.-- Independence and a free hand continue to be the basic principles of Poland's foreign policy, official circles cryptically answered today to all inquiries regarding this country's attitude toward the proposed tripartite anti-German declaration of Great Britain, France and Soviet Russia.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 24.-- Favorite players in the crowd at Tropical Park today were wishing that they had started the trek northward before the running of the program. All the favorites lost. lost.

CHICAGO, March 24.--Proposed legislation designed "to save the railroads" was discussed today at a meeting of the Association of Western Railway Executives. Discussion among about forty executives brought out a continuation of the opposition to some of the key proposals in the program for rail relief set up by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Three proposals involving a system of national airports, to meet the demands of aerial transportation and national defense, were submitted to Congress today by the Civil Aeronautics Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Some members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which is scheduled to start consideration on Wednesday of five pending proposals for revision or repeal of the Neutrality Law, expressed the fear ...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24. --The diary of Captain D.S. Stanley, who made the overland trek from Fort Smith, Ark., to San Diego in 1853, will be filmed by Warners under the title, "The Diary of the Santa Fe," the studio announced today.

Plans for a modern retail store building to displace two old structures on the upper West Side were announced yesterday when Isadore B. Geller, operator and builder, bought 720 and 722 Columbus Avenue, northwest corner of Ninety- ...
Two large apartment buildings in the Bronx figured in deals reported from that borough yesterday.

BOSTON, March 24.--Without appearing to want to detract from their rivals' excellent performances, the New York Rangers, one and all, today were hoping fortune would visit them for the first time in their current series with the Bruins.

BERLIN, March 24.--A "New Financial Plan" to extricate the government of the new German Empire from its acute financial difficulties and enable it to continue its present expansion policy was decreed today by a "law regarding the financing of the Reich's national political tasks."

Plans for the world heavyweight championship boxing bout between Joe Louis and Tony Galento here in June moved a step nearer completion yesterday when the New York State Athletic Commission announced that Galento was in satisfactory physical condition for an attempt at the title.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 24.-- The Rumanian Government's view of the commercial treaty with Germany is that it gives Rumania a breathing space and the western powers time to decide on the policy that they mean to pursue as regards Southeastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations peace conference today stalled on the terms under which the federation would readmit the United Mine Workers of America. An adjournment was taken until March 30, with the next meeting place to be the Hotel Biltmore in New York.

TOKYO, March 24.--Great opportunities for Japan, including the possibility of completely ousting United States and British interests from the Orient, are envisaged here among the developments likely to follow a German domination of Europe.

The struggle for economic security in a democracy was the subject of discussion yesterday at a symposium of the graduate faculty of political and social science in the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 24.--William C. Bird of Florence, Mass., was elected president of the American Brush Manufacturers Association as its convention ended here today.

SHANGHAI, March 24.--Mopping up in the town of Wucheng on the western shore of Poyang Lake, which was captured by a Japanese assault yesterday, was completed by noon today, according to the Japanese spokesman in Shanghai.

In a four-to-one decision the Appellate Division yesterday gave the Federal Government the right to continue its efforts to collect $18,600 of the income taxes allegedly owed by the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer from the Century Indemnity Company. Previously the government attempted unsuccessfully to collect a similar amount from the city.

After the City Council Committee on Civil Employes had rejected two amendments sought by Mayor La Guardia to the McCarthy Salary Bill yesterday, it was reported at the Mayor's office that the refusal might result in laying off some of the low-paid employes involved.

Power to direct complete foreclosure of the consolidated 4 per cent mortgage on the elevated lines now operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, so that clear title to the properties may be given to the city either through unification proceedings or by separate ...

Irving K. Taylor, big-game hunter and president of the liquor importing firm of W.A. Taylor Co. at 15 Laight Street, died Thursday night in Santa Barbara, Calif., where he had made his Winter home for the last ten years. He was 74 years old.

CHICAGO, March 24.--The government today agreed to a sharp reduction in its income-tax claim against the General Household Utilities Company, paving the way for reorganization of the company and re-employment of 3,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP).-- Cornelius H. Callaghan, manager of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, told the National Rivers and Harbors Congress today that construction of the St. Lawrence seaway "would disrupt and demoralize the transportation system of the United States."

WASHINGTON, March 24.--A Senate judiciary subcommittee of seven members today approved unanimously the nomination of William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.

The four-story apartment house at 77-05 Forty-first Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Philip W. Thomas of Croton-on-Hudson to Irving W. Karpf, operator, for cash above a first mortgage of $36,750, held by the New York Life Insurance Company.

AIKEN, S.C., March 24.--Thomas Hitchcock's Saluda, raced with success in the steeplechase events on metropolitan tracks last season, will likely be the favorite among nine horses that have been named for the Imperial Cup, feature of the second meeting of the Aihen Mile Track Association tomorrow.

Defaulting contractors who have cost the Board of Education much grief in the past will receive little of the school building work from now on, Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the board, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Department store sales for the week ended March 18 were 5 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and, for the fourweek period ended March 18, were 3 per cent more than for the similar period in 1938, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The gain for the previous week was 2 per cent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 24.--Mrs. Marie Hite Burckhalter was sentenced today to serve a term of two and a half to twenty years in the State Prison for Women at Bedford Hills for assisting in the suicide of her husband, Eugene Y. Burckhalter, on Nov. 19. She had pleaded guilty to manslaughter last month.

Representative Bruce Barton told the members of the Kings County Republican Committee last night that the issue in the 1940 Presidential campaign would not be "foreign affairs," but rather "they (the Democrats) kept us out of work." The Manhattan Representative spoke at a meeting in Kismet Temple, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn.

MONTVIDEO, Uruguay, March 24.--The International Congress of American Democracies closed its sessions here tonight convinced that it had laid the foundations for a vast militant Inter-American Popular Front movement somewhat similar to that which recently won control of the government of Chile.

Waging an impressive battle most of the way, Frankie Blair of Camden, N.J., received the decision over Cal Cagni, Cresskill, N.J., middleweight, in the feature eightround bout before 4,000 fans at the New York Hippodrome last night.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24.--Marse Joe McCarthy of the Yankees was seated in a deep chair puffing contentedly on a large cigar and chatting with Marcus Aurelius Roth, the rotund road secretary of the Yankees.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $7,729,375, to be represented by thirty-five municipalities, compared with $14,299,811 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date stands at $17,049,252.

MONTVIDEO, Uruguay, March 24.--The International Congress of American Democracies closed its sessions here tonight convinced that it had laid the foundations for a vast militant Inter-American Popular Front movement somewhat similar to that which recently won control of the government of Chile.

Waging an impressive battle most of the way, Frankie Blair of Camden, N.J., received the decision over Cal Cagni, Cresskill, N.J., middleweight, in the feature eightround bout before 4,000 fans at the New York Hippodrome last night.

Passion Sunday will be observed in all the city churches tomorrow. Many pastors will discuss the European situation. Prayers will be offered "for the peace of the world." In many Protestant pulpits a folder containing "A Christian Manifesto" ...

Houses which are not members of the New York Stock Exchange are to be allowed henceforth to make commission profits on a certain type of business done on its floor under a ruling handed down this week by the Exchange's committee on member firms.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The House farm group, confident that its own strength could retain the $250,000,000 in parity payments for farmers in the pending billion-dollar Agriculture Department bill, today spurned an invitation to an oldfashioned log-rolling extended by urban representatives who sought "assurances" of votes for the full $150,000,000 for relief asked by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP).-- With economy advocates maintaining silence, the Senate Appropriations Committee raised the regular War Department Appropriations Bill to $513,188,782 today in formally reporting it to the Senate.

Newspaper campaigns on mechanical refrigerators got under way here yesterday and will be intensified next week then first copy is placed on the Consolidated Edison promotion. Rex Cole, Inc., yesterday broke copy on the General Electric line of refrigerators and will continue for three months in about four papers in this city. Large-size ads for Servel Electrolux also appeared.

Winners of the Ligue Internationale des Aviateurs Harmon Trophy for outstanding aeronautical achievements for 1938 were announced at the annual "grand rallye" of the American section of the organization in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 24.-- The Dodgers lost both their boy wonder, Harold (Pete) Reiser, and a ball game today. The Tigers scored twice in the eighth inning to break a tie and win the game, 6--4. A charley horse stopped Reiser.

PASADENA, Calif., March 24 (AP). --Vic Frasier, White Sox pitcher, was confined to a hospital today with a lineal skull fracture suffered two days ago during a practice session. The fracture was not discovered until this morning.
BERLIN, March 24.--The conclusion of a five-year economic, industrial and commercial treaty between Germany and Rumania is the outstanding topic of discussion in the press today.

Debutantes of future seasons and young men at home from schools and colleges for the Spring recess attended several subscription dances last night, which were given in continuation of the series of dances begun during the Christmas holidays.
ROME, March 24.--At 10:30 this morning Crown Prince Humbert gave an audience to Andre FrancoisPoncet, the French Ambassador, at the Quirinal for twenty minutes.
On April 4 Houghton Mifflin will publish the reminiscences of Emily Bax, who spent thirteen years at the American Embassy in London, first as stenographer and later as confidential clerk.

A gathering of 14,000 attended the first performance of the charity figure skating carnival at Madison Square Garden last night. The show, which will be given three more nights, is being presented as a benefit for the Bellevue Hospital Social Service and the Carroll Club.

The first Boy Scout tent at the World's Fair, an Indian tepee, will be pitched on the Scout camp site at the Fair grounds this morning. Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, vice president of the National Council, and Dr. James E. West, chief Scout executive, will take part in this first ceremony in the program of Scout activity at the Fair.

Immediately after placing Joseph Schrank's "Cream of Mush" in "Pins and Needles" on March 29, the actors at Labor Stage will begin rehearsals on another item by Mr. Schrank entitled "The Harmony Boys" and, incidentally, the seventh new number to be added to the garment workers' revue. All the new numbers will be officially welcomed during the week of April 3 when a so-called new edition will be inaugurated.

Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc., and A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $5,150,000 of Cook County, Ill., 1939 levy taxanticipation warrants at 1 per cent for $2,100,000 of corporation fund warrants; 1 per cent for ...

COSTA MESA, Calif., March 24.-- Discovery of a prehistoric crypt which may antedate the catacombs of Rome was reported today by W.B. Murbarger of Costa Mesa, an archaeologist, who has been conducting investigations for the Bowers Memorial Museum in Santa Ana.

TORONTO.--At long last Canada will begin operating its publicly owned airway for passen gers on April 1. After more than a decade of delays the Canadian traveling public will be able to fly from one end of the Dominion to the other. No longer will it be necessary to cross the international border to catch a plane to cross the continent.

OPENED with a reception last evening, the sixteenth Corcoran Biennial in Washington will be current through May 7. The jury invited by the Corcoran to select the paintings, to install the exhibition and to make ...
SINCE 1907 the faculty of the Medical School of Harvard University has given a yearly series of free Sunday afternoon lectures "making available ...

TENG YUEA, Yunnan, China.-- To enter this Chinese city is to make an almost complete es cape from the West. Aside from a few bicycles imported in recent years there is no wheeled transport. There are no roads. And the 20,000 inhabitants of the city are protected by a wall of cut stone thirty feet high. There used to tie a moat outside the wall but it has long been dry.

DETROIT, March 25.--After administering a narcotic to himself with a hypodermic needle to ease the pain, Dr. Charles Schultz of 201 East Thirty-fifth Street, New York, stabbed himself fatally over the heart with a surgeon's scalpel in the Detroiter Hotel last night. His body was found shortly before midnight by the hotel manager.
IN the buccaneering days of the Eighties and Nineties, when the spirit of individualism was receiving its just inward, there must have been some women at least who shared in the spoils.

ALTHOUGH the lion's share of public attention has recently been claimed by military avia tion, the commercial end of flying has not been marking time. The men, the airlines and the manufacturers who have made America's commercial aviation the model and envy of the world have been going about their tasks as if deaf to the threats and rumors of war.

AFTER surveying electrically for three years to find a more satisfactory location for the WEAF transmitter, engi neers of the National Broadcasting Company have selected a neck of sandy soil at Port Washington, L.I., as the ideal spot.

TWO prizes of $200 each for organ compositions by American-born composers are being offered by John Hausser mann, sponsor of the organ at the Temple of Religion at the World's Fair. One of the awards is for a ...
AIKEN, S.C., March 25.--More than 300 members of the colony and their friends attended the Imperial Cup Ball at Willcox's this evening.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 25.-- Round Hill Community Church here, decorated with apple and cherry blossoms, was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of ...

THERE is a new travel thrill in Finland. Road development, especially the construc tion of the Great Arctic Highway, the only automobile road in the world leading to the Arctic Ocean, has made available to the visitor in the land of the Lapps a number of new attractions.

New Utrecht clinched the Division 2 honors for the second successive year and Stuyvesant, city ruler for the last two years, was assured of at least a tie for the Division 1 crown as a result of competition in the Public Schools Athletic League senior high team fencing tournament at Washington Irving High yesterday.
AS a result of experiments at Radio City, the program arrangers of the National Broadcasting Company re port that they are convinced television is to be a "powerful medium for teaching."
Followers of sport in the field are offered a double treat this week and may take their choice between two types of competition.

ABOARD BRITISH FREIGHTER SEABANK SPRAY, off Valencia, March 25.--There are 7,000,000 Spaniards still in the narrow wedge of country that runs from the Mediterranean to Madrid and is still described as Republican Spain.

The successful candidate for the Presidency in 1940 should be one chosen by those citizens who have put aside "fads, fancies and hobbies," discarded thinking along routine lines of party patronage and brushed aside personalities in their efforts to find a leader willing and able to tackle the real issues confronting the nation, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting given by the City Affairs Committee in the Murray Hill Hotel.
There will be no broadcast of the Police Department's Holy Name Society communion breakfast at the Hotel Astor this morning by the municipal radio station WNYC, it appeared certain last night.

A tall, brawny, white-haired man, 63 years old, standing in General Sessions prisoners' dock last week, was sentenced to four to eight years in jail for giving political protection to the policy racket.
ATLANTA, March 24.--The South's long fight for freight rate equality gained impetus from two events this week.

Active interest in the establish ment of an over-all limitation on the real estate tax such as in force in nine States is now being shown in eight additional States, reports Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

SHANGHAI, March 25.--Cabled suggestions from Berlin to the effect that Japan may be asked to return to Germany Tsingtao and the Kiaochow Bay area met a cold, evasive response from the Japanese official spokesmen in Shanghai today.

IN these days when most of Europe is a series of highly walled economic strongholds--only the western and northern fringes of the Continent now remain "free"-- no little skill is demanded of American travelers if they wish to dodge frontier money embarrassments.
RECENTLY a group of style experts gathered in the showroom of one of New York's leading young design ers to view her Spring and Summer collection.

Plans are being made for a third Section consisting of twenty-one buildings containing 1,080 rooms in the Fort Hill Village garden-type apartment development in Greenburgh, Westchester County, Rae Craerin, president of Fort Hill Estates, Inc., announced yesterday.

From several angles in recent days, spotlights focused on the intercoastal steamship trade have revealed an ailing and turbulent industry, as urgently in need of Federal attention as the nation's subsidized services to foreign lands.
A suit to determine the status of 1,400 distributors holding contracts with the Texas Company, oil producers, under the Social Security Act, was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the company.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 25.--American delegates and observers at the International Congress of American Democracies, which closed here yesterday, were surprised at the vehemence of the conference's support of President Roosevelt and everything that he stands for.

Four factors stand, out prominently in the orderly development of the Borough of Queens, called the "fastest growing community in the United States" by S. Dudley Nostrand, vice president of the realty firm of Butler Baldwin.
Club Woman's Day in Newark on Tuesday stands out as an important event in a week of district conferences, forums and music festivals planned for members of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 25 (AP). --Racing to victory in three events, Dick Werner of Haledon, N.J., tonight gained the senior men's crown in the Western New York Golden Skates championships.

If American troops are ever to be conscripted again for fighting overseas, a majority of Americans believe that the question should first be submitted to the people themselves in a national vote, according to a survey of the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.
PARIS.--"Commandments" to a total of twelve have just been drawn up in France to govern the art of eating well.
A.L. Burns won the High-OverAll Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, breaking 98 in the 100target competition.

TRENTON, March 25.--William C. Neville of the United States Department of Commerce Bureau of Fisheries told a wild-life conference of the New Jersey State Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs here today that the commercial fisherman and the angler should work together to increase the supply of striped bass so that there will be enough for both.

A mass meeting at which many of the organizations in yesterday's parade will be represented will be held at the Hippodrome tomorrow evening, it was announced last night by the Volunteer Christian Committee to Boycott Nazi Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--From several aspects the recent proposal of seventeen of the nation's stock exchanges that the Securities and Exchange Commission give favorable and immediate consideration to basic changes in the acts under which it operates was both ill-timed and ill-judged. One aspect is psychological, another political, another in the realm of horse sense.

WARSAW, March 25.--The Poles are confident of their future. They are ready to fight in defense of their independence and every square inch of their territory.

Women, for the first time, have become tax conscious, and are doing something about it, according to Mrs. Charles P. Barry, treasurer of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, and a student of taxation.

The Metropolitan Museum is having an exhibition of Victorian and Edwardian dresses, and women who have been wearing hoopskirts and snoods, in the fond hope that in these they look just like grandmother, are being brought face to face with their mistake.
Announcements last week of bonds tailed for redemption before maturity were ills smaller volume than in recent weeks and only a few large industrial prepayments were included in the list.

The arrival of Spring brings to the gardener a series of tantalizing invitations to take in all possible garden beauty spots, beginning in the Southern States and working North with the advancing season.

ROSELAND, N.J., March 25.-- A pair of perfect rounds by Frank R. Kelly of West Orange in the 20-gauge stage gave him individual honors and enabled his team to take the small-bore laurels as the fifth annual New Jersey State twoman skeet championship, opened at the Roseland Community Gun Club today.

ALTHOUGH it is generally supposed that there are several different bidding systems in popular use, analysis proves that the difference lies not in the system of bidding but in their methods of valuing one's hand.

PITTSBURGH, March 25.--When "horseless carriages" began to be supplanted by "traveling showcases" on our streets and highways about fifteen years ago--adding another complication to the fundamental conflict between speed and safety--it became obvious that something would have to be done about glass breakage as a source of injury.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29.-- With the Dodgers enjoying their last complete day of relaxation until they wind up the exhibition season against the Yankees at Ebbets Field on April 16, a bit of an inventory on the current Flatbush stock seems to be in order.
Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Brazil, has come from Washington to the St. Regis, where he will be joined in a few days by Mrs. Caffery, who is in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--In virtual reply to President Roosevelt's proposal for an export subsidy to help move the huge American cotton surplus into the world market, a group of Southern Senators determined today to push a two-point plan of their own, designed to extend benefits to the domestic producers.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The administration-sponsored program to begin on January old-age pension payments to persons insured under the Social Security Act would provide an absolute minimum of $20.75 a month for each individual instead of the negligible cash lump sum provided by current law, Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, told the Ways and Means Committee today.

ALBANY, March 29.--Representatives of the State Education Department and taxpayers from rural school districts clashed at a public hearing held by the Senate Public Education Committee today on a bill which would require a majority of the voters in each school district to approve plans for centralization or consolidation before such a plan could be made effective.

The Sperry Corporation, manufacturers of aviation and other equipment, had a net income of $4,961,398 in 1938 after taxes and other charges, according to the annual report to be made public today by Thomas A. Morgan, president.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The fight of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad to retain control of the Erie Railroad came before the Interstate Commerce Commission today when the debtor and the holders of Erie refunding and improvement mortgage bonds filed briefs with the commission.

Mass meetings were held in three boroughs last night to urge a $150,000,000 State appropriation for the construction of low-cost housing. At all of them a letter by Mayor La Guardia was read, declaring that the State "can do no less" than has already been done by the Federal Government.

A probable fourth indictment, which would lump the government's case against Martin T. Manton, former senior judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, was forecast in Federal Court yesterday by United States Attorney John T. Cahill as Manton pleaded not guilty to a third true bill charging him with corruption and bribery.

Efforts to save from foreclosure the apartment of Daniel Frohman, 87-year-old retired theatrical producer, in the Lyceum Theatre, 149 West Forty-fifth Street, were being made yesterday by the owners of the property. The apartment has been the scene of many parties

Mrs. Harold S. Vaughan gave a luncheon yesterday at Mayfair House for the Duchess de Talleyrand of Paris. Among the other guests were Mrs. Warner M. Van Norden, Mrs. Joseph H. Seaman, Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin, Mrs. Winfield Scott Schley, Mrs. Nathaniel A. Campbell and Miss Louise Hazeltine.

To determine the extensiveness of tuberculosis as an occupational disease in the fur industry, the Furriera Union, in cooperation with the WPA and the Health Department, began yesterday a drive to have X-ray examinations made of 20,000 fur workers here.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.-- Clarence H. Geist, public utility operator and financier who died last June 12, left an estate of $54,130,684, an inheritance tax return filed today at Media revealed. It is estimated that, after deduction of taxes, debts and administration expenses, about $20,000,000 will be available for Mr. Geist's heirs.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange commenced yesterday a two-day hearing into the investment-trust scandal that shocked financial circles last year. Representatives of a Stock Exchange house were summoned for question

CHICAGO, March 29.--Trading in wheat futures was restricted today and prices held within a range of about cent a bushel. The market showed no disposition to rally, although receiving some support from brokers who frequently act for cash and milling interests.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--All civilian employes in the departmental and field services of the War Department will be fingerprinted. Their prints will be kept by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Secretary Woodring said today that only temporary unskilled laborers would be exempt from the order.

CLEVELAND, March 29.--Officers of the United Automobile Workers of America, adhering to the Congress of Industrial Organizations, reporting to their convention delegates today, blamed Homer Martin, former president of the union for nearly everything that had gone wrong with their organization in the last few years.

ALBANY, March 29.--George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, urged the Senate Labor and Industry Committee today to postpone for a year any action on the Kleinfeld bill, which seeks to establish a State Wages and Hours Law similar to that of the Federal Government.

ALBANY, March 29.--Governor Lehman filled two vacancies on the Supreme Court bench in Brooklyn, and a City Court vacancy in the same borough today by naming William R. Wilson and Justice Frank E. Johnson of the Municipal Court to the high court posts, and Justice Murray Hearn of the Municipal Court to the vacancy on the City Court bench.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The House today adopted the conference report on the Government Reorganization Bill, thus sending the measure to the President.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO WARM SPRINGS, March 29.--After a last-minute canvassing of international, legislative and political questions confronting the Administration, President Roosevelt left the White House today on a round-about trip to Warm Springs, Ga., where he will pass

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29.-- The Hon. Peter and Mrs. PleydellBouverie of London, who have taken an Everglades maisonette for a fortnight, were the guests of honor tonight at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio in their home.
Harold Oliver, unattached featherweight boxer, retained his Metropolitan A.A.U. 126-pound-class championship last night at the Jamaica Arena before a capacity crowd of 2,500 persons. A strong

With "The Philadelphia Story" there seems little doubt that the Theatre Guild has a real hit on its hands. The Shubert Theatre box office boasted a steady line of customers all day yesterday, and there was a good demand at the brokers.
WASHINGTON, March 29.--The navy will begin soon the construction of a "mosquito" fleet, the units of which will represent the latest developments in design and equipment.

BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, March 29.--The Slovak Government sent a note to Berlin today inquiring as to Germany's attitude toward the Hungarian territorial demands in view of Germany's guarantee of the Slovak frontiers.

Fill-in reorders on dress coats to retail at $16.95 and $19.85 have been actively placed all this week, following the heavy retail trade in most areas at the close of last week. The expectation is that retail volume this Saturday will be even larger, provided weather conditions are favorable. Stores in a number...

With the approach of May 1, the customary "moving day" in the business world, realty men and tenants alike again are studying the possibility of "staggering" both commercial and residential leasing and spreading expirations over a wider period.

Leading air lines whose operating records showed a reduction in fatalities despite an increase in miles of flying won the recognition of the National Safety Council at yesterday's session of its tenth annual convention, which opened on Monday under the auspices of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 29.-- After four days of attempts to form a Syrian Cabinet a deadlock was reached today when Nasoubi el Bokhari, who had accepted the Premiership, admitted failure. Lutfy el Haffar resigned as Premier a fortnight ago.

Suspected by the police of having participated with two men in stealing thousands of dollars' worth of jewelry, furs and clothing from hotel rooms in the midtown district last year, Mrs. Lillian Gloria Bor

NEWARK, N.J., March 29.-- Emphatic denial of any part in the alleged conspiracy to defraud the city of Newark through meadowland purchases was made today by former Commissioner Reginald C.S. Parnell at the city land trial.

Mayor La Guardia came in for some more chiding yesterday from Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, this time on the matter of the 1938 Mayoralty telephone expense which, his critic said, exceeded that of former Mayor Walker at the peak of prosperity.

PARIS, March 29.--When the Nationalist troops enter Valencia they will find 1,000,000 persons crowded into a city that normally had no more than 350,000.

Preparations for the second Outdoor Sculpture Show are being made by the Sculptors Guild. It is to be held as it was last year, in the lot at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, from April 15 to June 15.

ROME, March 29.--The fall of Madrid is greeted today as another fascist triumph by the Italian press, which at the same time emphasizes the advantages, both political and military, that Italy will derive from a friendly Spain.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 29 (AP)--General Gerardo Machado, whose dictatorial Presidency of Cuba was overthrown in 1933, died on an operating table today as five physicians tried in vain to stave off his death from cancer. He was 67 years old.

Several hundred actors are on the verge of being forced to leave their permanent homes in the hotels of the Times Square area because of increased room rents during the World's Fair, it was charged yesterday by the Actors Equity Association in an appeal to Mayor La Guardia and the Hotel Association of New York for protection of its members against any wholesale eviction.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29.-- Held hitless and scoreless for six innings by Hank Borowy of Fordham, who as a sophomore turned in a record of ten straight victories last year, Navy lost to the Rams today, 6--1, in the first baseball game of the season for both.

BERLIN, March 29.--Washington reports that President Roosevelt had decided to force the export of the cotton surplus and subsidize the American grower provoked extended and significant comment in official quarters tonight.
MEXICO CITY, March 29.--The long-threatened bread strike was called today by the "only Breadworkers Union" because of "failure of bakery owners" to grant the union demands for a fourteen-point

LONDON, March 29.--The stock markets, helped by better Wall Street advices, showed a marked improvement in late dealings today. Earlier business had been quietly dull with losses much smaller than in yesterday's session.
Exports of American dresses, accessories and some textile lines have increased sharply since the first of the year, with the number of foreign buyers visiting the markets here
After being closed two years, the remodeled and much enlarged building of the New York Historical Society at 170 Central Park West will be reopened to the public on Saturday.

A young man, wearing a brown camel's hair topcoat and a brown suit, hat and shoes, held up the manager of a chain shoe store at 782 Nostrand Avenue, near St. John's Place, Brooklyn, at 9 A.M. yesterday and departed with $63.88 from the cash drawer, according to a report to the police.

IT'S hard to know whether the Ranger players thought it up themselves or took a tip from M'sieu Lestairre Patrick, but they switched tactics on ice the other night and scored their first victory in this Stanley Cup series.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (AP).-- Solo of Newport Harbor, Calif., sailed by Myron (Barney) Lehman, with Jack Streeton as crew, won the second race of the Star Class Spring championship series today on Lake Pontchartrain.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.-- The dismissal by Eugene Ormandy, conductor and music director, of Isadore Gusikoff as first 'cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra became known today as a trial board of Local 77, American Federation of Musicians, heard testimony and upheld Mr. Gusikoff's salary claims against the orchestra.

Edgar M. Queeny, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at St. Louis yesterday that, while the sales and profit positions of the company have improved thus far in 1939, the continued uncer

ALBANY, March 29.--Establishment of a State-wide system of "adult physical repair"' as a step toward solving the difficulty of middle-aged persons in finding and retaining employment was recommended today by the joint legislative committee created two years ago to investigate discrimination in employment of those past 40 years old.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 29 (AP).-- Catcher Rudy York went on the warpath today and, in five innings, got two home runs and a single in three trips to the plate, scored three runs and batted in four to help the Tigers top the Boston Bees, 9--8.

High-ranking officers of the Police Department became the first group of city employes to volunteer a pay cut to aid Mayor La Guardia in balancing the budget when a delegation told the Mayor yesterday that captains and their superiors would take a 5 per cent cut for one year.

An exceptional item of tragic association interest will come up at auction here in the dispersal of the outstanding library of the late John A. Spoor at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The sale will begin on April 26 and continue through May 5.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today, in an executive session, to begin hearings next Wednesday, at 10:30 A.M., on the six pending proposals concerning the existing Neutrality Act. The hearings, which will be public, are expected to last two weeks.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses moved yesterday to obtain War Department approval of his plan for a $41,200,000 suspension bridge between the Battery and Brooklyn, upon receipt of notification that the Legislature had adopted the bill giving the Triborough Bridge Authority permission to proceed with the project.

SHANGHAI, March 29 (AP).--Continuous battles are raging throughout Northern Kiangsi Province. The Japanese reported they were advancing southward along the Kan River after occupying Nanchang in Kiangsi and Wuning, sixty-five miles to the northwest.

ALBANY, March 29.--The Assembly today passed, 110 to 4, in a form satisfactory to the interested parties, the Wicks Grade-Crossing Elimination Bill which is expected to speed work of this type throughout the State. The bill had previously been passed by the Senate in a different form, and it must now be repassed by the upper house.

BERLIN, March 29.--Baron Constantin von Neurath, Reich protector for the Bohemian-Moravian Protectorate, and Dr. Emil Hacha, State President of the Protectorate, today express opinions concerning future cooperation between the Reich and her new territory in joint articles appearing in The European Review.

The first quarter is ending with a note of hesitation in the steel indutry and March business made no substantial gains, according to Iron Age, which continues that "sales of some products barely broke even with those of February,
BERMUDA, March 29.--The huge Pan American Boeing clipper under the command of Captain R.O. D. Sullivan made a perfect landing before 700 spectators at the Darrells Island airbase at 5:10 o'clock

ALBANY, March 29.--After one of the most productive days of the session, most of the members of the Legislature headed homeward tonight for a recess which, beginning Saturday, will last until April 10 in observance of the Easter holiday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 29. --Entering the winners' circle for the first time this Winter, O'Bantam snatched a photo decision from Ghost Queen in the West Palm Beach Purse at Tropical Park today. The chestnut 5-year-old returned $33 for $2 and covered the mile and seventy yards in 1:43 1-5.

President Roosevelt's endorsement of a plan for an export subsidy to reduce the cotton surplus, and concurrent arrangements to protect domestic producers from a boost in imports or loss of their export market met with widespread approval among selling agents and trade association executives in the cotton goods industry yesterday.
The government cracked down yesterday on operators of allegedly crooked investment trust companies charged with swindling thousands of persons out of a total of $1,150,000.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 29.-- Mrs. William Hockenjos of West Orange, former New Jersey State champion, was the only metropolitan New York entrant to survive the second round of the thirtyseventh annual North and South invitation golf tournament over the No. 3 course of the Pinehurst Country Club today. The foreign exchange market experienced a far more nervous day yesterday than might have been surmised from the relatively small net changes in the leading European currencies. In foreign ex

LONDON, March 29.--Great Britain today delivered her first military answer to Germany's seizure of Czecho-Slovakia by doubling the size of the Territorial Army, the "citizen army" similar to the National Guard in the United States.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 29.-- Miss Rosamond Ely and Homer Spofford, whose engagement was announced in January, will be married here the afternoon of April 22 in the Hitchcock Memorial Church.

ALBANY, March 29.--Acting on the request of the New York City Council, the Legislature passed today the Coudert-Crews bill permitting Robert Moses, as the one-man Triborough Bridge Authority, to construct a bridge from the Battery in Manhattan to Brooklyn.

The annual report of Gimbell Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries, issued for publication today by Bernard F. Gimbel, president, shows sales of $87,963,346 for the year ended on Jan. 31, against $100,080,574 for the preceding fiscal year, a decrease of 12.1 per cent.
VALENCIA, Spain, March 29. --Nationalist authorities formally took over Valencia at 1 P.M. today without meeting resistance.

Announcement of the proposed export subsidy plan caused a break of half a cent a pound on the Liverpool Cotton Exchange yesterday, narrowed relations between near and distant positions on the Cotton Exchange here about 16 points and under the most active trading in some time left the local market 7 points lower to 9 points higher.

Six subpoenas requiring the production of membership lists of local units of the German American Bund were issued yesterday to local Bund leaders at the request of William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in the sales tax in
MADRID, March 29 (AP).--After the fall of Albacete, last of Spain's provincial capitals to give up, the Nationalists officially announced: "The war has ended, Total Victory is Franco's."

The trial of John Torrio, the silent little man who for more than three decades has moved in a mysterious way through the criminal history of New York, Chicago and the Atlantic seaboard, got away to a swift start in Federal court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--A high Administration official said today that Leon Henderson, economist and secretary of the Federal Monopoly Committee, would probably be appointed soon to the chairmanship of the securities commission. He said also that the position, to be vacated when William O. Douglas, present chairman, is

The Board of Superintendents, in an unprecedented step, "drafted" yesterday women members of the New York City school system to apply for seven vacant positions as junior high school principals paying $7,500 each. For the first time in many years, it was said, women teachers are reluctant to apply for the administrative posts.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 29.--Robert Tyre Jones Jr., retired "grand slam" champion of golf, figured today he might make a fair showing in the sixth annual Augusta national tournament starting tomorrow "if I can get some putts to drop."

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The economy group of the House Appropriations Committee forced a reduction by the committee today of $50,000,000 in the $150,000,000 fund requested by President Roosevelt to finance relief for the rest of this fiscal year.
TOKYO, March 29.--Premier Kiichiro Hiranuma made a lengthy statement to Japanese newspaper men this evening to explain the government's course, but he said nothing indicating any change in policy.

The Police Department's practice of tagging illegally parked cars has not been invalidated by the Appellate Term of the Court of Special Sessions, it was explained yesterday by Chief Justice William R. Bayes, to correct an erroneous implication in an account published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 24.

Compliance with the Fair Labor Standards Act has been the rule and violation a minor exception, Ralph J. Watkins, assistant Wages and Hours Administrator, declared last night at the annual dinner of the National Knitted Outerwear Association at the Hotel Astor.

A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank will offer today to the public an issue of $73,444,000 of Metropolitan Water District of Southern California 4 per cent and 3 per cent Colorado River waterworks refunding bonds.
CHICAGO, March 29.--Indications were today that Chicago's Summer market events would show a greater uniformity of dates than for some years past.

There are only a few composers who can stand a program consisting wholly of their works. One of these is Beethoven, and last night, at the Philharmonio-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall, Mr. Barbirolli offered his audience a program consisting entirely of Beethoven music.

WARSAW, Poland, March 29.-- Poland, reluctant to join France and Britain in a bloc against Germany, has started talks with the Nazis to settle the future status of the Free City of Danzig, it was learned tonight.

DALLAS, Texas, March 29.--The Giants' two-day junket into Texas ended in a complete washout today when a combination rain, sleet and thunderstorm swept out of the Panhandle to frustrate all attempts for the second successive afternoon to stage a game with the Dallas Steers.

The Non-Sectarian Committee for German Refugee Children announced yesterday a tentative plan drawn up by child welfare experts for the selection, handling and placement of the 20,000 German refugee children who would be admitted to the United States this year and next year under the terms of the Wagner-Rogers bill now before Congress.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 30.--Before a packed chamber and crowded galleries Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King declared in the Dominion House of Commons this afternoon that his government would never conscript Canadians for service overseas.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--The Federal Trade Commission today announced a draft of trade practice rules for the mirror manufacturing industry to be the subject of a public hearing at the commission's offices here on April 18. They will supersede trade practice rules adopted for this industry on Dec. 31, 1936.
WASHINGTON, March 30.--The Navy Department contracted today for a seventh great aircraft carrier to be known as the Hornet and to cost, exclusive of armor and armament, $31,800,000.
A proposal that a Metropolitan Intercollegiate Conference be formed of New York City colleges was made last night at the annual dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers at the Hotel Lincoln.

One "thousand guests at the remodeled and enlarged building of the New York Historical Society, at 170 Central Park West, yesterday afternoon heard Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler praise the renovated museum as an expression of that intellectual and spiritual zeal "which is rapidly giving Manhattan Island the position of leadership in the world."

Following the example of high police officials, 230 ranking officers of the Fire Department told Mayor La Guardia yesterday that they would take a 5 per cent salary cut for the fiscal year 1939-40, a step that will save the city $64,645 in addition to the $50,000 saved by the police slash, offered on Wednesday.
Loans on new apartment houses in the Bronx featured realty fi nancing reported yesterday by mortgage brokers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30.--On the eve of commercial negotiations with Germany, Yugoslav official circles are at pains to explain that their scope will be strictly limited and the conversations will not be allowed to develop into a vast scheme threatening this country's economic independence.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--The Spanish Embassy in Washington and all Spanish consular offices in the United States will be placed in the hands of representatives of the Cuban Government tomorrow, according to well-founded reports current here tonight.

Again, and for the eighteenth year, the American Merchant Marine Library Association makes its annual appeal for books for seamen, especially for those who sail on American freight and cargo ships--not the "luxury liners," which are abundantly supplied.

The bond market, after creeping upward during the greater part of yesterday, broke sharply in the final hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Sales of department stores in the New York Federal Reserve District during the four weeks ended March 25 were almost 3 per cent higher, than in the corresponding period last year, the most favorable ...

WASHINGTON, March 30.--President Roosevelt today nominated Fred H. Brown, former Senator from New Hampshire, for Controllet General of the United States, which has been vacant for two and a half years since the statutory retirement of J.R. McCarl.

PARIS, March 30.--Colonial Minister Georges Mendel before the Colonies Commission of the Chamber of Deputies gave a reassuring account yesterday of what had been accomplished since last Fall to improve the French Empire's defenses.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 30. --Two of three players picked by Manager Leo Durocher for his regular outfield sat on the bench today while the Dodgers stopped a Tiger five-game winning streak. Brooklyn won by 6--4, with the pitching credit going to Luke Hamlin and the loss to little Tommy Bridges.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--Vice President Garner's boom for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1940 reached the floor of the Senate today when Senator Connally of Texas read a resolution of the Texas Legislature endorsing Mr. Garner for that honor.

BOWIE, Md., March 30.--An allMaryland victory was scored today at Bowie, where the Eastern racing season began with a triumph for Rough Time as the patrons were handled without gloves by both the weather and the favorites.
Robert M. West, a member of the law firm of Sherman Sterling, leased an apartment containing ten rooms and four baths in 520 East Eighty-sixth Street from Vincent Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--Ignoring President Roosevelt's suggestion for a cotton expert subsidy program, the Senate agriculture committee approved today a bill which would permit farmers to reclaim up to 3,000,000 bales of stocks now held as collateral for government loans.
LONDON, March 30.--The stock markets were narrowly irregular today. A session of fluctuations ended with liquidation of early gains in most sections. Business remained small.

There have been some significant orchestral performances by resident and visiting orchestras this week in this city and yet the performance of two symphonies, no more or less, and very familiar symphonies, at that, make the concert given by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall memorable.
BOSTON, March 30.--The author ity of the Legislature was invoked today in an effort to check the latest extra-curricular activity in the colleges--goldfish swallowing.

Three Cardinals who participated in the electoral conclave and the coronation of Pope Plus XII in Rome returned yesterday, expressing pleasure at the outcome of the election and high hope for the future of the church under its new leader.

As a means of ridding the New York City school system of mentally or physically incompetent teachers, Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Bronx member of the Board of Education, proposed yesterday that principals and administrative heads be held personally responsible for reporting unfit teacherS to the school officials.

A total of 1,059,252 persons in Brazil were vaccinated in 1938 with the new vaccine against yellow fever developed in 1937 by the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation, it is revealed in a review of the foundation's activities for last year by its president, Raymond B. Fosdick, made public here yesterday.

The first run of channel bass is nosy on along the North Carolina coast, according to word received from Bill Sharpe. The first fish of the season was taken off Hatteras, from the surf, by a local angler and tipped the scales at forty pounds.

The 150 largest commercial banks of the United States and the British Empire showed total deposits of $57,484,604,686 at the end of 1938, a new record high, according to the thirteenth annual compilation of deposit liabilities by the California Bank, Los Angeles.

BERLIN, March 30.--An exhaustive exposition of the principles, scope and aims of Germany's new finance and credit policy and the economic and financial relations of the Reich with foreign countries was furnished today by Walther Funk, President of the Reichsbank ...

Henry Armstrong again will defend his welterweight championship of the world when he tackles Davey Day, sharp-punching Chicago battler, in the star bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

MONTREAL, March 30 (Canadian Press).--Extension of air service to the Maritime Provinces and western Ontario was forecast today by S.J. Hungerford, president, in the annual report of Trans-Canada Air Lines.

The Transit Commission yesterday adjourned until April 28 its public hearing on deficiencies of Interborough Rapid Transit service after Arthur G. Peacock of counsel for the company had promised that service improvements would be made.
An indictment charging conspiracy to "fix" for $50 an abortion charge involving a Brooklyn physician was filed yesterday by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen against William F. McGuinness, ...

LONDON, March 30.--A new broadcasting service to reach listeners over telephone wires--which, of course, would be immune from radio interference or jamming by hostile foreign radio stations in wartime--is to be developed throughout Britain, according to G.C. Tryon, Postmaster General, who controls Britain's telephones.

HARTFORD, Conn., Harch 30.-- Viggo E. Bird, until yesterday president of the Hartford Electric Light Company and its associate, the Connecticut Power Company, was arrested tonight at the Hartford County Court House by Edward J. Hickey,

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP).-- Officials, carefully studying the effects in Latin America of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's complete victory in Spain, are firmly convinced that Germany and Italy will seek to better their position in the southern part of the Western Hemisphere, with General Franco as their driving wedge.

Lewis E. Pierson resigned as chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company at the regular meeting of the board yesterday afternoon, after having served the bank and its predecessor for fortyone years, the last twenty-three as chairman.
Banks were among the sellers of properties traded yesterday in Manhattan.

The marriage of Miss Suzanne Klauber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Klauber of 885 Park Avenue, to Henry Sicher Abenheimer, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Abenheimer, took place last night in the White and Gold Suite of the Plaza. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman.

WARSAW, Poland, March 30.-- Opposition political leaders today gave the Polish Government assurances that reliable sources said were a pledge of cooperation against any German attempt to "trample on Polish rights."

The Corlear's Hook section of the lower East Side will figure prominently in the city's housing news in the months just ahead. Several blocks in that old neighborhood will be utilized as the site for Manhattan's latest public housing enterprise--a joint city and Federal project which is designed to supply low-rent apartments for about 1,775 families.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 30.--Old man weather, who has been much more of a master over the masters' golf tournament than has Bobby Jones, in whose honor the tournament was inaugurated some six years ago, horned in again today just to keep his record clear.
For the tenth successive year Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. heads the ranking of the National Squash Tennis Association.

BOSTON, March 30.--Clint Smith kept the New York Rangers in the running for the Stanley Cup by blasting a long shot past Frank Brimsek into the Bruins' cage tonight. Smith's goal, made in 17 minutes and 19 seconds of the first overtime period, enabled the New York skaters to gain a hard-earned victory by the score of 2 to 1.

ALBANY, Ga., March 30 (AP).-- John Jay Watson, New York financier, died of a heart attack while at work in his office in the Albany Exchange Bank Building today. He was 64 years old.

Ten more arrests were made yesterday in the investigation started ten weeks ago by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey into the looting of nickels from station turnstiles in the city's independent subway system.

The cotton export subsidy program offered by President Roosevelt would work to the detriment of the domestic textile industry, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of the Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, said yesterday.
Furniture volume for 1939 should show an increase of 10 per cent over 1938, N.S. Sachs, president of the National Retail Furniture Association, asserted yesterday.

LONDON, March 30.--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is expected to announce to the House of Commons tomorrow the momentous decision that Great Britain and France would give full armed assistance to Poland in case of aggression by Germany.
MADRID, March 30.--Nationalist authorities imposed stern measures today to crush any lingering Republican opposition to the civil war victors.

THE regular order of business would be some mild comment on the approaching Armstrong-Day debate at Madison Square Garden this evening with the world's welterweight championship at stake, but another topic is more alluring.

BENTON, Md., March 30.-- Puppies and representatives of local owners struggled against adverse conditions today in the first two stakes of the annual Spring field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club, which was started this noon on the estate of R.R. M. Carpenter of Mont Chanin, Del. The grounds extend along the banks of the Bohemia River.
Our dispatches report that Mr. Chamberlain is expected to make in the House of Commons today an announcement which, we are entitled to believe, will profoundly affect the destiny of Europe.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30.-- Contestants stuck to the form charts in the first four events of the national A.A.U. indoor swimming championships tonight at the Ohio State University pool, three defending titleholders repeating their 1938 victories and the champion Buckeye team taking the lead on points.

ROME, March 30.--In his annual report to the stockholders of the Bank of Italy, Dr. Vincenzo Azzolini, its governor, disclosed today that on Dec. 31, 1938, Italy's gold reserves amounted to 3,826,000,000 lire, inclusive of 152,000,000 in credits abroad [the lira is currently quoted at 5.26 cents].

As an immediate result of last Autumn's war scare, $1,083,289,000 foreign gold came to this country in September and October, 1938; $968,828,000 of it from Europe. October's gold import, $562,381,000, exceeded by more than $100,000,000 the highest previous monthly record.

The frivolous collegiate tradition of the all-male chorus line reigned last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor as Columbia undergraduates in wigs and skirts romped through "Fair Enough," the forty-fifth annual varsity show of the Columbia University Players.
WASHINGTON, March 30.--Registration statements were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation and the Fairchild Aviation Corporation.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30.-- Fred Spuhn, who is in the second year of his coaching tenure at Princeton and whom Ed Leader once called the toughest oarsman he ever coached at Washington, spent three hours with Tiger oarsmen on a rainy, chill Carnegie Lake today and spoke of prospects and plans.
PARIS, March 30.--Re-election to the Presidency of the French Republic was offered on a silver platter to President Albert Lebrun tonight.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 30. --Pit Terrier, 3-year-old owned by Louis Stroube and I.J. Collins, scored his second victory in six starts this year today when he came from far hack to capture the sixfurlong feature at Tropical Park.

Because the Federal Wage-Hour Act was badly conceived and badly drawn in many ways, its original sponsors, at the request of the administrator of the act, are now compelled to offer amendments. These amendments are in the right direction.

LOS ANGELES, March 30 (AP).-- The Cubs routed Los Angeles, 12 to 1, today in their farewell California exhibition. Of more interest to Manager Gabby Hartnett, however, was Dizzy Dean's official 1939 pitching debut.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 30.-- Two Northerners and two Southerners survived the quarter-final round of the thirty-seventh annual North and South invitation golf championship for women over the No. 3 course of the Pinehurst Country Club today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30.-- The lakefront terrace adjoining the orange gardens of the Everglades Club was the setting for a cocktail party given today by Mrs. Adolphus Busch 3d.

Balked in his effort to eliminate WNYC, the city radio station, from the budget, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx warned his colleagues on the Board of Estimate yesterday that the City Council would cut the "wind-jamming machine" out of the budget in May.

ROME, March 30.--Premier Edouard Daladier's speech brought forth an immediate reaction from Premier Mussolini, who in a speech today said that "Italy does not intend to remain suffocated in the Mediterranean."
WESTFIELD, N.J., March 30.-- The Presbyterian Church here will be the setting the evening of May 13 for the marriage of Miss Emilie Streat Lewis and Dr. Frank Thompson Bell.

A convocation said to be unprecedented in this country was held yesterday in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue with more than 250 rabbis taking part in prayers and traditional chants for the deliverance of oppressed Jews overseas.
STREATOR, Ill., March 30.-- Frank Farrington, one of the bestknown mine union leaders in Illinois, died in his home today at the age of 66. He had suffered a heart attack on Monday.

Masterpieces of French art from 1500 to 1900 will be shipped to this country for display in the French Pavilion at the World's Fair, according to Georges Wildenstein, who has been appointed by the French Government to arrange the exhibition and who arrived yesterday on the Normandie.
ALBANY, March 30.--Governor Lehman, working on a particularly heavy lot of ten-day bills, today signed sixteen measures and vetoed two others.

CHICAGO, March 30.--Rumors of unfavorable developments in the European political situation and the sharp sell-off in securities enlivened trading in grain futures late in the session today. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at gains of 3/8 to cent a bushel. Kansas City, Minneapolis and Winnipeg gained a like amount.
ALBANY, March 30.--Governor Lehman today nominated Captain Arthur W. Brandt as State Superintendent of Public Works to succeed the late Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--President Roosevelt threatened today to use his veto power to prevent the imposition of higher import taxes on vegetable oils and the virtual repudiation thereby of the Hull trade agreements policies.

BERLIN, March 30.--An official intimation that Germany regards the situation of her national minority in Poland as unsatisfactory and that the Polish-German minority agreement was "incomplete," was given tonight by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, speaking at a meeting of members of the foreign diplomatic services and foreign press.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 30. --The Slovak border commission returned here early today and resumed its sessions.

MADISON, Wis., March 30.-- Benny Alperstein, Maryland 135pounder seeking his third straight title, was defeated tonight in a first-round match of the National Collegiate Athletic Association boxing tournament by Gene Rankin of the University of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, today sent a letter to officers of all national and State banks admonishing them not to let any reasonable loans go unsupplied.

SHREVEPORT, La., March 30.-- After their two damp and ill-spent days in Texas, the Giants almost found the combination of a brilliant Louisiana sun and a capacity crowd of 6,000 fans too much for them today.

LISBON, Portugal, March 30.-- The Yankee Clipper arrived in Lisbon at 4:15 o'clock this afternoon, having covered the 1,200 miles from Horta, the Azores, on the second stage of her first transatlantic flight in 7 hours 7 minutes.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--There was an increase of 9 per cent in manufacturers sales in February as compared with the corresponding month a year ago, according to figures issued today in a joint study by the Bureau of the Census in cooperation with the National Association of Credit Men.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30.--This was moving day for the Yankees. Players who for most of the last five weeks gave their attention almost exclusively to conditioning themselves devoted their time to packing and dispatching trunks, arranging transportation for their families and general cleaning up at Hugging Field.

Plans are now under way to send 100,000 needy children of this city to camps this Summer--an increase of 20,000 over last year--Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, president of the Children's Welfare Federation, announced yesterday.

CLINTON, N.J., March 30.-- While rain pelted dawn constantly, the annual four-day Spring meeting of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club got under way today with Thorne's Lou, owned by Jonathan Thorne of Greenwich, Conn., gaining the top award in the open Spring derby for puppies.

BOSTON, March 30.--A victoryflushed line of Rangers piled into the visitors' dressing room in the Boston Garden tonight after their second straight National Hockey League play-off victory over the Bruins and proceeded to pound one another in sheer exhilaration.

Classification and segregation of inmates of New York State's prisons according to their educational needs and abilities was recommended yesterday in a report of the Division of Education of the Department of Correction, prepared with the help of the Governor's Commission on Education in Correctional Institutions.

PARIS, Friday, March 31.-- France, working with Britain to stop Adolf Hitler in Eastern Europe, early today initialed a commercial accord with Rumania and was reported to have invited Foreign Minister Josef Beck of Poland to Paris after his London talks next week.

The A.S.B. Realty Company, a subsidiary of the A.S. Beck Shoe Company, has renewed its lease on the six-story loft building at 60 Thomas Street, between Church Street and West Broadway. The Haggstrom-Callen-Davis Company negotiated the renewal.

Eight junior high school principals, three of them women, were nominated by the Board of Superintendents at a special meeting yesterday. Two of the women are among those who were "drafted" last week to appear for examinations.

TOKYO, March 31.--Japan announced today that she had annexed the seven Spratly Islands, 700 miles southwest of Manila, which had been formally claimed by France in 1933 and that a "commercial" air service would start next week between Yokohama and Saipan, seventy miles north of Guam, United States naval station, 1,500 miles east of Manila.
In the Brooklyn trading reported yesterday a number of mufti-family houses passed into new hands, many of them being sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31.--A "sandwich" of two pieces of plate glass, each less than one-eighth of an inch thick, with a filling of a new highly elastic material known as polyvinyl acetal resin, was introduced to the public today under the auspices of the Franklin Institute. The formula was worked out at a cost of $6,000,000 in six years of research.
MADISON, Wis., March 31.--Five members of the University of Wisconsin's powerful boxing team tonight advanced to the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's fifth annual tournament.
One of the greatest rarities in American literature has come to light here from an unkonwn source.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--The Democratic cleavage in the Senate, accentuated since the attempted "purge" last Fall, resulted today in an acrimonious debate over Federal spending in which Senator Smith of South Carolina flung at the New Deal leaders a charge that the spending program was inseparable from vote-getting efforts.

BERLIN, March 31.--The formal British and French pledges to defend Poland's independence with all the means at their power, if the Poles find it necessary to fight for it, announced by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today, created a profound impression in German official quarters amounting to consternation.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--The announcement in Tokyo of the beginning of "commercial" air service between Yokohama and Saipan in the Marianne Islands was linked in the views of official experts here with the assumption by Japan of jurisdiction over the Spratly Islands and her occupation earlier of Hainan Island.

Libby Holman Reynolds, stage star and torch singer, widow of Smith Reynolds, tobacco heir who was slain on July 6, 1932, at his home near Winston-Salem, N.C., was married last Monday to Ralph Holmes, 23-year-old actor of this city, it was disclosed yesterday.

Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation has set up the largest advertising budget in its history for the 1939-40 season, it was revealed at Chicago yesterday at the company's annual sales convention. C.E. McCarthy, advertising director, placed the appropriation at $2,000,000, almost three-quarters of which will be spent in newspapers.

NEWARK, N.J., March 31.--Former Commissioner Anthony F. Minisi took the witness stand in his own defense today at the city land conspiracy trial and, like his fellow-defendants who had preceded him, denied having taken part in any conspiracy to defraud the city.

SHANGHAI, March 31 (AP).--Chinese today reported increased Chinese opposition to the Japanese in the Shanghai and Hangchow Bay areas. In the last forty-eight hours guerrillas moved so close to Shanghai that the firing of machine guns could be heard here.
As four ninety-foot pylons flamed into pillars of blue and golden fire, the gas industry's "Court of Flame" and "home of tomorrow" received a spectacular dedication last night at the World's Fair.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 31.--A call for the condition of State banks, trust companies, industrial banks and private bankers as of March 29 was issued today by William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, the weekly bulletin of the department announced.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was more active than in February. The largest day's business was 2,888,390 shares, on March 22, also the largest of the year, and the smallest was 465,280 shares, on March 29.

Carpenter, which extends along the shores of the Bohemia River.

LOS ANGELES, March 31.--Mme. Norma K. Lutge, America's first woman impresario and a patron of art and music, who made 125 trips to Europe to bring to this country the best of the Old World's musical talent, died last night at her home here after an illness of several days. She was 85 years old.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 31 (AP).--The boundary dispute between Hungary and Slovakia, over which the two countries clashed last week, was settled today through concessions on both sides.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--Imposition of trade barriers abroad should hold no terrors for the American exporter who applies intelligent effort and reliable information to his search for new and wider foreign markets, electrical manufacturers were assured today by officials of the Commerce Department in the concluding session of a two-day conference.

It covers, they think, every act of aggression and every fait accompliviolating Poland's treaty rights.
