TAMPA, Fla., March 31.--Bill McKechnie didn't have enough cooks to spoil the broth of victory for his Reds over Leo Durocher's Dodgers today, although the one he used-a right-handed rookie pitcher named Earl Cook-certainly did his best while the Dodgers were at the "dish."

The serious accident in the Steinway Loop of the city-owned Independent Subway System mars a clear record of safe operation covering almost seven years. Automatic safeguards failed to control the human judgment by which danger signals must be interpreted.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is an active and aggressive candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, close friends of his said today.

MOSCOW, March 31.--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement that Britain and France were pledged to support the integrity of Poland was received here with modified gratification. The game was a semi-final in the Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament.

Two new regulations in the Health Department's drive for completely sanitary conditions in the sale of dairy products went into effect last midnight. One requires that cream be sold in its original bottle or container and the second that cream be bottled at the place where it is pasteurized.

MEDFORD, N.J., March 31.-- Two events in the annual Spring meet of the South Jersey Field Trial Club, which opened a threeday competition near here today, were completed late this afternoon. A total of thirty-five dogs took part in the two stakes.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 31.--The annexation of Patagonia by the Third Reich is one of the objectives of the present Nazi penetration of Argentina, according to a secret document published here last night.

Henry Boewig, the oldest member of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra before his retirement several years ago and who was librarian of that organization for more than forty years, died yesterday in his home, 1,435 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

Ziegler, pathologist of the Federal Public Health Service, assigned to the Marine Hospital at Chelsea. His statement was unqualifiedly supported by several of the city's leading pathologists.

Henry Armstrong battered the courageous Davey Day to the canvas at Madison Square Garden last night and in so doing successfully defended his welterweight championship of the world. Armstrong, who holds the lightweight title as well as the 147-pound crown, knocked out his Chicago challenger in 2 minutes and 49 seconds of the twelfth round of a scheduled fifteen-round affray.

Negro music that ran the gamut from primitive African tribal melo-- dies to sophisticated contemporary choral works was heard from the Mwalimu Festival Chorus, under Manet Harrison Fowler, at its first Town Hall concert last night.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 31.--Faction Fighter, from the Rokeby Stables of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon, heads a field of eight timbertoppers named for the tenth running of the Carolina Cup race over the Springdale Course tomorrow. This is one of the best fields that has competed for the trophy in years.

Mrs. Thomas Barbour Paxton of New York and Cincinnati has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Paxton, to Edward Tytus Gardner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner of Dayton, Ohio.

WOODLANDS, N.Y., March 31.-- Great puffs of smoke billowed from the stovepipe stack of a trim redand-gold locomotive, cascaded back over three yellow coaches and drifted off in the hills of Westchester today as the pages of railroad history were turned back nearly threescore and ten to the days of Jim Fisk and Jay Gould. PRAGUE, April 1.--Emil Vadnay, since 1926 one of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff for Central and Southeastern Europe, died in a nursing home here tonight of a complication of diseases, including diabetes and pleurisy, He was 47 years old.

The Federal Government is receiving returns steadily on its investments in insured savings and loan associations, made when thrift institutions throughout the country needed more funds to supply the demand for sound home loans in their communities, it was revealed ...
BATON ROUGE, La., April 1.-- The Giant reserves succeeded where the regulars failed today as the Terrymen resumed hostilities with the Cleveland Indians.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 1.-- Johnnie J., claimed by Miss C. Hardin out of his last race for $1,500, came right back in his first effort under her silks today to win the $2,000 allowance race for 2year-olds featuring the Tropical Park card.

To raise funds for the emergency needs of the Travelers Aid Society, a musicale and tea will be given on April 12 in the auditorium of the International Business Machines Corporation, 590 Madison Avenue.

Slung aboard the forward deck of the Furness Bermuda liner Queen of Bermuda yesterday afternoon just before she sailed were the four International Class racing yachts from Long Island Sound which wlll start their much series with the Bermudian Internationals on Wednesday.

CLEARWATER, Fla., April 1.-- In the drizzling rain that washed out today's scheduled Tiger-Dodger game the veteran Tony Lazzeri kept running up and down in a far corner of the field as if he were carrying that famed message to Garcia and didn't intend to fail to deliver it.

ROME, April 1.--Since Premier Benito Mussolini's speech last Sunday it has become increasingly apparent that the problems outstanding between the Italian and French Governments, as stated by official Italian diplomacy, are not identical with the aspirations of the Italian people as voiced by the press.
A new development oP twenty homes is now being constructed by the Ramapo Heights Corporation, Robert H. Gittins president, at Sloatsburg, Rockland County.

THE broadcast tactics of superimposing local comment and snatches of translation on im portant international speeches from Europe is causing American listeners who can understand foreign languages to suggest that a new technique be adopted.

VERACRUZ, Mexico, April 1.-- Veracruz, one of the oldest and most important ports of Mexico, views its glutted warehouses and piers today with concern. Merchants and freight brokers fear that the time may come when the port will be unable to handle any more merchandise and that ships bringing cargoes will have to go elsewhere to unload.

In a speech yesterday which he took extraordinary precautions should not be broadcast to the German people, Chancellor Hitler showed great moderation in answering the action of London and Paris in giving military guarantees to Poland against an attack by Nazi Germany.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1.--Farmer Gene Sarazen pulled a rough April Fool joke on the field in the masters' tournament today when he tied the course record on the famous Augusta National layout and took the lead in the sixth annual event which commemorates Bobby Jones's past feats in golf.

Considerable activity at Atlantic Beach, L.I, is reported by builders and brokers operating in that vicinity. New homes are being erected; several plots and dwellings have been sold; leasing is running ahead of last year and several of the beach clubs at the resort are constructing additional facilities.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 1.-- An appraisal of $36,260 was placed on the estate of F. Donald Coster Musica, president of the McKesson Robbins Company when he committed suicide, an inventory filed with Judge Bradford Boardman in Fairfield Probate Court revealed today.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, April 4.-The forty-two-ton Yankee Clipper alighted in the harbor here at 2:30 this afternoon after a flight of 700 miles in less than five hours from Marseille, France.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (AP).-- John A. McCarthy, Philadelphia financier, died today after an illness of three months. He was 66 years old. Executive vice president of the Real Estate Trust Company, he was also a trustee of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 4 (AP). -- The Pirates smeared the Browns, 14 to 1, in an exhibition game today behind the excellent hurling of Cy Blanton, who yielded only six hits in seven innings. The other St. Louis hit was a single off Truett Sewell in the ninth.

Although members of the American Physical Society disapprove the present German course of action, they are not in favor of barring American laboratories to visiting German scientists, Dr. W.A. Shurcliff, a member of the society, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, April 4.--The Republican swing which started last November continued in operation throughout Michigan in the State elections yesterday when the entire Republican ticket was voted into office.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP).-- Steamship operators and seamen's unions endorsed today legislation to outlaw stowing away on intercoastal and overseas vessels.

Mrs. William S. Stokes of Philadelphia gave a luncheon yesterday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Her guests included Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley, Mrs. Robert Hillas, Mrs. William Ahearn, Miss Hope Kingsley, Mrs. Ralph H. Boots, Miss Dorothy Hillas, Mrs. Joseph Mann and Mrs. John M. Kingsley.

PARIS, April 4 (AP).--France tonight disclosed she was reinforcing her defenses in the Sanjak (district) of Alexandretta, Syria, after Turkey had informed her of a desire to annex the 10,000-square mile area "as quickly as possible."

CLEVELAND, April 4 (AP).--Murray Fowler, 50-year-old Steubenville bowling alley owner, took first place in all-events in the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a total of 1,973 pins, two more than William Beisner Jr. of Watertown, Wis.
BOSTON, April 4.--Four naval airmen were killed when two bombing planes, flying in squadron manoeuvre above the launching of the aircraft carrier Wasp, struck wings and crashed.

WASHINGTON, April 4.--Colonel Henry L. Stimson, who was Secretary of State under President Hoover, will be the first witness before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee when it begins its neutrality hearing tomorrow morning.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 4.Five hundred retail food dealers voted unanimously here today to join the growing revolt against the Indiana Gross Income Tax Law. They charged that it was working on business men the greatest hardship ever imposed by taxation.

CHICAGO, April 4.--Mayor Edward J. Kelly, Democrat, was reelected Mayor of Chicago today by a plurality of 183,410 over Dwight H. Green, his Republican opponent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4.Bobs Watson, the youngster who attracted attention in "Alexander Graham Bell" and "Dodge City," was engaged today by Metro for the role of Pud in "On Borrowed Time," the part that was filled on the stage by Peter Holden.

An 8-year-old son of a Park Avenue physician held an eleven-story apartment building in a state of siege at 5 o'clock last night as he trained his older brother's 22 caliber rifle across a courtyard from the ninth floor of 383 Park Avenue and sniped at a ventilator on a building at 118 East Fifty-fourth Street.

Plans for improvement of part of the land owned by Ben Riley, operator of the Arrowhead Inn, in Riverdale, were filed yesterday in the Bronx.

Many of the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday were made with operators and institutions figuring as principals. Most of the parcels traded were multi-family structures, including several on Washington Heights and in Harlem.
A number of apartment houses, several single-family dwellings and a theatre building figured in the deals in New Jersey reported yesterday.

The joint Congressional committee which has just reported on the Tennessee Valley Authority consisted of five Democrats, one Independent Republican of New Deal sympathies, and three regular Republicans.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 4.-- President Roosevelt denounced today the strategy of some Senators and Representatives in forcing favorable action on pet measures by having them inserted as "riders" to major legislative enactments on which there appears to be general agreement.
Tom Iannicelli, world open squash tennis champion, started in quest of his fifth succesive title last night on the courts of the Shelton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 4.-There was a general decline of European and South American purchases of United States goods in February, according to statistics on this country's foreign trade for the month and made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Police Lieutenant Cuthbert J. Behan, who has threatened departmental revelations that will "shock New York," was indicted yesterday on three counts charging seconddegree grand larceny, unlawful removal and mutilation of public rec- ...

CLEARWATER, Fla., April 4.If Big Al Todd has any weakness for proverbs, any one of several old saws must have come to his mind today, such as the "ill wind," "the long lane" or the one that "one man's meat is another man's poison."

Negotiations are under way to equip two or three Broadway motion-picture theatres with Baird television apparatus by May 15, according to Arthur A. Lee, vice president and general manager of Gaumont-British Corporation of America, which owns a controlling interest in Baird Television.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 4.Flawless pitching and relentless hammering of the ball, with Joe DiMaggio once more leading the attack, floored another Texas League team today, as the Yankess trampled the Fort Worth Cats underfoot, 8 to 2.

Georges Enesco, Serge Prokofieff and Albert Stoessel will be guest conductors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next season when John Barbirolli, the permanent director, takes four weeks' rest in the course of the season, it was announced yesterday by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.

WASHINGTON, April 4.-Pierre S. du Pont on Feb. 24 returned 41,276 shares of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. common stock which he had borrowed on Oct. 25, 1929, according to his reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public today.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 4.-St. John's University used its heavy bats in its opening game with Princeton's nine on University Field today and handed the Tigers their third consecutive defeat, 11-3. The Redmen collected fifteen safeties, three of them triples, off two Bengal twirlers.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP).-- Vice President Garner has cautioned his two partners in a housing venture back home in Uvalde, Texas, not to go too deeply into debt.

BOSTON, April 4.-The mild bickering that makes a Boston-Toronto hockey play-off series official, at least as far as Managers Art Ross and Connie Smythe are concerned, commenced today when both demanded equipment changes.

After a debate which consumed less than two hours, "the greatest deliberative body in the world" on Monday passed a very important bill affecting our whole agricultural policy. It authorized farmers to buy at 5 cents a pound up to 3,000,000 of the more than ...

BOWIE, Md., April 4.-In his first race since last June, High Hedge, owned and trained by H. L. Bowers, lasted to beat Irish Moon by a head in the Halcyon Class C Handicap today. Unselfish trailed by a length in accounting for the show. Unable to win in seven previous starts last year, High Hedge completed the six furlongs in 1:14 and returned 13 to 1.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 4.-- Harry L. Hopkins, Secretary of Commerce, who has been mentioned as President Roosevelt's choice for the Democratic nomination in 1940, disclosed tonight that he planned in a few weeks to establish a legal residence at Grinell, Iowa.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 4.--Following the death early today of King Ghazi of Iraq from injuries received in an automobile accident his 3-year-old son was proclaimed King Feisal II.

The German Special Account Fund, from which payments are made to Americans proving claims against Germany arising out of the World War, will benefit to the extent of $800,000 from a ruling made yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe. Judge Coxe directed a jury, which had heard a suit against ...

Jack Benny, radio and screen actor, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to smuggling gift jewelry he had bought far his wife, paid a $10,000 fine, received a suspended jail sentence of one year and a day and was placed on probation for a year.

Owing to the Jewish Passover holidays there was no kosher slaughter in local markets yesterday. Slaughterers had larger supplies of light weight lamb, including plainer grades, than in several months. These were obtained for the Easter holiday trade and sold at very high prices compared with better grades of heavier weights.

Among the new attractions listed yesterday for the amusement area at the World's Fair were a Congress of Sixty Beauties of the World, a village of alligator-fighting Seminole Indians and a camp of Greek Amazons engaged in their warrior sports.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5.--Two more defendants, former Assistant Corporation Counsel Jules E. Tepper and David B. Raschkover, local real estate dealer, testified in their own behalf today at the opening of the twelfth court week of the city land trial.

Negotiating committees representing the Seafarers International Union and the Seatrain Lines, Inc., signed a collective bargaining agreement yesterday, ending a strike of the unlicensed personnel on the company's three vessels, Seatrain New York, Seatrain Havana and Seatrain New Orleans.

The timeless saga of a boy and his dog was renewed yesterday to the extreme gratification of Jerry McDonald, curly-haired and blue-eyed, who will be 6 years old today. He was the boy in the story. Pick, a 2-year-old Boston terrier, was the dog and Captain Thomas Harrison, a Chicago policeman, was the hero.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 5.-- Miss Sibyl Marvin Huse, wellknown practitioner of Christian Science, died here tonight in the home of her sister, Mrs. Charles B. Crane.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 5.-- Adhering to his formula of doing as little work as possible while vacationing here, President Roosevelt slipped away from the "little White House" on Georgia Warm Springs Foundation today to travel over dusty red clay roads on a visit to Cason Callaway, retired textile mill operator and a trustee of the infantile paralysis foundation.

Preparations for the Strauss Waltz Ball, which will be given April 21 in the ballroom suite of the RitzCarlton for the benefit of the National Orchestral Association, were advanced yesterday with the appointment of a debutante committee to assist with ticket sales and other material plans.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 5.-- A seven-point program in regional planning for the South was advanced here today by George B. Galloway, field representative of the National Economic and Social Planning Association, a private research and educational organization supported by the Whitney Foundation.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 5.-- Favorable word of the condition of Carl Hubbell's pitching arm and an encouraging demonstration of Dick Coffman's hurling condition came almost simultaneously today to reassure Colonel Bill Terry as he led the Giants through a workout, topped off with the last scrub game of the year.
LONDON, April 5.--Events have moved rapidly here since Monday. Nervous tension rises and falls in London like an intermittent fever, up today and down tomorrow.

A schedule of fifty feature films and four serials will be made by Republic Pictures during 1939-40, according to an announcement which will be made tomorrow at the opening of the company's Southern sales meeting in Houston, Texas.

The damage verdict in the Apex Hosiery Company case raises questions of such importance both for labor organizations and for employers that it would seem desirable to have a decision of the Supreme Court on the points of law involved. It has been indicated that appeal eventually will be taken to the high court in this case.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP).-- Representative August H. Andresen of Minnesota declared in the House today that President Roosevelt had written a "one-way economic ticket for the South" that, if followed, would cause "general disintegration of the nation."

MOSCOW, April 5.--The Soviet press today features long, cabled reports of the British House of Commons debate, which created an excellent impression here. The Russians are especially gratified by the statement of David Lloyd George that the "U.S.S.R, has 18,000,000 admirably trained, cultured and brave soldiers."

Leases of quarters in buildings in downtown Manhattan marked contracts for business space yesterday. The New York News Bureau, Inc., publisher of a ticker service furnishing world news, financial reports ...

DALLAS, Texas, April 5.--The Yankees' majestic sweep through Texas claimed no victim today for the simple reason that the elements intervened. A Texas twister swept down from the Panhandle at the very moment the world champions were licking their chops and preparing to go to work on the Dallas Steers.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., April 5.-- Walter L. Ross, retired president of the Nickel Plate Railroad and a native of Bloomington, died in Phoenix, Ariz., today, according to word received here. He was 74 years old. Surviving are a son, George S. Ross of Cleveland, and a daughter, Mrs. H.A. Crow of Toledo.

COLUMBIA, Mo., April 5.--The good old disputatious, Democratic techniques of the open forum were applauded to the echo this afternoon as the first National Conference on Consumer Education was adjourned in the auditorium of Stephens College. It marked an unprecedented assembly of delegates ...

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 5.--The funeral of King Ghazi this morning was the occasion of a remarkable display of the people's devotion to the throne. At least half of Baghdad's population of 300,000 appeared to have gathered in the neighborhood of the royal mausoleum, and their numbers were swelled by deputations of mourners sent by Basra and other provincial towns.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 5.--With little Tommy Bridges pitching calmly and expertly for seven innings and Paul (Dizzy) Trout giving the 2,000 Tiger fans the jitters for two innings, but still hurling effectively in the pinches, the Dodgers suffered their second whitewashing of the Citrus season today, bowing to Detroit by 2--0.
Sectional qualifying rounds for the United States open golf championship will be staged over thirtytwo courses throughout the country on May 22.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 5 (AP)-- A big second inning producing four runs started the Red Sox to a 9-to-4 victory over the Reds today. Singles by Manager Cronin, Bobby Doerr, Lefty Grove, a couple of infield plays and walks marked the big inning against Junior Thompson.

BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, April 5. --The Hlinka Guard, which played a leading role in founding the independence of Slovakia and cooperated with the military recently during the frontier incidents in Eastern Slovakia, will be reorganized as a ...

A ninth-inning uprising by the C.C.N.Y. baseball team caused unlimited excitement at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, but it all went for naught as the belated Lavender rally fell short and the N.Y.U. nine clung grimly to a one-run advantage as it recorded a thrilling 4-3 decision.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5.-- "Stronger Than Desire," a Metro property written by W.E. Woodward, will go into production next week with Robert Montgomery in the lead, the studio announced today.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow through Monday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary ...

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Changes in important commands, including the air base at San Diego, the aircraft carriers Lexington and Ranger and the battleship division of the Battle Force of the Fleet were announced today by the Navy Department.

Rumors of an impending largescale policy war in Harlem were heightened with the murder Tuesday night of Anthony Milone, 32 year-old small-time policy collector with a record of four arrests and known to police as an associate of Joey Rao, Harlem gangster.

A system that may change the whole conception of modern radio studio design, making it possible for engineers to create over the home receiver the quality of musical tone heard in a concert hall, even though the performers play in a small "dead" studio, was demonstrated here last night.

Members of the Democratic County Committee of the Eighth Assembly District, said to number 350 out of the 402 in the district, met last night at 138 Second Avenue and elected M. Michael Edelstein Tammany leader of the district to succeed Charles A. Schneider, who resigned because of criticism of his leadership.

Large supplies of country dressed Spring lamb and kid goats are on the local market this week for the Easter trade. The market was fairly active on these and prices about in line with last year. Twenty-five to thirty-five pound fancy Spring lamb dressed with head, pelt and feet on and carrying the naslet, are selling from $6-$9 per head with few extra fancy slightly more and some plain to medium light ...

CHICAGO, April 5.--President Roosevelt appealed today for the destruction of interstate tariff walls, which, he said, threaten the nation with "social and economic problems even more serious than international tariffs."

Claude G. Bowers, retiring Ambassador to Spain, sailed on the United States liner Manhattan last night to return to his post at the temporary Embassy at Saint Jeande-Luz, saying that he would probably return here late in April.

Paul M. Hahn, vice president of the American Tobacco Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting held at Jersey City yesterday that sales for the first quarter of 1939 were substantially ahead of those in the corresponding period of 1938. While earnings came within 11 cents of covering the full ...

W.K. Vanderbilt, a director of the New York Central Railroad, held 39,085 shares of its capital stock on March 15, the company announced yesterday. He holds also 28,818 shares of stock of the Pittsburgh Lake Erie Railroad, 600 common shares of the Mahoning Coal Railroad and thirty shares of ...

The President is thoroughly justified both in calling attention to the irrelevant "rider" attached to the emergency national defense measure and in denouncing the general practice of which this is an example--though it must be remembered that the Administration itself has, on occasion, used the method of the "rider" to further its own ends.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP).--Another shipping strike on the West Coast was forecast today by Harry Lundeberg, head of the A.F.L. Sailors Union of the Pacific, if the Maritime Commission goes ahead with plane to establish hiring halls there.

MEXICO CITY, April 5.--Mexico's barter trade with Italy and Germany, it was learned today, is about to enter the inevitable second phase, that of resale of products imported in exchange for oil. This phase seems destined to increase the Mexican Government's grip on private industry.

In a year which is the "most vital" in the history of this country, The American people may be expected to solve their problems on a "sound and permanent basis," Howard Coonley, chairman of the board of the Walworth Company and president of the National ...
LONDON, April 5.--The end of the fortnightly accounts today found the stock markets quiet and depressed with the imminence of the Easter holidays tending to hold down the values of business.

As the Army Day parade moves down Fifth Avenue on Saturday New York will have an opportunity to inspect modernized military units which it hopes never to see at war. But this city, like the rest of the nation, finds reassurance in the fact that in a troubled world the American Army is ...

The Lehman Corporation liquidated a substantial portion of its holdings of common stock in the first quarter of 1939, increasing its cash holdings from 11 per cent of total assets at the year-end to 28.5 per cent on March 31, according to a report made public yesterday by Robert Lehman, president of the company.
MEXICO CITY, Thursday, April 6. --This city's newspaper row was stoned last night by a mob of antiFascist rioters.
The Bushwick and Williamsburg sections were well represented in the Brooklyn realty transactions reported yesterday, when a number of small apartment properties passed into new ownership.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--Three Federal Circuit Court judges, two of whom are more than 70, gave replies today to the question whether a man 97 years old transferred securities to his heirs in anticipation of death or for another reason.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly yesterday and ended with gains of 2 to 5 points. Selling in the early trading carried the May below 8 cents a pound for the first time since the middle of February, but the market improved later in sympathy with a recovery in the stock ...

American boys and girls today are apathetic, with a defeatist, hopeless feeling about their future, Dr. Caroline B. Zachry of the Progressive Education Association declared yesterday in making public the findings of a five-year study of adolescents.

An attempt to recover from the United States Treasury $7,000,000 in unemployment insurance taxes paid by New York employers in 1936 and 1937 but not recorded to the credit of the State job insurance fund because of differences in the coverage of the State and Federal laws is being made by the State Government, it became known yesterday.
ST. LAMBERT, Que., April 5 (Canadian Press).--Three major evils within Canada today are expanding public debt, unemployment ...

BOSTON, April 6.--Plans to curb their over-exhilarated followers, rather than the Toronto Maple Leafs, were foremost in the mind of Manager Art Ross today when he gave his Boston Bruins their final instructions for tomorrow's opening Stanley Cup hockey contest at the Boston Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--Affiliates of the C.I.O. through the Industrial Union Council discussed today a plan to aid Branch 1 of the American Federation of Hosiery workers in its legal battle to have the $711,932 damage award to the Apex Hosiery Company set aside.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.-- Elmer F. Andrews, Federal WageHour Administrator, warned here today that the "honeymoon" period of the law's administration was over and that business men who "monkey with the buzz saw" of enforcement would find the teeth "big and sharp."

With optimistic predictions for American business and industry and for the World's Fair as a stimulant to constructive enterprise, Henry Ford dedicated yesterday "The Road of Tomorrow," principal feature of his company's exhibit at the Fair.
Seeking to make New York more attractive for visitors to the World's fair opening on April 30, Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday calling April "Dress Up and Paint Up Month."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Thursday, April 6.--An anticlimactic chapter in Governor Sir Reginald J.T. Hildyard's attempt to persuade the Bermuda Assembly to allow him the use of an automobile was written this morning when it was announced through the Colonial Secretary's Office that Sir Reginald had been permitted to retire next Sept. 30, before his normal term of five years expires.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Independent motion-picture exhibitors began arguments today for the Neely Anti-Block Booking Bill before a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee and pictured themselves as almost helpless in the selection of films they run.
Modern adaptations of costumes from northern lands, including Iceland, Lapland, Norway and Sweden, were presented yesterday in a Spring fashion show at the John Wanamaker store auditorium.

WHAT started it was a chance remark about Walter (Pop-Eyed Woods, the welter weight who is due to fight Paul Mahoney at the Hippodrome tonight. It appears that Woods, a product of the Gas House district of this fair city, only recently returned from Australia.

PARIS, April 5.--As a penalty for releasing what is regarded here as an anti-French film--"Devil's Island"--a two months' ban on Warner Brothers' films in France was announced by the French Government today.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 5.--Running a wide, independent and stylish race, Farmwood Fleece today captured the first prize in the members' derby stake, the opening event of the thirty-eighth annual field trials of the English Setter Club of America. The meeting got under way this morning and will continue through Sunday.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5.--Judge William Clark of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals deferred today until April 17 decision on an application of Walter Kidde, trustee for the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad, for instructions regarding the payment of State taxes amounting to $1,101,173.
GENEVA, April 5.--The Albanian press bureau issued a statement today saying:

WASHINGTON, April 5.--A demand that the House receive an opportunity to amend the National Labor Relations Act was made today by Representative Cox, Democrat of Georgia, who intimated that if the House Labor Committee did not conduct hearings on the subject, a move would be made for a special Congressinonal investigation of the Labor Board.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5.-- Navy conquered the University of Vermont baseball team today, 11 to 7, scoring eight runs on a barrage of hits, mostly for extra bases, in the fourth inning. Madison, Navy hurler, was hit for three singles and a double in the first which netted the visitors two runs.

Formation of a "Buy New York Products" campaign, designed to focus attention on this city as a style center, was announced yesterday by the Dress Creators League of America, Inc. The league plans a series of informal conferences with local retail executives, to begin soon.

BERLIN, April 5.--The deeper meaning of the increased activities of Anglo-French diplomacy during the last week has not escaped the Berlin and Rome governments, and the week-end may witness a counter-demonstration by the axis powers, it was reported in neutral diplomatic circles here today.

PARIS, April 5.--Anxiety over the situation in Albania has become acute in Paris. It bears too much evidence, despite all denials of concerted action between the partners in the Rome-Berlin axis, to be dismissed as either local in importance or isolated in intent.

Two defendants in the restaurant racket case who were fugitives at the time of the trial two years ago appeared yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook. William Kramer, 40 years old, who was arrested in Brooklyn Tuesday night, pleaded guilty to extortion and conspiracy and was remanded to the Tombs without bail.

CHUNGKING, China, April 5.-- Ta Kung Pao, the leading Chungking newspaper, published today details of alleged negotiations between Wang Ching-wei, fugitive former Premier of China, and the Japanese Premier, Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma, looking toward the assumption by Mr. Wang of the leadership of a Chinese regime cooperating with Japan.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club, national amateur squash tennis champion since 1930, played his opening match in the world open tournament last night on the courts of the Shelton Hotel and passed the test with flying colors.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP).--The Investment Bankers Association of America expressed today opposition to legislation to give the Securities and Exchange Commission greater control over trust indentures on the ground that it would impede private financing.

Still undefeated after five rounds, Stephen P. Diliberto, Princeton, '42, continued in the lead yesterday in the annual tournament for the individual championship of the H.Y. P.D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club, where the final games will be contested this morning and afternoon.
A variety of properties, including tenements, private homes and loft buildings, figured in the Manhattan realty sales reported yesterday.

Asserting that his candidacy should not be interpreted as a fight against any person or group in the party, Walter S. Mack Jr. announced yesterday his willingness to run for president of the National Republican Club in opposition to John R. Davies, who has been president for the past two years and has been proposed for re-election by a majority of the club's nominating committee.

A new ten-point treatment, which includes the use of such vitaminrich fluids as orange juice and tomato juice, has proved highly valuable in combating delirium tremens at Bellevue Hospital, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Karl M. Bowman, director of the division of psychiatry at the hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP).--The Board of Tax Appeals denied today a claim by the Internal Revenue Bureau for $2,950,592 additional income taxes for 1930 from C.A. Munroe, financier, of Chicago and New York.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--The Senate Appropriations Committee voted unanimously today to give the Administration the $100,000,000 deficiency appropriation approved by the House to finance the Works Progress Administration funds for the rest of the year, ending June 30. The intent was to avoid possible bitter debate on the floor.

Transient families would be permitted to acquire legal settlement while getting relief in this State under a proposal submitted to the State Department of Social Welfare yesterday by the director of a special study of the State's program for aid to non-residents.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--The Securities and Exchange Commission instituted today a public investigation to determine whether the Union Electric Company of Missouri had violated either of the securities acts or the Holding Company Act, and if there is need for legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Advocates of realistic tax revision at this session of Congress read with greater interest than any others the President's denunciation at Warm Springs yesterday of "so-called riders" added to bills "which have no relation whatsoever to ...

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, arriving today from Southampton and Cherbourg, has among her prominent passengers the Ranee of Sarawak, George M. Cohan, actor and playwright; Percy S. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., with Mrs. Straus; Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Wanamaker ...
The bond market settled back into a narrow trading range yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with mild recovery movements developing among the domestic corporation issues.

BERLIN, April 5.--The totalitarian conscription of all boys and girls between 10 and 18 years old for service in the Hitler Youth, which gets exclusive charge of the "physical, mental and moral education of the entire German youth within the Reich territory outside of the home and school," was decreed today in ordinances signed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the National Socialist party.

Paul Mahoney, Buffalo middleweight, will make his local boxing debut tonight, meeting Walter Woods of New York in the feature ten-round bout at the Hippodrome. Mahoney will step into the ring with an impressive record, for he has received only five reversals in more than fifty professional bouts.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 5.-- All tables in the Orange Gardens were filled tonight by a large number of members and their guests attending the final dinner dance of the season at the Everglades Club.

Imported Swiss cheese and Gorgonzola cheese are made of cow's milk, not goat's milk, investigation showed yesterday. The erroneous statement was supplied by the city Health Department for an article on goat milk published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday.

The best traffic accident record in the last five years was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine in his annual report to Mayor La Guardia.

The Wright Aeronautical Corporation, controlled by the CurtissWright Corporation, and its wholly owned subsidiary yesterday disclosed in the annual report for 1938 a net profit of $3,288,772 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--A new fundamental time division, the 89-36year sunspot cycle, has been introduced by H. Helm Clayton in a report on mathematical analysis of solar activity issued by the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Clayton demonstrates that he can make ...

GREENWICH, Conn., April 5.-- Benjamin T. Fairchild who died in Greenwich March 25, left real estate exceeding $10,000 and personal property in excess of $10,000, according to the petition filed with the will which was admitted to probate by Judge Harold L. Knapp here today.

PRAGUE, April 5.--The temporary military government of the German army of occupation was replaced today by a civil regime with the arrival of Baron Constantin von Neurath, Protector for BohemiaMoravia. With Baron von Neurath came Lieut. Gen. Fridirici, who was sent to liquidate the Czech Army.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 5.-- Princeton's baseball team triumphed, 7-5, over Manhattan on University Field today for its first success in four starts this season. Although they collected eight hits to equal Princeton's total, the Jaspers, playing their first contest of the campaign, virtually handed victory to the Tigers with six errors afield.

A circus blessed by a chorus of angel-winged-trapeze artists, topped by a man in the moon and sprayed by twenty-four ultra-redolent scentdispensers--something entirely new in New York big show history-- opened the season in Madison Square Garden last night.

Josef Hofmann, pianist, will be soloist in the Chopin E minor concerto with the Philharmonic-Symphony Society under John Barbirolli at the World's Fair inaugural concert on April 30. The remainder of the program, announced yesterday by Mrs. William C. Breed ...

The Rev. Sebastian Schaff, pastor since 1936 of the Capuchin Church of Our Lady Queen of Angels, East 113th Street, near Second Avenue, died of a heart attack in the rectory, 226 East 113th Street, on Tuesday. He was 58 years old.

Although the channel bass are not as plentiful as they will be in two weeks in the surf, they seem to be taking plenty of them from boats in Oregon Inlet. It looks as though you had better get your duffle together and make your reservations, for it promises to be a banner year for North Carolina channel bass.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP).-- Representatives of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad criticized today as economically unsound a $13,000,000 Federal program to develop the Connecticut River between Hartford and Holyoke, Mass.

In the face of alarming news that Britain had taken the precaution to prepare against possible surprise air raids and that Italy was making threatening gestures toward Albania, the stock, market here settled down yesterday and prices made moderate recovery from their losses of the previous day.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 5.-- Judge Ernest A. Inglis today turned over to defense counsel in the Waterbury conspiracy trial testimony given by Charles E. Williamson, a Darien lawyer and former leader in State Republican circles, before the extraordinary grand jury which investigated the city's affairs last Spring.

BENARES, India, April 5 (AP).-- The Maharajah of Benares, Captain Sir Aditya Narayan Singh Bahadur, died today at the age of 64. He became Maharajah of the Benares district of the North-West Provinces in 1931 and was created a knight in 1933.

The subcommittees of the joint conference of bituminous coal miners and operators of the Appalachian region, appointed by the conference to bring in recommendations for a new collective agreement, met again all day yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore without results.

Under Tuesday's decision of the Court of Appeals the City Council can proceed, without the Mayor's approval, to find out whether or not the municipal broadcasting station WNYC is a mouthpiece of Moscow. Many of us think that it probably isn't, but there can be no harm, one way or the other, in looking into the matter.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--The National Steel Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $50,000,000 of first (collateral) mortgage bonds, due April 1, 1965, and $15,000,000 of serial notes, due April 1, 1940-49. Interest rates will be supplied by amendment.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--The United States has no public debt, Representative T. Alan Goldsborough declared today in a valedictory address to the House prior to taking the oath as Justice of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

PARIS, April 5.--The independence in French character, which refuses to goosestep in any given direction, even though it may secretly approve, dominated the reelection of Albert Lebrun as President of France by the National Assembly at Versailles today.

Plans for the new home of the Madison Square Boys Club in East Twenty-ninth Street, embodying many unusual features, were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings by Holden, McLaughlin Associates, architects. The cost of the structure was estimated at $350,000.
TIRANA, Albania, April 5 (AP).-- Albanian authorities said tonight that they had taken "suitable military precautions" to maintain the tiny kingdom's independence.

Pine Lawn Farm, the forty-acre property of Fred J. Dietz on Nut Swamp Road, Middletown Township, near Red Bank, N.J., has been sold to Charles Fredericks, New York attorney, through Charles E. Sweeney, broker.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 5 (AP).--A couple of athletes on opposite sides of the nation pointed today toward a season-long contest, with another new native record for the javelin throw and an American threat to perennial Finnish supremacy in that event already produced.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--An "all farm" group of Southern and Western Senators made preliminary plans today to push an enlarged program of aid to producers of important crops. Their proposals, if enacted by Congress, would call for additional expenditures of at least $400,000,000.

ALBANY, April 5.--President Justice James P. Hill of the Appellate Division, who was chairman of the Committee on Contingent Expenses of the recent Constitutional Convention, has refused to approve payment of a bill for $3,000 for the preparation of a book entitled. "A Pictorial History of the New York State Constitutional Convention."
Mrs. Matthew Hanna gave a cocktail party yesterday afternoon in her apartment at Hampshire House for Jefferson Caffrey, United States Ambassador to Brazil, and Mrs. Caffrey.

Expansion of Summer dress lines to include models at $7, $8 and $9 by manufacturers in the $10 to $12 bracket will be a feature of postEaster preparations in the wholesale markets, it was indicated here yesterday. RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 5.--A reinsurance bank with which all insurance companies operating in Brazil must place such excess coverage as they canont carry was created by President Getulio Vargas by decree today.

The East led the West, two victories to one, when the opening matches of the national indoor polo championships had been completed at the Squadron A Armory last night, but the most important triumph of the evening went to the West.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--A suggestion that temperature changes exerted a great influence on the sex of babies was made before the American Association of Physical Anthropologists today by Dr. William F. Petersen, Professor of Pathology at the University of Illinois.

Fordham University's hard-hitting undefeated baseball forces fattened their batting averages on their home field yesterday, pounding the offerings of four Brooklyn College pitchers for fourteen safeties as they triumphed by a 14-3 count.

The support of women of finance and of business executives in the Metropolitan Opera Guild's efforts to bring about wider interest in the Metropolitan Opera Association was stressed yesterday in an address by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation and head of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The annual statement of condition of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and its affiliated stores, to be issued to stockholders today by Percy S. Straus, president, discloses total sales of $125,223,909 for the fiftytwo-week period ended on Jan. 28, 1939, compared with $135,871,800 in the preceding fiscal year.
BOSTON, April 5.--General Francis Henry Appleton, former State Representative and Senator and member of a distinguished family, died today in his Back Bay home at the age of 91.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for the new home of the Madison Square Boys Club in Manhattan, an apartment for a site on Hull Avenue, the Bronx, and new apartments in Brooklyn.

Plans for the berthing of vessels of the United States Fleet that will visit New York for the opening of the World's Fair were announced yesterday by Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, Commandant of the Third Naval District, through the Mayor's Naval Committee.

Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., announced yesterday at a meeting ...

While the annual report of the Gatineau Power Company for 1938 has not been issued yet, consolidated net income for the year, after all expenses and charges, amounted to $1,949,602, compared with $1,641,767 in 1937, according to figures filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission and released here by the company.

Funeral services for Patrolman James J. Sweeney, who shot himself at his home, 664 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, last Sunday afternoon, were held yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, Brooklyn.

Grigori Benenson, international financier, former owner of the Benenson Building at 165 Broadway, died yesterday in a London nursing home of a stroke of apoplexy, according to word received here by his attorney, Abraham Tulin. He was 79 years old.

RICHMOND, Va., April 5.--An important advance in the fight against cancer was reported today by Dr. Shields Warren of the Pondville (Mass.) State Hospital for Cancer, to the American Association for Cancer Research, meeting here.

One of the largest Fifth Avenue store leases of the year has just been closed after six months' negotiations by Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., brokers. Receipt of $18,356,000 foreign gold that will go immediately into the monetary gold stock of the United States was reported by the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday. In addition, the bank reported that $2,400,000 of the metal had been engaged in London for shipment here.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Revision of the Neutrality Act should be approached as a problem of national defense rather than of foreign policy, Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, told the Foreign Relations Committee today as it opened hearings on the seven proposals pending before it.

Creation of a bureau of health education in the State's Department of Education was advocated yesterday by Dr. C.E.A. Winslow, Professor of Public Health at the Yale School of Medicine, in an address before the Public Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CLEVELAND, April 5 (AP).--Christ Whitaker of Alliance, Ohio, rolled into a fifth-place tie with Cone Hermann, St. Louis, in the singles division of the American Bowling Congress today with a 696 total. Whitaker rolled games of 243-207246.

Mayor Kelly's re-election was inevitable, as the Republican prophets to the contrary well knew. The KellyNash machine, severely controlled, was sure to deliver an enormous vote, some of it collected from curious sources. Some business men of high repute advertised the Mayor's virtues.

Nearly a score of speakers, among them American diplomats and business men interested in South American affairs and representatives of Latin-American countries, will participate in the second Foreign Political Congress under the sponsorship of the Graduate School of Fordham University on April 22, 23 and 24, according to a program made public yesterday.

DURHAM, N.C., April 5.--Despite the brilliant individual performance of Captain Hubert Reavis of Duke, Princeton's well-balanced track team turned back the Blue Devils today, 73-53. Reavis raced home first in the 220-yard dash and the 220-yard low hurdles and was a close second in the 100-yard dash ...

OTTAWA, April 5.--Farmers of Western Canada will benefit from an acreage assurance plan this year if legislation outlined in the House of Commons today by J.G. Gardiner, Agriculture Minister, becomes law. In future years the principles may be applied to all branches of agriculture in Canada.

A preview of Fall football was given at New York University's Ohio Field yesterday when Coach Mal Stevens's Violet squad played host to Coach Herb Kopf's Manhattan charges in a spirited scrimmage session that lasted for more than an hour.

BOWIE, Md., April 5.--In the Greenbury Purse, five-and-a-halffurlong dash for 3-year-old colts and geldings today, the Crescent Stable's Chalmac, recently a good second, defeated seven rivals with ease under capable handling by the veteran George Seabo. The brown son of Challenger II and Peggy. Mac, who campaigned in Florida the past Winter, clicked by three lengths.

Benny Goodman presented to a representative of Harvard University yesterday a collection of records and materials on swing that will be the basis of the HarvardGoodman Collection of Music. The collection will be placed in the Widener Library.

ALBANY, April 5.--Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, announced today that he would sell two issues of New York State bonds, one of $10,000,000 for State institutions buildings and the other of $10,000,000 for elimination of grade crossings, at his office here at noon on April 18.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., April 5.-- Mask and Wig, a 3-to-1 shot, sped to victory in the six-furlong dash for 3-year-olds at Tanforan today. The winner, timed in 1:12, finished in front of Colonel Bret and One Shen.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--The Texas Corporation filed today an amendment to its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $40,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures, due 1959, in which it listed the underwriters through whom the securities will be offered and the amounts to be underwritten by each.

CLEVELAND, April 5.--Candidates who were supported by the Communist faction won thirteen places out of nineteen on the general executive board of the United Automobile Workers group recognized by the C.I.O. in the elections which ended today the convention of the organization.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Thomas E. Dewey will be President of the United States and Senator R.A. Taft of Ohio Vice President after 1940, and John N. Garner and James A. Farley will be the defeated candidates, according to the general opinion of fifty Washington correspondents as expressed in a vote.

The famous Eton blue silks with brown cap, flown by the color-bearers of three generations of Whitneys, again will be seen in action upon the opening of the New York season April 15, with the horses scheduled to arrive at Belmont Park today.

A time-honored collegiate tradition at New York University's downtown center was considerably jarred when Commissioner Moses's Park Department installed forty benches on the east side of Washington Square Park, it was revealed yesterday.

Fifty-three athletic awards made at Brooklyn College to basketball and swimming athletes were announced yesterday by Lou Oshins, director of athletics. Twenty-one major letters, twelve minor letters and twenty sets of class numerals were given out.

President Roosevelt publicly thanked American industry last night for its cooperation with his national defense program by mobilizing its resources for prompt use by the army and navy in case of war, in a message delivered to 1,200 high-ranking army and navy officers, business and industrial leaders, and professional and technical experts from all over the country at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 5.-- Frank Strafaci, 22-year-old Brooklyn star, who won the event last year, was extended to win his firstround match in the thirty-ninth annual North and South invitation amateur golf championship over the No. 2 course of the Pinehurst Country Club today.

CHICAGO, April 5.--Trading in wheat futures today was fairly active. Most of the business was in spreading between the various deliveries. The May was bought by cash and milling interests against sales of the July and September tending to widen the difference.

Convention time is near at hand for many leading realty and building associations. Preliminary programs which have been outlined for most of these meetings indicate that State and national legislation and the influence of governmental policies on their industry will occupy a leading place in the discussions of the realty groups.

We print elsewhere on this page a letter from Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, taking issue with a recent editorial on the Government's cotton program. Several points which he raises deserve further attention.

LONDON, April 5.--The conclusion of a defensive alliance between Britain and Poland is expected to be announced in the House of Commons by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain tomorrow, exactly a week after the historic pledge that Britain would resist aggression in Eastern Europe.

LONDON, April 5.--Sydney Wooderson, Britain's holder of the world mile and half-mile records, was granted permission today to compete in Princeton University's invitation track meet, June 17, after a controversy with the British Amateur Athletic Board.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 5. --It was officially announced today that Foreign Minister Grigore Gafencu would go to Berlin April 16 on Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop's invitation. Following his visit to that capital M. Gafencu will go to Brussels, London and Paris and on his return he will halt either at Milan or Rome to see Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Thomas E. Dewey will be President of the United States and Senator R.A. Taft of Ohio Vice President after 1940, and John N. Garner and James A. Farley will be the defeated candidates, according to the general opinion of fifty Washington correspondents as expressed in a vote.

The famous Eton blue silks with brown cap, flown by the color-bearers of three generations of Whitneys, again will be seen in action upon the opening of the New York season April 15, with the horses scheduled to arrive at Belmont Park today.

Walter Woods, East Side middleweight, had little trouble in disposing of Paul Mahoney, Buffalo boxer, in the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the New York Hippodrome last night. Woods stopped the up-State representative in 2 minutes 41 seconds of the third round, when Referee Arthur Donovan intervened to halt the one-sided battle.

Skulduggery among the ledgers and journals of Prendergast-Davies, Ltd., liquor distributors, when mysterious John Torrio anonymously guided the company's destinies, was disclosed in Federal court yesterday through Sam Borden, an uneasy government witness in the trial of Torrio and four others for income-tax evasion.

In a letter published on this page today Mr. J.B. Milgram calls attention anew to the problem of our city pension systems. Among the numerous provisions in Amendment No. 1 to the State Constitution, adopted last Fall, is one which will make membership in a pension or retirement system a contractual obligation of government after July 1, 1940.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--More command and staff shifts in the fleet were announced by the Navy Department today. The changes included the command of the Fleet Submarine Force, the Panama Canal Naval Station and the mine craft units of the Battle Force.
In weather that the British officials present described as "typically English"--that is, slightly more than damp, the Merrie England Village at the World's Fair was dedicated yesterday.

Two bills designed to reduce taxes payable on property improvements will be the subject of a public hearing before the City Council's Finance Committee in the Council Chamber at City Hall, April 20, at 2 o'clock, it was announced yesterday.

A youthful exiled Basque, a Cambridge graduate, who arrived here last August during the Spanish civil war, disclosed yesterday that he was the agent of the "Basque government of Jose Antonio de Aguirre" in the United States and that, regardless of Generalissimo Franco's victory, his compatriots regarded the Aguirre government as "the only and lawfully constituted Basque government."

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 6.--A nine-point program giving the anthracite operators' opinions on rehabilitating the hard-coal industry is included in a bill turned over today to Claude T. Reno, Attorney General. It is slated for introduction in the Legislature Monday.

An action to set aside the will of Mrs. E. Eurana Schwab, wife of Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, was begun yesterday by Mrs. Eurana De Bobula, a niece, of 611 Kappock Street, the Bronx, on grounds of "fraud and undue influence" practiced by Mr. Schwab and another niece, Mrs. Mary Mock Walter of 1,505 Prospect Avenue, Bethlehem, Pa.
Tom Iannicelli, defending titleholder in the world open squash tennis championship, reached the semi-final round of the tournament last night on the Shelton Hotel courts.

George F. Johnson, 81-year-old industrialist and philanthropist who has shared millions of his profits with his employes, and who once said that "any man who dies rich dies disgraced," received yesterday one of his highest honors--a gold medal for his business statesmanship in creating better relations between worker and employer.

The annual Good Friday matinee performance of Wagner's "Parsifal" will be given this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Kirsten Flagstad, Laurita Melchior, Friedrich Schorr and Emanuel List will head the cast.

A group of 300 skiers departed last night from the Grand Central Terminal on the New Haven's snow train for what promises to be a pleasant Easter week-end of running in the Eastern Slope area of New Hampshire. WASHINGTON, April 6.--Members of a House subcommittee set up to investigate the WPA said today that Department of Justice agents would be used in the inquiry "if needed."
Several properties close to the Brooklyn waterfront in the Brooklyn Heights, and Bay Ridge sections of the borough were taken by new owners in deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Brian Reuter, vice president of the Pittsburgh Union Trust Company, testified today before a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee that in his opinion the proposed regulation of trust indentures would erect "another bar" to business recovery.
Minneapolis, Minn., will be in the market on April 20 with $3,299,000 of various purpose bonds, city officials disclosed yesterday in announcing details and revision in the original notice of sale.

The ever-changing schedule of premieres for the two weeks after Easter now resolves itself, temporarily at least, as follows: Monday, "The Flashing Stream," at the Biltmore, and Thursday, "My Heart's in the Highlands," which thereafter plays next Friday and Saturday and the following Monday and Tuesday, at the Guild.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--The day after William O. Douglas was confirmed by the Senate to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States the fact was published by Newsweek that he ran fourth in a guessing contest among fifty Washington newspaper correspondents on the identity of the next Presidential nominee of the Democratic party.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, warned members of his organization last night against Communist attempts to obtain control of locals through the so-called "united front."

The American public does not complacently accept the idea that people are bound to be killed in automobile accidents and is willing to submit to drastic measures if traffic accidents could thereby be reduced, according to national surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

JUST the other day a horse by the name of Holluschickie won at Tropical Park and paid $37.10. Reading about it at a distance, what caught these eyes was not the $37.10 in particular, though such fancy figures always make interesting reading, but the name of the horse.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--President Roosevelt, in a letter to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., made public by the State Department today, specifically placed Bohemia, Moravia and Slovakia on the tariff blacklist with Germany.
Alfred L. Bennet, who served in the Union Navy in Civil War engagements, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home, 113 Broadway, Howard Beach, Queens. Mr. Bennet was 93 years old.

CHICAGO, April 6.--Hearing on an Illinois "fair price" bill has been set for April 19 before a legislative committee at Springfield, S.M. Libit, counsel for the Associated Groceries Industries Council, announced today.

CAT CAY, British West Indies, April 6.--Mrs. David Manson Weir of Steubenville, Ohio, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances Weir, to Allan Shelden 3d, son of Mrs. Allan Shelden and the late Mr. Shelden of Detroit.

As a result of increased educational activities in recent years, rapid strides have been made toward the conservation of eyesight, particularly among children, according to the annual report of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, Inc., which is made public today.
MOSCOW, April 6.--It seems appropriate at the moment to define the Soviet attitude to the world in general and Europe in particular, meaning mostly Poland and Britain, without forgetting Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--In the first of a series of reports on labor policies of employers' associations, the Senate Civil Liberties Committee asserted today that the National Metal Trades Association, which in 1937 had a membership representing 952 manufacturing plants, functioned as an anti-union and strikebreaking agency creating "a danger to orderly government."

WASHINGTON, April 6.--In the eighth of a series of reports on American-listed corporations being compiled for it as a WPA project, the Securities and Exchange Commission described today the financial status of fourteen American cane and beet sugar refiners.

CHICAGO, April 6.--Holiday dullness prevailed today in the wheat market. Prices held within narrow limits, but there was no material pressure, and short covering to even up for the Easter holidays resulted in moderate advances in prices. Net gains on the Board of Trade ...

MEXICO CITY, April 6.--David Alfaro Siqueros, noted mural painter, who was a colonel in the Spanish Republican Army, was under arrest today as the ringleader of a union mob that stoned the plants of the Novedades, Excelsior and Universal, three of this capital's leading newspapers, in an anti-fascist demonstration last night.

With the exception of one important game, the seven rounds of the annual tournament for the H.Y. P.D. College Chese League championship were completed at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Stephen P. Diliberto, Princeton, '42, remained at the head of the list of seven competitors, but no definite decision was reached with reference to the title.

LONDON, April 6.--The British Government today promised Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, that it would not overlook Poland's desire for emigration and colonization facilities for some 3,500,000 Polish Jews.

LONDON, April 6.--The British Government today made a preliminary move toward offering a military guarantee to Hungary, it became known tonight as Foreign Minister Josef Beck of Poland concluded his conversations in London.

Leasing of space in Rockefeller Center and along Fifth Avenue was active yesterday.

Miss Emmy Jo Schweizer, daughter of Mrs. David Dows of New York, has completed plans for her marriage to Charles Clinton Burke, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burke of Plainfield, N.J., which will take place April 28 in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The ceremony will be performed by the pastor, the Rev. George A. Buttrick.

Safety on the highway will be emphasized by General Motors Corporation at the New York World's Fair. Establishment of a traffic and safety information center at the company's Highways and Horizons exhibit, in collaboration with organizations interested in the promotion of highway safety, was disclosed yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due to sail today for Southampton via Cherbourg. Her passenger list includes the Duke of Montrose, the Earl of Dalhousie and his sister, Lady Jean Ramsay; James Roosevelt, son of President Franklin D. Roosevelt; Lea Velloso, Brazilian Ambassador to the ...

HAVANA, April 6.--The Senate modified the electoral code early this morning after a lengthy session so as to conform to the wishes that President Federico Laredo Bru expressed in his veto message when he returned the bill to Congress on March 31.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System have set a new high record at $3,710,000,000, according to the system's report for the week ended on Wednesday. The week's gain was $190,000,000, raising the total $110,000,000 above the previous record, made at the end of January.

Maj. Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York National Guard, emphasized the need of bringing the National Guard of the nation up to 95 per cent efficiency as part of "our initial protective force" in addressing members of the Rotary Club at luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

Warrants entitling holders of common shares of the Eastman Kodak Company to purchase one new share at $127.50 a share for each ten held, or 225,092 additional shares, were mailed yesterday to stockholders and the distribution will be completed today, the company announced.

John Barbirolli, for his New York Philharmonic-Symphony audiences of last night and Wednesday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, elected to revive a score, known to few and forgotten by the many, of Gioacchino Rossini: the "Petite Messe Solennelle" of that master, composed in his seventy-second year, a little more than five years before his death, thirty-one years after his...
SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, April 7.--Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons died this morning after a two-day illness.

FLORENCE, S.C., April 6 (AP).-- The Red Sox and Reds struggled through eight innings of a ball game today in a forty-mile breeze that rolled great clouds of dust over a newly laid-out diamond. Then they had to quit, with the score 18 to 18 (verified by expert statisticians).

With both foreign and domestic developments having an unsettling effect on sentiment, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued easier yesterday. The May sold at its lowest figures of the year and the list lost 2 to 6 points. Resumption of heavy foreign selling at the opening...

LONDON, April 6 (AP).--King George and Queen Elizabeth and the royal court have moved to Windsor Castle for the Easter holidays but will enjoy less leisure and relaxation than the average Briton. They took to the historic Berkshire retreat a number of books and maps of the United States and Canada.
Army posts all over the natton held "open house" to the public yester day--Army Day--the twenty-second anniversary of the entry of the United States into the World War.

BOWIE, Md., April 6.--A featureless program once again was offered patrons here today and the card, made up entirely of events for platers, was run off under most adverse conditions. A steady rain and black clouds made visibility poor.

The Appellate Division ordered yesterday the replacement of thirtyfive persons holding positions as supervisor, grade 3, in the Department of Public Welfare at salaries ranging from $2,400 to $3,000 a year under provisional appointments with regular employes from the civil service list for assistant chief investigator.

The Rev. Dr. A.D. Belden, a leading Congregational Minister in England, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary as the official delegate of the National Peace Council of Great Britain, bearing a petition with 1,062,000 names, urging American support of a world-wide peace move.

An emergency campaign for funds to aid overseas refugees was launched by the Women's Division of the New York United Jewish Appeal for Refugees and Overseas Needs at a meeting yesterday morning at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Selection of the Fresh Meadow Country Club course as the site for the annual Goodall Trophy tournament this year was announced yesterday by the committee in charge of the event. With the fifteen outstanding professional golfers of the Winter and Spring campaigns slated to participate, the tourney will be held on the Flushing links from June 1 through June 4.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Marching in a rain which at times was a downpour, army units stationed in or near Washington displayed some of their modern equipment today to thousands of people lining Constitution Avenue.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., April 6.--The only effective means for checking the Yankees that has yet come to light was still holding Marse Joe McCarthy's world champions in a tight grip today. Wintry blasts and flurries of snow that had the athletes burying their sun-tanned noses deep in their upturned coat collars greeted their arrival here and, of course, wiped out the scheduled exhibition game with the Oklahoma City Indians.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 6.--Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, arrived by air for a short visit to Cairo this morning, coming from Rhodes. He was accompanied by a suite of seven persons.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York adopted a resolution at its monthly meeting yesterday calling for "substantial reductions" in the present city budget as well as in future budgets.

Standing on girders far above the Forty-ninth Street sidewalk crowds, steel workers yesterday "topped out" the framework of the thirteenth unit in Rockefeller Center-- the fifteen-story combination office building and parking garage in the south block of the midtown commercial and amusement center.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Through an exchange of notes today the United States and Great Britain agreed on a system of joint control and administration of Canton and Enderbury Islands of the Phoenix group in the Central Pacific. Sovereignty has been claimed over the islands by both governments.
PARIS, April 6.--The Spanish Government tonight assured France there had been no recent landing of Italian troops at Cadiz, Spain.

A union shop agreement covering 700 employes of the Hotel St. Regis, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, was signed yesterday by representatives of the hotel and the New York Hotel Trades Council, composed of live American Federation of Labor unions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6.-- Contracts for the filming of Sinclair Lewis's "Angela Is Twentytwo" were signed today by the author and Lester Cowan, independent producer who recently completed "You Can't Cheat an Honest Man." A releasing arrangement is being discussed both with Universal and RKO.
Mrs. Yetta Weisbrod, who will celebrate her 104th birthday anniversary today, has a simple formula for longevity.

Addressing a forum of the Women's City Club of New York at 20 West Fifty-first Street, Mayor La Guardia defended yesterday his executive budget for 1939-40 as the best "humanly possible" under existing circumstances and the product of 365 days of work a year on his part.
