Development of a new, colored stainless steel, reported to be lighter and stronger than any other metal now in use, and which, it was said, may revolutionize industry, from the making of pen points to the building of houses and battleships, was announced yesterday by Oscar B. Bach, well known metallurgist, industrial designer and sculptor.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--The general level of wholesale prices continued to decline gradually in the week ended on April 1, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, dropped to 76.5 ...
Good Friday, the most solemn day in the Christian calendar, commemmorating the crucifixion, will be observed today in a series of services in virtually every church in the city.

The National Maritime Union yesterday withdrew its support of the government's merchant marine training schools and decided to support the Maritime Federation of the Pacific in its fight against the Maritime Commission's proposed hiring halls on the West Coast.

Production of steel in March was the best, with one exception, for any month since October, 1937, according to a report by the American Iron and Steel Institute showing March output of open-hearth and bessemer steel ingot of 3,364,877 gross tons.

Most of the foods that go into a lavish Easter dinner are characterized as cheap by the Consumers' Division of the Department of Markets. As usual, there are plenty of good things for everybody. Heavy demand for favorite Easter meats, ham and poultry brings lower prices for the week-end because supplies are large. In addition, eggs, butter and milk are low ...

The need for a Congressional definition of standards necessary to wilderness national parks and the control of commercial and semicommercial activies within them was voiced yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by Dr. Carl P. Pussell of the National Parks Division of the Department of the Interior.

Democracy no longer can be taken for granted, but must be constantly stressed in the classroom, teachers were advised yesterday by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens representative of the Board of Education. She warned against letting intolerance creep into the schools and urged the teachers to practice democratic principles in their daily lives.
The New York Conservation Department will study the productivity of two additional trout streams during the present season, according to an announcement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Increase in the license period for radio stations to a year, from the present six months, was set out as a final recommendation today by the Federal Communications Commission's committee on broadcasting rules. It suggested the longer period in an earlier report in January.

Dr. William Hallock Park, former director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the Health Department and an outstanding specialist in the field of antitoxins, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home, 1,225 Park Avenue. He was 76 years old.

ALBANY, April 6.--Motor vehicle accidents caused by intoxicated drivers are three times more likely to prove fatal than accidents in which sober drivers are concerned, according to a report made public today by Commissioner Carroll E. Mealey.
A large taxpayer property and two blockfront apartment sites in Queens figured in the Long Island realty transactions announced yesterday.

Rayon yarn producers here expressed no concern yesterday over a report from Mexico City that Italy and Mexico were planning a deal by which Mexico would import 8,840,000 pounds of rayon yarn in exchange for oil from expropriated oil wells.
BATON ROUGE, La., April 6.-- "Yes, sir. I'm afraid everything's going to be all right with Zeke."

LONDON, April 6.--Business in the stock markets here shrank today to negligible proportions on the eve of the long holiday week-end. Continued international uncertainty and unfavorable New York reports imparted a dull tone.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Whether sinking funds as a means to reduce railroad debt will prove to be entirely effective is questioned by W.H.S. Stevens, assistant director of statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission, in a report issued today. Since 1933 the commission generally has enforced the provision of sinking funds for new railroad bond issues.

Beginning at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, New Yorkers may dial a number and hear the latest weather forecast spoken over the wire by a special voice-recording and reproducing machine of the New York Telephone Company. The number that will bring information as to whether it will be clear or cloudy, rainy, warmer or cooler, is WEather 6-1212.

More than 450 clergymen and laymen of Protestant churches throughout the United States, including forty-one Protestant Episcopal and Methodist Episcopal Bishops, joined in a Good Friday petition to Pope Pius XII yesterday, urging him to use his influence to stop "un-Christian" reprisals threatened by Generalissimo....

BERLIN, April 6.--Early reaction in German quarters to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's House of Commons statement on the outcome of the Anglo-Polish talks affects to show complete indifference to any commitments that Foreign Minister Josef Beck of Poland may have entered into with the British statesman.

Taking complete exception to the Federal Trade Commission's order against it, the Fashion Originators Guild of America filed here yesterday a petition "to review and set aside" the FTC order in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 6. --The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad announced today it would add twenty-eight trains a day to its. Westchester-New York schedule beginning May 1, operating fourteen additional trains in each direction and providing service every half hour or more often for residents of the Long Island Sound side of Westechester County.

The growing urbanization of this country is responsible for a rapid decline in the birth rate which may lead to a major turning point in American history, Dr. Frederick Osborn, research associate in anthropology of the American Museum of Natural History, declared last night in the annual Hermann M. Biggs Memorial lecture at the Academy of Medicine.

The increasingly angry tone of political developments in Europe, coupled with widespread discouragement over the domestic business outlook, brought on yesterday a severe decline in security prices on the Stock Exchange here.

LONDON, April 6.--Use of the Admiralty's "D" notice, asking newspapers to refrain from printing the speech of Earl Stanhope, First Lord of the Admiralty, delivered on Tuesday night, was "a mistake," Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 6.-- Casa del Pastor was the setting tonight for a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. in honor of Mr. and Mrs. James Wright Stewart.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Plans for the speedy passage by the Senate today of the House bill adding $100,000,000 to the WPA appropriation for the current fiscal year collapsed in the face of a fight waged by a handful of New Dealers, led by Senators Pepper and Mead.

Dr. William C. Thro, clinical pathologist and retired professor at the Cornell University Medical College, died yesterday at his home, 33-09 Twenty-eighth Avenue, Long Island City, after a two-year illness of a heart ailment. He was 64 years old.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 6.-- A.L. Aste's Miss Happy triumphed by three lengths at Tropical Park today in the Ponce de Leon Purse. The race, for 3-year-olds, was at five and a half furlongs.

Three of the fastest horses ever to step on a metropolitan race track --Airflame, Fighting Fox and The Chief--appeared yesterday to be sure starters in the historic Paumonok Handicap, traditional opening-day feature for the local racing season. Frank J. Reilly, aide to President Edward P. Kilroe at ...

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 6.-- While marching men and roaring cannon lent color to Army Day celebrations throughout the country, President Roosevelt today observed quietly the twenty-second anniversary of the nation's entry into the World War with a review of the detail of marines assigned to guard the "Little White House" during his stay here.
CHUNGKING, China, April 6.-- Reports indicate that the Japanese are making effective use of the recently captured Nanchang airdrome which, before the war, was one of the main Chinese air bases.

The invitation was accepted promptly by Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and ...

BOSTON, April 6.--Little Bobby Bauer squirmed through a sixtyfoot spread of Toronto Maple Leafs to give the Bruins a 2-1 victory in the opening game of the final Stanley Cup hockey play-offs tonight before an unusually orderly crowd of 16,523 at the Boston Garden.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 6.-- Exponents of the progressive and essentialist theories in education clashed tonight in a debate at the University of North Carolina's Human Relations Institute.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 6.-- By dint of fine sailing, the Bermudian team turned seeming defeat into victory today in the first race of the series against Long Island Sound crews in International Class sloops. The score was 21 points to 16.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation and subsidiaries had a profit of $7,737,712 in 1938 according to the report released for publication today by H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee. The profit was after interest, depreciation, depletion canceled leases and abandonments and taxes but excluded ...

SEBRING, Fla., April 6 (AP).--The two-time champion Newark Bears haven't been out of first place in the International League standings since about May 1, 1937, and there is no indication they will be evicted this season, in spite of a mediocre record in training camp clashes.

Miss Beatrix Hoyt of the Beekman gave a luncheon there yesterday for Mrs. John William Hulme Jr., who returned recently from her wedding trip in Nassau. Mrs. Hulme is the former Miss Joan Selden. Other guests were the Misses Anne Whitmarsh, Jane Tanner, Mary E. Plant, Nancy Parks, Harvey Brown and Margaret Harris.

"Dodge City," a drama of pioneer days in the West, produced by the Warners in Technicolor, will open an engagement this morning at the Strand. Players include Errol Flynn, Olivia de Havilland, Bruce Cabot, Ann Sheridan, Alan Hale, Victor Jory and Frank McHugh.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Japan has accumulated substantial stocks of war supplies in recent years through imports from the United States into Manchukuo, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today. The imports include petroleum, automobiles and other machinery, manufactured iron and steel, ...

Assemblyman Robert F. Wagner Jr., will offer in the Legislature on Monday a bill calling for the creation of a New York Securities Commission, modeled after the Federal body and having broad powers to regulate all those engaged in selling securities to the public within the State.

BALTIMORE, April 6.--A new process which, it is hoped will make possible the production of a new type of commercial synthetic rubber and a host of other derivatives that may be of value as drugs, dyes, plastics and countless other products beneficial to man, was reported here today before the closing sessions of the annual Spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.

TO kill one soldier in the Napoleonic wars, some pundits hold, cost about $7,000. At the time of the World War the expense had perhaps doubled--which seems believable enough when you consider the general rise in the price level in the course of that progressive century.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 6 (AP). --Joe Chamaco, who clinched the national three-cushion billiard championship this week, pushed Johnny Layton, eleven times United States titleholder, farther down in the season's list by winning from the veteran, 50 to 35 and 50 to 36, today.

MACON, Ga., April 6 (AP).--A reduction in freight rates on peaches, estimated to save growers $250,000 annually, has been proposed voluntarily by railroads in the South and East.

The suddenly manufactured crisis in the Adriatic, involving Italy and Albania, is plainly part of a much larger European picture. For all practical purposes Albania has been in Italy's pocket for a dozen years, ever since the treaty of Tirana. Italian support has helped to keep the present Government of Albania in power. Italian loans have built Albania's public works.

PITTSBURGH, April 6.--Despite a less-than-seasonal gain in new automobile sales and a fairly large drop in bituminous coal production, business in the Pittsburgh district rose to a new high for 1939 last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University ...

Police Commissioner Valentine and his men are to be congratulated on the results of their traffic safety campaign, as disclosed in the Commissioner's annual report. Considering the complexity of the problem, a decrease of fiftythree fatalities for 1938 on the streets of New York--to the lowest number of the past five years--is a fine accomplishment. So, too, is a decrease of 2,240 in the total number of accidents.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 6.-- Three metropolitan New York players and one Southerner won their second and third-round matches in the thirty-ninth annual North and South invitation amateur golf championship over the No. 2 course of the Pinehurst Country Club today.

To keep pace with the rapid growth of the New York City vocational schools, forty new positions as first assistants in shop subjects have been created by the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Sidney R. Kent, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, told a subcommittee of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today that the Neely anti-block booking bill was the conception of only 20 or 25 per cent of the country's exhibitors and would definitely increase the cost of motion pictures to both exhibitors and the public.

The story of how a modest English vicar first conceived and then pushed through his plan for honoring the Unknown Soldier with shrines in the most hallowed retreats of the allied nations was told yesterday for the first time publicly by the originator of the idea in a short-wave radio broadcast from Manchester, England.

Automobile manufacturipg companies in a number of different price ranges made public March figures yesterday showing substantial gains over March, 1938, and in some cases reaching the best totals since early 1937.

SUMTER, S.C., April 7.--An announcement just before the Tigers and Dodgers met today informed the 2,500 local fans that "for the first time in the history of Municipal Field two major league teams will play."
ALBANY, April 7 (AP).--Governor Lehman, wielding the executive pen frequently in the recess of the Legislature, has approved 227 of 386 bills which lawmakers sent him.

TSINAN, China, April 7 (AP).-- While Japanese troops and Chinese guerrillas battle almost every day and night for supremacy throughout Shantung Province, Japanese strategists are hoping partially to solve the problem of pacification by shipping an estimated 3,000 Shantung coolies and peasants to Manchukuo daily.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt devoted most of yesterday to selecting a wardrobe that will carry her not only through the Easter holidays but also through the state and informal functions of the visit of the King and Queen of Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 7.-- Money in circulation on March 31 was $6,817,211,309, or $52.07 per capita, compared with $6,731,243,857, or $51.44 per capita, on Feb. 28, the Treasury reported today. The total for March 31 compared with $6,355,457,188, or $48.88 per capita, according to revised figures, for March 31, 1938.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7.--Republican leaders of Philadelphia have decided to press for defeat of a series of bills, now before the Legislature, giving this city a new charter. The principal provisions are election of a council by proportional representation and the appointment of a city manager.

Upholding the Board of Education's right to establish physical standards, the Appellate Division yesterday overruled the Supreme Court in the case of a high school substitute to whom a regular teaching license was denied because of a cardiac condition.

IT looks like a plot. For the first time in some years Mr. Clark Calvin Griffith, owner and president of the Washington Senators, didn't forward a club roster to his old admirer in this corner. It was thought at first, with some understanding of Griff's saving graces, that the general economic condition might account for the nonappearance of a Senatorial roster.
BOSTON, April 7 (AP).--An exchange of sneers was the only aftermath of the Stanley Cup hockey opening registered today by the idling Boston Bruins and Toronto Maple Leafs.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Supply contracts valued at $6,963,814 were awarded during the week ended April 1 by fifteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Five clergymen will take part in the Easter Dawn service at 7 A.M. tomorrow on the Mall in Central Park, to which the entrance is through Seventy-second Street. The Elkan Naumburg Memorial Shell will be the platform for the leaders, and seats for 10,000 worshipers will

CANBERRA, Australia, April 7.-- Lord Gowrie, the Governor General, this afternoon swore in Sir Earle C.G. Page as Prime Minister to succeed Joseph A. Lyons, who died today. Six other Ministers retain the portfolios they held under Mr. Lyons.

Easter will be celebrated tomorrow by the churches from early morning until late at night. In anticipation of the great crowds that always attend the 11 o'clock festival services parishioners have been asked to come early. Indoor polo's national championships continue with three more East-West matches at Squadron A Armory tonight. Victory in any one of these games for the winners of last Wednesday night will end that division of play and crown a 1939 titleholder.

The tolling of the great bell in the tower of Trinity Church at the head of Wall Street thirty-three times to commemorate the age of Christ at His death brought to a close at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Lenten services in the historic structure.
WASHINGTON, April 7.--Faik Konitza, the Albanian Minister, formally protested to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today against the invasion of his country by Italy.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 7.-- Good hurling gave Princeton a 7-1 victory over Penn State in the Nittany Lions' opener today, Fred Rowe, junior right-hander, limiting the opposing batsmen to five hits and two walks and striking out ten. The Tigers' postponed game with Brown, rescheduled for this morning, was canceled because of wet grounds.

RICHMOND, Va., April 7.--Eight horses have been named for the renewal of the Deep Run Hunt Cup race, feature of the Deep Run Hunts meeting tomorrow. It is probable that five of these will go to the post in the three-mile test over timber. At the weights, it should provide a good contest.

The advance sale of tickets for the World's Fair yesterday passed the $2,000,000 mark, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair, announced. This he said, was well beyond expectations and put the sales well beyond the schedule set for a hoped-for advance purchase of $3,000,000 worth.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Negotiations between American companies and President Lazaro Cardenas over the expropriation of oil properties in Mexico "have not reached the stage where any question of success or failure arises," Donald R. Richberg said in a statement today.

LONDON, April 7 (Canadian Press).--Leaders came through successfully in Good Friday soccer games played in England and Wales today before big holiday crowds. Everton, leading in the drive for the championship, won, 2--1, at Sunderland.

LONDON, April 7.--When at 1 o'clock this afternoon the British Broadcasting Corporation's orchestra performance was interrupted for an emergency news bulletin announcing Italian occupation of Albania, British listeners learned the real reason for those recent naval and military concentrations at Bari and Brindisi, Italy.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia sails today for Mediterranean ports. Ross, Mrs. W.B. Atwater, Miss A.J.G. Perkins, Mrs. Edward Everet Hale.
CHICAGO, April 7.--Sales in the retail division of Marshall Field Co. are running ahead of those in the 1938 period, Frederick D. Corley, president, said today at the annual stockholders' meeting.

WARSAW, Poland, April 7 (AP).-- The Hungarian Government was said to have assured Poland that Hungary would join her in resisting Nazi influence and expansion if her military forces could be strengthened.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 7.-- T.H. Cross's Charmed One made it five victories in six starts this year today, when he captured the National Association of Insurance Agents $1,000 allowance race at Tropical Park. This feature event for 4-year-olds and up, was run at five and one-half furlongs.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 7 (AP). --Governor William H. Vanderbilt today wired President Roosevelt that State Unemployment Compensation Boards throughout the country would have to cease functioning April 30 for the rest of the fiscal year unless funds were provided by the Federal Social Security Board or appropriated by State governments.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 7.--An honor student at St. Joseph's College, Philadelphia, and his two young cousins both girls, were killed today when a Pennsylvania-- Reading Seashore Line train struck their automobile in which they were returning to their homes from a Good Friday mass at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, Pennsauken Township.
WASHINGTON, April 7.--The biggest corporation salary paid in 1937, Congress learned today, was the $1,161,753 which Louis B. Mayer, the movie producer, drew as production executive of Loew's, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP).--A declaration that American warplanes were "second best" to Germany's failed, it was disclosed today, to persuade the Senate Appropriations Committee to approve all the money sought by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who has defnite ideas about what he does and doesn't like, does not like the big electric signs he heard were to be put up on the State-erected Marine Ampitheatre at the World's Fair to advertise Billy Rose's Aquacade and has written a letter to Grower A. Whalen, Fair president, to that effect.

New bond issues offered formally for public subscription this week amounted to only $5,791,000 and consisted of three tax-exempt loans. Of the total, $5,000,000 was represented by a short-term note issue of Boston, Mass., which was offered on a 0.375 per cent interest basis.

Proceeds from the supper dance at the opening of the St. Regis Root for the season on May 2 will be devoted to the Musicians Emergency Fund. The Women's Auxiliary Board of the fund, which is taking part in the arrangements for the event, is under the chairmanship of Mrs. Vincent Astor.

A suit to enjoin the publication by Universal Syndicate of a salary directory was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Rembert R. Wurlitzer, a vice president of R. Wurlitzer Company. The complaint says the plaintiff is listed in the directory and in an advertisement announcing its publication as receiving a salary of $60,000 a year.

One of the highest peaks in the Western Hemisphere, rising 19,000 feet, snow-capped within sight of a warm sea and coastal jungle country, in a land where roaming wild horses and cows are reminders of the Spanish conquistadors of four centuries ago, was scaled in March for the first time by an American expedition.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed at 1 P.M. yesterday for Southampton via Cherbourg with 775 passengers, of whom 26 were in the cabin class, an unusually large number for this season, officials of the company said. There were no cancelations.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., April 7.-- With a frosty northwest wind whipping in their faces, two young Chicago professionals, Dick Metz and John Bulla, cracked par by two strokes today to tie for the firstfound leadership in the $5,000 Land of the Sky open tournament, which winds up golf's Winter campaigning.

KANSAS CITY, April 7--Thomas J. Pendergast, the "big boss" of the Kansas City Democratic machine and a power in State and national politics, was indicted this morning by a Federal Grand Jury on income tax charges.

Norvin R. Lindheim of 1 Sheridan Square, associate architect of the Jewish Palestine Pavilion at the World's Fair, died yesterday at Murray Hill Hospital after a week's illness. He was 30 years old.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 7.-- Amid the new crisis in Europe President Roosevelt today joined many Americans in quiet observance of Good Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Majority and minority leaders in the Senate cooperated tonight in forcing a session tomorrow on the "Pepper bloc" of advocates of a $150,000,000 additional appropriation for the WPA in opposition to the $100,000,000 agreed upon as a compromise by the leadership. The step was taken after the opposition group declined to permit a vote today.

The Puget Sound Power and Light Company and subsidiary companies will report today for 1938 consolidated net income of $1,527,723, after taxes and appropriations for retirement reserve. The net compared with $1,771,607 in 1937. Operating revenues last year were $15,793,069, a decrease of $924,965, or 5.5 per cent, from 1937.

Forkner of Teachers College declared yesterday at the forty-second annual convention of the Eastern Commercial Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Hecla Mining Company had profits of $718,715 for 1938 after deducting all charges except taxes and depletion, compared with $1,700,054 in 1937, according to the annual report of the company, made public yesterday by James F. McCarthy, president.

Geoghan in Brooklyn, was ordered suspended last evening by Mayor La Guardia after disclosures that Frank Erickson, described by the Mayor as "a notorious bookmaker," had paid $1,050.05 to Cannon as money he had won betting on horses.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 7. --Outwardly Italy's action in Albania is accepted with composure as unlikely to affect this country's vital interests and it is stressed by official sources that "Rome kept Belgrade constantly informed of the march of events."

In Dr. William H. Park the city loses not only a distinguished scientist but a devoted public servant. He and his predecessor and friend, the late Dr. Hermann Biggs, made the Health De partment of New York so much a model of efficiency that its work commands the admiration of the world.

BERLIN, April 7.--The news that Italy had landed troops in Albania was broadcast throughout Germany late this afternoon. The morning papers contained no mention of impending military action, although initiated circles were prepared for the event following the Italo-German general staff conversations of the last several days at Innsbruck.

NEWARK, N.J., April 7.--David B. Raschkover, testifying in his own defense in the city land conspiracy trial, refused this afternoon to answer a series of questions put to him on cross-examination on the ground that "to do so will expose me to criminal prosecution on other indictments."
With the appointment of its various sub-committees, the United States Golf Association is now fully prepared for the opening of the 1939 golf season, which is not far off.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 7.-- Dr. James Clifton Edgar, retired New York obstetrician, died today at his residence in Round Hill Road here after an illness of several months. The author of many works on his specialty, he had been a member of the staffs of leading New York hospitals and university faculties. His age was 79.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 7.-- Three new stained-glass windows will be dedicated on Easter Sunday morning in tie Hill School chapel to the memory of the parents and brother of the donor, an alumnus of the school. The windows are the work of Charles J. Connick of Boston.

CHICAGO, April 7.--With March sales of men's clothing showing a good gain over last year, the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers took a peek at fashions for Fall and predicted that stripes will be more than twice as popular as any other single pattern. Second in favor will be tweeds, followed by herringbones.
ROME, April 7 (AP).--Solemn church ceremonies commemorating Chirst's death on the cross brought to a climax Rome's Good Friday observances tonight.
ATHENS, Greece, April 7.--Queen Geraldine of Albania and her infant son, born only two days ago, are fugitives on Greek soil tonight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 7.-- Dr. David Efrom of Peru, in an address on "The Perils of a Totalitarian Invasion of South America" at the opening session today of the first intercollegiate conference of Latin-American students, said that the democratic forces were cooperating and that the outlook was encouraging.

The outdoor tennis season in the metropolitan area will be officially launched on May 27. On that date the annual invitation grass court tournament of the Crange Lawn Tennis Club will start at South Orange, N.J.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 7.--Running a faultless race, the white and liver pointer dog, Virginia R. Boy, owned and handled by Dr. B.F. Driggers of Near Brunswick, N.J., won the Members' All-Age Stake today at the thirty-eighth annual field trials of the English Setter Club or America. The meet is being contested over the famous course in this little village.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 7.-- Colonel Samuel Mowry Nicholson, president of the Nicholson File Company and one of the city's most prominent industrialists, died at his home here today after an illness of several months. He was 78 years old.

Reorganization of the clerical staff of the New York City school system, designed to raise the qualifications for more efficient service, was proposed yesterday by the Board of Education's law committee, James Marshall, president of the board, announced.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Department store sales during the week ended April 1 rose 7 per cent over the corresponding week last year and during the four-week period ended April 1 rose 4 per cent over the similar period in 1938, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The gain for the previous week was 2 per cent.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, April 7.--Part of the Navy personnel on Easter leave were recalled to their bases at Helder and Flushing today and the coastal defense was restored last week to its former strength when the effectives were increased for training purposes.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP).--The Bureau of Mines reported today that stocks of all oils on Feb. 28 were 554,241,000 barrels, or 154 days' supply. This compared with stocks of 554,243,000 barrels on Jan. 31. Stocks on Feb. 28, 1938, were 582,579,000 and equaled 172 days' supply.

PARIS, April 7.--French opinion has been far more shocked today by Italy's act of piracy against Albania than even by Germany's seizure of Austria or the dismemberment and annexation of CzechoSlovakia.

PARIS, April 7.--The countermoves of Italy and Germany against the British undertaking of mutual assistance today have become apparent, or have been carried out.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7--The California District Court of Appeals ruled today that closed shop union contracts were illegal in California, that "peaceful picketing" was unlawful when used for illegal purposes and that the question of jurisdiction, which has been the subject of frequent labor disputes of late, was in the province of governments, not of individuals and groups.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP).-- Benjamin C. Marsh, spokesman for the People's Lobby, told a Senate Labor subcommittee today that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was "stopped" when she started to show that "land speculators and building material profiteers" were blocking low-cost housing in this country.

BOWIE, Md., April 7.--Dizzy Dame, 5-year-old daughter of Distraction, carrying the silks of Herbert Kerr, made her second start of the year a winning one when she withstood a hard drive to take the six-furlong fifth event here today.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 7.-- The Giants came to the parting of the ways today. In a setting more suited to football than baseball the athletes, some of whom had been drilling since last Feb. 21, Went through their final non-game workout here to fit them for the 1939 National League flag race.

LONDON, April 7.--This is the one day in the year when everything stops in England. The utter quiet of the world's most crowded city is a startling climax to a tumultuous and momentous week. As far as London is concerned, today's bad news can wait until tomorrow. Not a newspaper was published.

Thompson, chairman of the Finance Committee, stated today. The report is to be presented April 20.

WASHINGTON, April 10.--President Roosevelt will withdraw the nomination of Thomas R. Amlie, former member of Congress from Wisconsin, to be a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission. This action follows the receipt of a letter from Mr. Amlie suggesting that his name be withdrawn.
LONDON, April 10.--The Cabinet decided today that any aggression upon Greece, Turkey or other countries in the Eastern Mediterranean would be regarded by Britain as an "unfriendly act."

GREENVILLE, S.C., April 11.-- In a dripping battle that was interrupted several times while the heavens wept at the rare spectacle, and then finally had to be abandoned completely after five innings because of a drenching downpour, those singularly inspired Dodgers today vanquished Joe McCarthy's world champion Yankees for the second successive afternoon.

CUXHAVEN, Germany, April 11. --A German Antarctic expedition, which left here four months ago for aerial research, returned today aboard the Schwabenland, the Lufthansa's South American service catapult ship which had been chartered for the expedition.

The Maritime Commission's drive to replace obsolescent tonnage in the American merchant marine has brought the United States into second place among the world's shipbuilding nations, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, containing figures to the end of March.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 11. --Surprising the Bermudians in their two International Class yacht races today, the Long Island Sound sailors scored their third straight victory in the afternoon and now need only one more for the match.

The old St. George Building, a five-story structure occupying part of the site in the heart of the old "hide and leather district," where the St. George Chapel stood nearly two centuries ago, is about to undergo extensive changes.

If the Board of Education endorses its law committee's recommendations at today's meeting, the city's kindergarten and elementary school teachers will in future have to have an A.B. degree or its equivalent. Teachers now on active, substitute or eligible lists will not be affected.

The withdrawal of Roy Durstine as president of Batten, Barton, Duretine Osborn was the chief topic of conversation in the advertising field here yesterday and rumors were numerous concerning his future plans. Mr. Durstine was not available for comment and is not expected back in the city until tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--Italian trade, particularly in the foreign field, has been adversely affected by international political developments. Trade generally throughout the world reflects political conditions, according to advices received by the Department of Commerce by cablegrams and radiograms on favorable and unfavorable developments of the week.

ALBANY, April ll.--Governor Lehman today signed nineteen bills and vetoed five. Most of them were of local or minor nature.

Foreign dollar obligations were sold off sharply to register new low levels for the current downward movement yesterday in another day of unsettlement and nervous price swings in trading on the listed bond market on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--An unexpected show of strength for a movement to repeal the Neutrality Act and put nothing in its place marked the opening today of hearings before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--The President's slogan of "No Compromise" does not change. He proved it again today by his inferential rebuke of his Senate leader, Mr. Barkley, in the form of a letter to Senator Pepper.
PEIPING, April 11.--Japanese Army headquarters here reports that Chinese attempts to conduct offensives throughout Southern and Southwestern Shansi have been repulsed on all fronts.

Duplex apartments, in which the rooms are arranged on two floor levels, appear to be in brisk demand. Several leases of Manhattan suites of this type were reported by brokers yesterday.

PETERSBURG, Va., April 11 (AP) --Cincinnati and the Red Sox put on another slugging match today in their North-bound exhibition series and the Reds finally took it, 11 to 9.

NEWARK, N.J., April 11.--The defense and prosecution rested this afternoon at the close of the last day of the twelfth court week of the city meadow land conspiracy trial after Special Prosecutor Warren Dixon Jr. had called only one rebuttal witness.

For the first time in the memory of the Federal Reserve Bank's clerical force, that bank's gold statement yesterday reported the receipt of $273,000 of gold from Scotland. The ship was the Caledonia, and the port of departure was Glasgow.

After a secret and stormy meeting lasting nearly four hours yeserday, delegates of the Patrol men's Benevolent Association representing 16,000 city patrolmen finally agreed to accept the tentative proposal of Commissioner Valentine to place all city police on emergency 16-hour-a-day duty during the first week of the World's Fair.

The first criminal prosecution of non-commercial smuggling in recent years, started by a tip from a German maid who was offended by dinner-table criticism of Adolf Hitler in the home of Supreme Court Justice Edgar N. Lauer, was closed yesterday in Federal court. Mrs. Elma N. Lauer, the jurist's wife, was sent to prison for three months and was fined $2,500.

Events in Europe are not marking time. In every country on the Continent more men are being called to arms and this fact is sufficiently disturbing in itself. Poland, calling reserves to the colors, apparently believes that it has increasing reason for concern over what Germany intends to do in Danzig.

Prospects of Sunday performances on the Broadway legitimate stage during the World's Fair were no-- ticeably dimmed yesterday after the Actors Equity Association refused to hold a referendum of its membership on playing Sabbath shows at the daily rate of pay until the other theatrical unions agreed first to work for the same scale.

What might properly be classified as the first major upset of the local college baseball season occurred yesterday at Dexter Park, where Long Island University's predominantly sophomore nine subjected the well-regarded St. John University team to an 8-2 setback Phil Caruso, sophomore southpaw, pitched the distance for the winners, limiting St. John's to five hits.

The "puller-in," as indigenous to Manhattan's lower East Side as pushcarts and old-law tenements, is doomed to extinction as a result of a bill signed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, making the practice a misdemeanor punishable by a $50 fine, ten days in jail or both.

The pamphlet report for 1938 of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, released for publication today, shows sales of $327,910,574, compared with $358,227,298 in 1937, a decline of about 8 per cent. Including $12,901,297 received from interest, dividends and other sources, gross income was $340,811,871, compared with $365,521,364.

FORT SMITH, Ark., April 11.-- One of the notable pursuits in the annals of baseball came to a close today. The Indians, after a sixyear chase through sixteen States, finally pulled even with the Giants.

After easing a few points under pressure of foreign liquidation, buying by trade and commission house interests steadied the market and left the list unchanged to 4 points lower.

A majority of the realty buyers figuring in the deals reported yesterday selected properties along the West Side in the area between midtown and Fort Tryon Park. Residential buildings were in demand for investment purposes.

SEATTLE, April 11 (AP).--William Thomas Lopp, chief of the Alaska division of the Federal Bureau of Education for fifteen years and credited with building the Territory's reindeer industry, died yesterday at the age of 74.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 11.--Three Army Air Corps officers were shaken up and an experimental attack-bombing plane built by the North American Aviation Corporation was destroyed here today when, in a forced landing near Wright Field, it hit an obstruction and burned. The plane was one of three ...
WASHINGTON, April 11.--Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States, had his seventyseventh birthday today and devoted it principally to work.
LONDON, April 11.--To understand the present grave situation in Europe and to appreciate exactly the attitude of the Western powers, one must distinguish between three kinds of measures.

After six weeks of negotiations between the Group Theatre and the Eastern Service Studios of Astoria, L. I., contracts have been drawn up for the filming here of three motion pictures in which the Group Theatre would be starred as a unit.
PARIS, April 11.--The strategic, economic and political advantages that Italy may derive from the occupation of Albania are so obvious that they need no explanation.

PARIS, April 11 (AP).--Most of the French Mediterranean fleet sailed tonight from the Toulon naval base for an undisclosed destination as France strengthened her defenses in the face of a troubled international situation.

The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday that net assets on March 31 were $28,450,374, equivalent to $70.60 a share for the preference stock and to 83 cents a share for the common stock, compared with $34,450,631, or $1.61 a common share, on Dec. 31, last.

Quarters in office, store and loft structures in four boroughs figured in the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. Involved were buildings in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 (AP).-- The pick of the country's amateur boxing talent marked time today for tomorrow's opening of the national A.A.U. championships. For part of one day and for three nights leather gloves will be pounding in the most varied pugilistic show for simon pures the nation has to offer.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11.--The recently filed suit to have the Pennsylvania Railroad and seven of its former directors or their estates adjudged responsible and liable for losses suffered by the Pennroad Corporation through the operation of the National Freight Company received indirect attention today at the annual stockholders' meeting of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
WARSAW, Poland, April 11.--Reservists usually called up for annual training in the Summer are already being instructed to report to their units for immediate service.

Contending that he had suffered unjust competition from a school cafeteria, the owner of a candy store and luncheonette opposite the school is suing the principal and his assistant for $10,000 and demanding a court injunction to prevent further "unfair" acts.

London was less apprehensive last night after a busy diplomatic day, as a result of which Prime Minister Chamberlain is expected to widen tomorrow's declaration on the Mediterranean to cover a determination to resist aggression anywhere in that region. Although Mr. Chamberlain ...
WASHINGTON, April 11.--A joint declaration under the Holding Company Act has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the International Utilities Corporation, the General Water...

LYONS, N.Y., April 11.--Miss Clara Knyphen Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Platt Williams of this place, was married to Henry Osborne MacCabe Merewether of Folkestone, England, here at noon today in Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, of which her grandfather, the late Rev. W. H. Williams, was one-time rector.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York defended the National Labor Relations Act today in the crowded caucus room of the Senate Office Building as the Senate Committee on Labor and Education opened its hearings on amendment proposals.

Alvan Macauley, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, announced yesterday that, subject to approval by the directors, he would at his own request become chairman of the board and be succeeded as president by M.M. Gilman, vice president...

Reports that Mayor La Guardia would not seek re-election when his term expires in 1941 were confirmed yesterday by the Mayor's executive secretary, Stanley H. Howe, in a talk before the Merchants and Manufacturers Association of Bush Terminal.

Parents in other cities who bring their children to visit the World's Fair need have little fear of children's diseases while in New York, Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Com-- missioner, said yesterday in commenting on the vital statistics for last week.

BERLIN, April 11 (AP).--An attempt to reach Grover Cleveland Bergdoll by telephone from Berlin through the postoffice of Weinsberg, the Wuerttemberg village where he had made his home, brought an answer today that "Herr Bergdoll already has left with his family for America."

The indictment of Sanitation Commissioner Carey and Health Commissioner Rice by the Queens grand jury for dumping garbage in the Jamaica Bay area focuses attention again on a civic problem which must somehow be solved.

The annual meeting of stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, held at Wilmington, Del., yesterday, was adjourned until April 25 in order to give the corporation time to advise stockholders that proposals would be made at the meeting to change the place of holding meetings to New York City and to permit stockholders to vote for independent auditors.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 11.--In ceremonies blending the old and the new, the Right Rev. Edwin V. Byrne, Roman Catholic Bishop of San Juan, blessed the new Banco Popular de Puerto Rico Building at its official opening here today.

ALBANY, April 11.--The New York Court of Appeals held valid today the "little Wagner act" under which the State set up machinery for collective bargaining in industries engaged in intrastate commerce.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 11.-- Happiness in marriage and in family life is important not only on personal and social grounds, but as a national safeguard, Dr. Ernest R. Groves of the University of North Carolina declared today in opening the fifth conference on conservation of marriage and the family, of which he is the founder and director.
Tony Canzoneri came back from the edge of certain defeat to earn a draw with Jimmy Vaughn of Cleveland in the feature bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 11.--The Bulgarian Government ordered today the dissolution of the Bulgarian Nazi organization, which was supported by Germany. Although all political groups have been prohibited in Bulgaria for some time, this one escaped the ban owing to the impression that it was a patriotic association.
LONDON, April 11.--Increased nervousness in the stock markets today marked resumption of business after the Easter holiday as the result of political developments in Europe over the week-end.

DOVER, Del., April 11 (AP).--The Delaware Supreme Court decided today that Loft, Inc., and not its former president, had a right to a large block of stock of the PepsiCola Company that has been is litigation for some time.

The Salle d'Armes Vince team of Miss Maria Cerra, intercollegiate champion; Miss Madeline Dalton and Mrs. Marion Lloyd Vince, former national champion, won the women's national foil championship on the strip of the Fencers Club last night.

The National Maritime Union, which has been threatening a strike against oil tanker operators, resumed negotiations with the companies yesterday in the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street. The union announced last week that it would take "action" against the operators unless agreements meeting the workers' "fundamental" demands were signed by April 17.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Society, John Barbirolli conducting, will give the world premiere performances of Bernard Herrmann's dramatic Cantata, "Moby Dick,"

ALBANY, April 11. --Senator Joseph D. Nunan Jr., Queens, Democrat, today sponsored a bill in the Legislature that would permit the City Council to levy a fivecent tax on all World's Fair admission tickets. Senator Nunan...

A simple memorial service for the late Dr. Charles Ruppert Stockard, professor and head of the Department of Anatomy at Cornell University Medical College, was held yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the school.
The season's first wheat crop estimate, as of April 1, published by the Agricultural Department yesterday, places the indicated Winter wheat production at 549,219,000 bushels.

A memorial exhibition made up of more than 200 paintings and drawings by Alexandre Iacovleff, who died last year at the age of 51, opened with a reception and preview yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 11 (AP). --The world's two fastest harness horses, Billy Direct, the pacer, and Greyhound, the trotter, will meet in a series of match races this season if Vic Fleming has his way.

M.L. Toulme, secretary of the National American Wholesale Grocers Association, was elected chairman of the Council of National Wholesale Associations at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Mr. Toulme succeeds B. ...

WASHINGTON, April 11.--The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an application by the Greyhound Corporation of Chicago to acquire stock control of the Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., and the Northland Greyhound Lines, Inc., which control has been shared hitherto with the New York Central Railroad and the Great Northern Railway, respectively.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Reports are reaching Washington that followers of former President Hoover are becoming active in a movement to make him the Presidential nominee in 1940.

Surrogate James A. Foley signed a decree yesterday settling the account of Henry O. Havemeyer, sugar merchant, which was filed on June 24, 1937, by the children of the decedent, Horace Havemeyer of Islip, L.I., Electra H. Webb, Westbury, L.I., and Adaline H. Frelinghuysen, Morristown, N.J., executors and trustees, which valued the estate at $28,797,053.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 11.--The District Circuit Court of Appeals here reversed today an order of the National Labor Relations Board requiring the Waterman Steamship Company of Mobile to reinstate forty-three members of the National Maritime Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, and to allow delegates of the union to go aboard ships of the company to solicit members.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--President Roosevelt strongly implied at his press conference today that he believed the involvement of the United States in any general European war was inevitable and that this nation should stand shoulder to shoulder with Great Britain and France against Nazi-Fascist machinations aimed at world domination by force.

Prominent publishers, trade union officials and veteran pressmen who had seen high-speed newspaper printing revolutionized under the inventive genius of Henry A. Wise Wood joined in tribute to the inventor at funeral services yesterday.
Arthur N. Pierson, treasurer of Union County, N.J., and former State Senator, spoke yesterday at a luncheon of the Municipal Forum of New York in the Lawyers Club.
WASHINGTON, April 11.--A coalition of Democrats and Republicans in the House pushed through today an amendment to the Federal Housing Authority Mortgage Bill. The amendment was designed ...

The vanguard of 100 ships of the United States Fleet--most of them due to arrive here April 29 for the opening of the World's Fair--will steam into port today when the supply ship Arctic and the oiler Neches arrive at the navy yard in Brooklyn.

ROME, April 11.--The international situation brought about by Premier Benito Mussolini's Albanian coup grew sufficiently alarming today to induce the fascist government to issue a general warning to all that Italy is militarily strong, having more than 1,000,000 men under arms and therefore is not an easy target for punitive or preventive measures.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--A combined profit of about $53,000,000 after all charges was reported for the fiscal year 1937 by five leading mail order houses studied in connection with the Census of American Listed Corporations and made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The report of the Engineers Publice Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, and issued yesterday, discloses a net income after all expenses and charges of $4,567,244.
GENEVA, April 11.--Hungary notified the League of Nations today of her intention to withdraw at the expiration of the required two-year notice. Peru resigned Saturday.

Alfred Robert Kirkus, real estate man, who operated for more than sixty years in the Worth Street dry goods district, died yesterday in his home, 18 Cranberry Street, Brooklyn Heights. Mr. Kirkus was influential in the creation of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals in 1916. He was 82 years old.

A syndicate headed by the First National Bank of New York and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $3,999,000 of non-callable refunding bonds of Detroit on a bid of 100.0212 for $3,623,000 as 4s and $376,000 as 3 s, or a net interest cost basis of 3.9568 per cent.

Effective nationally, a broader liability coverage without increase in premium was announced yesterday by the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters for passenger car owners insured under standard, or "limited," type of policy.

Seizing Time not so much by the forelock as by the back hair, the Sixth Avenue Association is offering prizes for the best photographs of its favorite thoroughfare, before and after the removal of the elevated line.

With prices on Fall clothing practically unchanged from the Spring level, leading manufacturers started to send salesmen on the road with the new lines yesterday. While they were highly encouraged by the improvement in retail sales of Spring lines in the last two to three weeks, they admitted that domestic uncertainty and the ourrent tension in Europe may militate against heavy advance covering by stores.
Mrs. Elias Compton, mother of Dr. Karl Taylor Compton, president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Dr. Arthur Holly Compton, Professor of Physics at...

There is doubtless a good case to be made for the Administration'a plan to offer to exchange with England, the Netherlands and Belgium 2,000,000 or more bales of cotton and 100,000,000 bushels of wheat for large supplies of rubber and tin.

The four-story dwelling at 814 Park Avenue, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Mrs. Madeline W. Levy through C. Alfred Burhorn Company and Joseph A. Carluccio, Inc., co-brokers.

Regulations covering the eightysix certified coal tar colors to be used under the provisions of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act have been issued by the Department of Agriculture, it was reported...
Out of a shattering tragedy Charlotte Armstrong has recovered a few merciful strands of beauty, "The Happiest Days," which arrived at the Vanderbilt last evening.

Despite the threats to European peace, The Netherlands is going ahead with her public housing program for low-income groups and expects to rid the country entirely of slum areas within the next five or six years, Jan Bommer, a leader in the housing movement in that country and a member of the City Council of Amsterdam, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 11.--An alltime record for safe Winter operations has been made by the airlines of the United States, according to the Civil Aeronautics Authority.
Argentina is whole-heartedly behind the Hull reciprocal trade policies, despite that country's bilateral trade agreements with England, Germany and others, John Abbink.

The two five-story apartment houses on an irregular plot 120 by 109 feet at 1,103 and 1,109 Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, were sold by the estate of Jacob S. Mehlman to an investing client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney.

Business leaders of the country will support the Wagner act if it is amended to make it a "good law," Tom M. Girdler, board chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, told 400 members of the Ohio Society of New York at their annual dinner last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, followed up his recent criticisms of the American press with a dissertation last night on "columnitis, that curious, endemic malady which, in these modern days, has infected one newspaper after another." In the course of his remarks he disclosed his opinion of most of the better-known columnists.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--A Senate coalition which was not impressed today by another White House appeal stood by the House and voted a relief deficiency appropriation of $100,000,000 instead of the $150,000,000 requested repeatedly by President Roosevelt.

Fred Corcoran, just in from the Winter golf circuit, believes this country's professionals have reached such a point of perfection that par, as it is now figured, is an utterly outmoded standard, he told The Associated Press in an interview yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11.--In a 2-to-1 decision the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today dismissed 483 claims of error and affirmed the conviction of Ellis H. Parker, former Burlington County (N.J.) detective, and his son, Ellis Jr., in the kidnapping and torture of Paul H. Wendel.

An early-afternoon rally of sharp proportions, apparently inspired by Prime Minister Chamberlain's peace appeal to Premier Mussolini, checked yesterday a break in the stock market which had depressed values to last June's levels.
TALKING with Wilfred H. (Bunny) Austin, the former British Davis Cup star, it turned out that Bunny was of the opinion that Don Budge "had lifted tennis to new heights" with his swishing racquet.

ALBANY, April 11.--The Court of Appeals in a four-to-three decision today ruled that funds of the Moscow Fire Insurance Company, now on deposit in the Bank of New York and Trust Company, could not be taken over by the United States. The money, the court held, is subject to distribution to the owners thereof.

Manufacturing industry paid more than 3 per cent of aggregate sales in taxes during 1938, exclusive of Federal excise taxes, according to an analysis made public yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., of the first 10,000 returns to its national survey on taxes paid by business in 1938.

MOSCOW, April 11.--Once, it was ten or twelve years ago, the then Commissar of Foreign Affairs of Soviet Russia, named Tchitcherin, said blandly to me: "In dealing with the Japanese we are faced by the atrocious subtleties of Oriental diplomacy."

WASHINGTON, April 11.--President Roosevelt conferred with Senate and House leaders on legislative matters and with Secretary of State Hull and Assistant Secretary Messersmith and expressed approval at his press conference of a newspaper editorial which interpreted his farewell remarks upon leaving Warm Springs...

BOWIE, Md., April 11--High Hedge, speedy 6-year-old son of Tall Timber, flying the white, green and red racing livery of H.L. Bowers, recorded his second triumph in three local starts when he outfooted five other sprinters in the six-furlong Hardcastle Purse today.

TORONTO, April 11.--Little Bobby Bauer caught the opposition in a brief lapse tonight and started the Boston Bruins on the way to a 3-1 victory that gave them a one-game advantage over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the Stanley Cup finals.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP).-- President Roosevelt took another step toward speeding up national defense preparations today by asking Congress to appropriate $32,500,000 for "educational" orders to train manufacturers in mass production of munitions.

The feature of the concert given last night by the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall--and a significant feature it was--was the appearance as guest leader of the composer Paul Hindemith in the performance of one of his latest works, "Nobilissima Visione: Concert Suite From the Ballet 'Saint Francis.'"
Supreme among the amateurs for ten years, Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. met his master in the world open squash tennis championship last night at the Shelton Hotel.

A campaign to raise $2,967,000 for a new building and equipment for Roosevelt Hospital was opened last night is the presence of a distinguished gathering of physicians and laymen at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria with the announcement by Thomas S. McLane, president of the board of Roosevelt Hospital, that nearly $500,000 of the needed money already had been obtained.

An offering of $40,000,000 of twenty-year 3 per cent debentures of the Texas Corporation, to increase working capital will be made today by an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co. The debentures, due on April 1, 1959, are priced at 101, and interest.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 11.-- Kansas City, formerly reputed one of the most "wide open" towns in the United States, is now closed, so far as open gambling and nudity or near nudity in its night clubs are concerned.

ALBANY, April 11.--The possibility of the candidacy of James A. Farley for President in 1940 was a matter of discussion here today among Democratic leaders of the State at a luncheon and a Jefferson Day dinner tonight.

Floyd Bennett Field was invaded yesterday by 6,000 air-minded youngsters who swarmed all over the place, bicycled on the runways, clambered on and slid off sloping wings and astounded every one by keeping completely out of the way of the throbbing propellers of incoming and outgoing planes.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the Western Electric Company yesterday Charles L. Rice, vice president of the company and manager of its Hawthorne works in Chicago, was elected a member of the board of directors. All other directors were re-elected.
PITTSBURGH, April 11 (AP).--Dr. John Bain Sutherland will lead into gridiron battle, for charity's sake, at least one more football team that has Pitt written all over it.

OTTAWA, April 11 (Canadian Press).--Canadian banking, as currently operated under governmental control, is "more secure than it has ever been" Finance Minister Dunning said in the House of Commons today as he interrupted an argument on money and banking by C.H. Landeryou of Alberta, Social Credit member. Mr. Landeryou...

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, told shareholders yesterday at their annual meeting that, with restoration of the European situation to a peaceful basis, he expected an increase in the earning power of the electric power and light industry and a revival of its ability to provide for expansion through equity financing.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 11.-- At least one indictment and perhaps several, which will not be opened until tomorrow, were obtained here today by United States Attorney John T. Cahill of New York under a special Federal commission authorizing him to pursue his judicial bribery investigation to Connecticut.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 11.-- Testimony given before the extraordinary grand jury which investigated Waterbury's municipal affairs last Spring was read to the jury today as the trial of twenty-three men charged with conspiring to defraud the city was resumed following an adjournment last Thursday.
Receipt of an additional $14,831,000 of foreign gold, which will go immediately into the monetary gold stock, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank.

BERLIN, April 11.--Official Berlin is emerging only slowly from its Easter lull, and the Foreign Office today was silent again on the activities of Britain and France. The absence of official reaction, however, was amply offset by press comment.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--The deadline for payment of premiums on 1939 "all risk" crop insurance has been set at April 23 by the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation. Insurance does not go into effect on a crop until the premium has been paid.

Charging that operators in the Appalachian soft coal region have locked out 320,000 miners who have been idle since April 1, when their contract expired, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, accused the operators yesterday of aiming to destroy the union in response to the desire of "outside interests."

PARIS, April 11.--It is believed that the French and British admiralties have already taken every measure needed to make effective the resolve of the London and Paris Cabinets to prevent the Mediterranean status quo from being further disturbed to their disadvantage, and that guarantees for that purpose will be given to various powers either in general terms or under the form of separate agreements.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 11.-- Events in Slovakia are being carefully watched here. Radio broadcasts ...

PHILADELPHIA, April 11.--The New York Herald Tribune was announced today as the winner of the Francis Wayland Ayer Cup, offered annually by N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., to the daily newspaper chosen as outstanding for typographical excellence. A total of 1,328 newspapers were entered in the ninth exhibition of newspaper typography.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,443,900 barrels, compared with 3,358,200 in the previous week, an increase of 85,700, according to the American Petroleum In-- stitute. Production was 9,900 barrels in excess of the calculation of 3,434,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for April.

Dr. Julius Weiss, a Bronx general practitioner who also specialized in obstetrics and gynecology, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. Dr. Weiss, who was a founder and president of the medical board of the Bronx Maternity and Woman's Hospital, had his home and office at 1,000 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. He was 63 years old.

ATHENS, Greece, April 11.--There has been as yet no announcement concerning the progress of the Greek-British negotiations, which are believed still to be going on between Premier John Metaxas and Sir Sydney Waterlow, British Minister to Athens. The proceedings are secret, and it is expected the results will not be made known here until after they have been formally announced in the British Parliament.

CHICAGO, April 11.--Wheat prices fluctuated in an erratic manner today. An early advance of 1 cent a bushel carried the market into new high ground for about two months, but as soon as short covering let up prices turned downward and final trades were near the bottom, 1/8 cent lower to 1/6 cent higher than yesterday. Trading was fairly active, especially early in the session.
Edward Drago, who will be five months old next Friday, was crowned yesterday with the title "Perfect Baby" in Brooklyn.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11.-- Walter Wanger today concluded deals to borrow Ann Sheridan and Richard Carlson for the leads in "Winter Carnival," scheduled to go before the cameras April 24.

The golden, emerald-encrusted Crown of Our Lady of the Andes, sixteenth century treasure fashioned by the Spanish goldsmiths of Popayan, Colombia, for their Queen of Heaven as a token of their appreciation at being spared from a devastating plague, will be placed on view today at the Grand Central Art Galleries for about two weeks, devoted "to the piety of the American people."

LOS ANGELES, April 11.--Joan Crawford obtained a divorce today from Franchot Tone in Judge Benjamin Scheinman's court after she testified that they could not make a success of marriage, but "would always be friendly."

An investigation within an investigation was launched by Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday to determine how Frank A. Erickson, bookmaker, described by Mayor La Guardia as a "notorious gambler" and persona non grata within the city, happened to enjoy with full authority of the Police Department the right to possess a pistol in his home.

WASHINGTON, April 12.--The United States Fleet will pass in review before the Secretary of the Navy, Mr. Swanson, when it weighs anchor in Hampton Roads and heads for New York two weeks from tomorrow.

Educators were warned yesterday that unless they paid more attention to the grave problems of society and less to their own professional and technical interests they stood in danger of losing the support of the general public.
GREENVILLE, Miss., April 12.-- The Giants' losing streak snapped today without benefit of Colonel Bill Terry's leadership or appreciable effort on their part.

WASHINGTON, April 12.--Kenneth Anderson, clerk of the House Military Affairs Committee, refused today to testify under oath for a deposition to be used as evidence at the Newark (N.J.) meadow land conspiracy trial. Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark is among the defendants in the case.

PRINCETON, N.J, April 12.-- Fordham pounded two Princeton pitchers for fourteen hits today to down Old Nassau, 7--2, and hang up its fifth consecutive victory this season.

Mrs. Marius de Brabant entertained with a dinner last night at her home, 7 East Fifty-first Street, for Miss Adah Horn, daughter of Mrs. Tiemann N. Horn, and Griff G. Berkeley, whose marriage will take place on April 20 at the home of her mother, 1,130 Park Avenue.

Moving forward with his plans to operate the $1,000,000 Czecho-Slovak exhibit as an integral part of the World's Fair, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that the enterprise would be finished and staffed by a committee of outstanding citizens.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 12.-- Concluding its Winter fishing contest, the Sailfish Club gave its annual party tonight at the clubhouse. Elmer Rich, president, awarded more than fifty trophies to winners in various classifications. Later there was dancing with supper served at midnight.

Delegations of local and up-State retail druggists and grocers will urge passage of the Parsons costplus bill at the hearing on the measure to be held in Albany today by the General Laws Committee of the Senate.

After trailing through six innings the City College nine pushed over six runs in the seventh to win from Seton Hall, 9--8, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. It was the opening game of the season for the losers and the fourth for the Beavers, all four of their tests Laving been decided by one-run margins.
WASHINGTON, April 12.--The House gave Speaker William B. Bankhead a standing ovation today, his sixty-fifth blrthday.

CANNES, France, April 12.--Dr. Walter Lehman, court physician of King Zog of Albania, who attended Queen Geraldine at the birth of Crown Prince Skander last week, said here today that Albania's plight was a result of the country's having taken Italian money despite the fact that it was not too fond of the givers.

HENDAYE, France (near the Spanish frontier), April 12.--It is reported from Madrid that all motorized troops in Spain, estimated to number between 35,000 and 50,000, will be withdrawn to Morocco during the coming week.
CLEVELAND, April 12 (AP).--An epidemic of championship jitters had a hold on the American Bowling Congress today and no changes resulted in the standings.

The Southern Natural Gas Company in its annual report for 1928, made public yesterday, shows a net income of $949,230 after all charges and taxes and after an extraordinary deduction of $226,326 for natural-gas exploration.

In Federal court yesterday the government began to draw back the curtain from the spy mystery associated with Donald L. and Ruth Norma Robinson, the married couple nobody has heard from since they were put into a Moscow prison early in 1938.

The coming of Spring infected with a strong attack of wanderlust eleven adventurous orphans from St. Malachy's Ocean Home, a Catholic institution run by Sisters of St. Joseph on 112th Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens. The brief attack ended suddenly yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, April l2.--At a meeting this evening, at which representatives of Arab countries, except Palestine, were present, British proposals to Palestine Arabs were again discussed.

Willard Huntington Wright, who as S.S. Van Dine created Philo Vance and made best-sellers of the fictional detective's adventures, died Tuesday night of coronary thrombosis in his home, 241 Central Park West. He was 51 years old and had been ill for several months.
An ownership of sixty years' duration of a Brooklyn building has just been interrupted with the sale of the three-story cold-water flat with nine rooms at 489 Eighteenth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, April 12.-- The Chinese military spokesman declined today to describe the Chinese attacks against Japanese positions on almost all war fronts as a general counter-offensive.

WASHINGTON, April 12.--The United States has the economic power to prevent the outbreak of war anywhere in the world, Professor Charles G. Fenwick of Bryn Mawr College told the Foreign Affairs Committee today.

Miss Cobina Wright Jr. was honored as "the most attractive and talented New York girl of the 1939 season" at the opening reception last night of the Society of Illustrators in connection with its annual ...

ALBANY, April 12.--The State death rate for February was 10 per cent higher than a year ago, according to a report made today by Dr. J.V. De Porte, director of the division of vital statistics of the State Department of Health.
WASHINGTON, April 12.--The resignation of Edwin S. Thomas as United States judge for the District of Connecticut was accepted by President Roosevelt today.

Colby M. Chester, chairman of the General Foods Corporation, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that net profit for the first quarter of this year was $4,082,316, equal to 74 cents a share on the common stock ...

OWENSBORO, Ky., April 13 (AP). --Bob Klinger, whose right arm may be a deciding factor for the Pirates this season, singled with the bases full in the tenth inning today to give Pittsburgh a 5-to-4 victory over the White Sox in the last contest of their nine-game series.

With no indications that President Roosevelt would grant the applications for clemency for three convicted former officials of the State Title and Mortgage Company yesterday, it was expected that they would surrender today in Federal Court here to begin serving the sentences they have avoided since their conviction nearly fifteen months ago.

Mrs. Sadie Nova, 55 years old, wife of Supreme Court Justice Algernon I. Nova, was found dead after suffering a heart attack last night in the bathroom of her home, 135 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. Mrs. Nova had been receiving treatment for a heart ailment for some time.

NEWARK, N.J., April 13.--Final defense motions for dismissal were denied today by Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan at the city land conspiracy trial and defense attorneys began summing up in behalf of the nine defendants.
Two guarantee forms recommended for use by the cosmetic industry under the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act have been formulated by the Toilet Goods Association, it was learned yesterday.
An important deal for property in Queens which apparently presages the entry of a New England restaurant chain into the New York field on an extensive scale, was revealed yesterday.
ALBANY, April 13.--Retailers from all sections of the State today urged passage of the Esquirol-Parsons "Loss Leader" Bill, which would prohibit the sale of merchandise at less than cost.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 13 (AP). --J.C. Milam's Kentucky Derby "dark horse" Opelika stepped away from two other Derby nominees today to win the Parrish Purse before a crowd of 6,000 gathered at the Keeneland race course for the opening of the Spring racing season in Kentucky.

BERLIN, April 13.--Spain's future role in world affairs will be that of a powerful nation which, if she knows what is good for her, will ally herself closely with the totalitarian powers, it is stated by Colonel Rudolf von Xylander, a well-known military writer and instructor at Berlin's Military Academy.

Teachers were advised yesterday to take an active part in combating the current "campaign of misrepresentation" against business and to place more emphasis in the classroom upon old-fashioned homely American virtues, in an address by Aorace Liversidge, president of the Philadelphia Electric Company.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13.-- Morris R. Bockius, a widely known attorney, died at his Summer residence near Newtown Square today after an illness of two months. He was 79.

ROME, April 13.--Premier Benito Mussolini watched for three hours from a balcony of the Palazzo Venezia a series of aerial precaution tests held here this morning.

WASHINGTON, April 13.--Edward J. Noble, newest addition to the business men in the Department of Commerce, is a "nut" on the subject of increasing business volume, he told his first press conference today.

World stocks of refined copper at the end of March amounted to 506,391 tons, compared with 493,114 at the close of February, an increase of 13,277, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks last month declined 7,407 tons, making the net increase 5,870 tons in all stocks.

ALBANY, April 13.--The proposed State-wide sales tax, which has bobbed in and out of the State fiscal program ever since the start of the legislative session, is once more in eclipse.

WASHINGTON, April 13.--Secretary Ickes signed a license today permitting Pan American Airways, Inc., to use Canton Island, about 1,250 miles Southwest of Hawaii, as an air base for a projected transPacific air transport service between California and New Zealand.

Agnew, secretary of the association.

Andrews, administrator.

Mr. Herbert Winlock has worked steadily and brilliantly for the Metropolitan Museum of Art for almost a generation. As its director for the last eight years, hard years of straitened allowances, he has had what may be called an all-around success.

LONDON, April 19.--The stock markets developed a firm undertone today on a more hopeful view of the political situation. Caution remained the keynote, however, and business was still small. A program is being launched by the Provincetown Art Association to raise $50,000 to build and maintain a fireproof Memorial Gallery as a tribute to the late Charles W. Hawthorne, who founded the Cape Cod Art School in 1899.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--Subsidies still appear to Secretary of Agriculture Wallace to be the most economical and efficient means to pursue in this country's drive to recapture a fair share of the world's trade for cotton exports.

Woolf's hope to capture the Kentucky Derby for his second consecutive triumph, ran a mile in time varying from 1:39 1-5 to 1:40 flat--the fastest reported prep for any Derby candidate this year. Arthur Rubin defeated Joe Procita, 40 to 32, in 31 innings last night in a semi-final round match of the open three-cushion tourney at Jack Doyle's Academy. Rubin had a high run of 12 to Procita's 6. Rubin will play Edward Lee tonight in the final.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--The House Ways and Means Committee recommended today that Congress "freeze" the social security old-age payroll tax at 1 per cent for the next three years instead of permitting it, as provided in the law, to rise automatically to 1 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 28.--Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here advanced today 1 to 2 cents a bushel to the highest prices for any delivery since July, 1938.
