LONDON, May 1.--As a sequel to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's denunciation of the Anglo-German naval agreement Britain, France and the United States have begun to discuss, informally, the possibility of removing the ban on the construction of heavy cruisers, which they imposed on themselves by the London Naval Treaty of 1936, it was learned tonight.
TRENTON, N.J., May 1.--By a vote of 41 to 18, but without debate, the Assembly passed tonight a bill to limit the powers of Chancery Court in issuance of preliminary injunctions in labor disputes.
MEXICO CITY, May 1.--The militant Mexican labor movement showed its strength today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP).--Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, endorsed today major provisions of a bill by Senators Wheeler of Montana and Truman of Missouri to revise railroad bankruptcy procedure.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--Though the Administration will have its own chairman of the SEC if the Senate confirms (as it probably will) the New Deal's Leon Henderson to be a member of the commission, and though Jerome Frank may not be required to vote for himself in order to become chairman, recent events indicate the SEC has become a truly independent agency and is likely to remain so far a while.

IT is difficult to put into words the refreshing quality of Peter de Polnay's "Angry Man's Tale,"* but the book has a spirit of its own and ought to please those who like a taste of tartness now and then. It has wit, character and, for a first novel, which it is, a fine polish. It is an ironic comedy of manners, opening in Majorca shortly before the outbreak of the Spanish civil war.

With the Federal Building serving as a background and the foreign pavilions in colorful array close by, the Borough of Queens started its varied activities for the week yesterday afternoon in the Court of Peace at the World's Fair with a program dominated by music and a historical resume of the dance in this country.

Two veteran Tammany district leaders disappeared from the political scene yesterday in the course of the political manoeuvering that has followed the conviction by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of James J. Hines.

Juan Negrin, Loyalist Premier of Spain until the last three weeks before the Nationalist victory, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie. He said he would leave in about a week for Mexico to arrange for the admission of Loyalist refugoes now in France. Until he had Consulted with President Lazaro Cardenas, he said, he could not estimate how many of the 400,000 refugees would be admitted.

MIAMI, Fla., May 1.--The Miami Daily News's fight against the ultimately recalled City Commission majority, which was announced today as a Pulitzer Prize winner, began about seven months after two of the three commisisoners under attack had been inducted into office by the largest pluralities ever given commissioners by a Miami electorate.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--Despite "the terrible situation in New York," said B.F. Beach, secretarymanager of the Michigan Milk Producers Association, before the Temporary National Economic Committee today, State milk control was preferable to free competition which resulted in "ruinous" prices to the consumer.
Castle Point Building and Loan Association sold to the Eno Holding Corporation, for a consideration shown as $42,500, the apartment house at 889-891 Palisade Avenue, Union City, N.J.
MOSCOW, May 1.--About 15,000 soldiers and 1,500,000 civilians-- men, women and children--marched through Red Square today in the May Day parade.
The stewards of the Jamaica track will put into effect a new rule for the protection of bettors, it was announced last night.

CHICAGO, May 1.--Monty Stratton collected upward of $25,000 and Dizzy Dean lost a ball game today. The White Sox, for whom Stratton pitched last year, knocked Dean out of the box and won an exhibition intracity game from the Cubs, 4 to 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1.-- Mack Sennett was engaged today by Twentieth Century-Fox to act as associate producer on the forthcoming "Hollywood Cavalcade," with Alice Faye, Don Ameche and J. Edward Bromberg.

ALBANY, May 1.--Governor Lehman today signed the McBain bill providing that where electricity is used to light a voting machine the electric light so used shall have an intensity not greater than 60 watts.

Twenty-two hundred members of the International Business Machines Corporation organization gathered at the World's Fair yesterday to mark the beginning of the conventions phase of the Fair, which will witness several hundred similar meetings during the coming months.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--"What is Scotch whisky?" was asked of the Supreme Court today in the final argument of the waning term. Taking this question under advisement the justices shut off all other hearings preparatory to final adjournment on May 29.

The Federal Reserve Bank began yesterday a system of more complete reports on foreign gold receipts by giving total gold imports instead of merely those directly affecting the monetary gold stock of the United States. The bank's daily ...

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 1.-- From affairs of state President Roosevelt turned his attention briefly today to the subject of Dutch colonial architecture and, with two Cabinet officers and his royal Danish guests, motored to Rhinebeck to present to that town a new postoffice which probably will go down in history as one of the most thoroughly dedicated buildings of its kind in America.

LONDON, May 1.--On a fuller consideration of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech, investors round little inducement to support the stock markets today and, with the Polish situation providing some uncertainty, prices fell as business was reduced to small proportions.

Mayor La Guardia was credited yesterday with playing a major role in the settlement of the jurisdictional dispute between carpenters and metal workers which had resulted at noon in the laying off, of 200 bricklayers on the Red Hook housing project and which threatened to halt all construction there by the end of the week.

WASHINGTON,May 1.--American business was warned today by Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, in charge of the Administration's anti-monopoly drive, to comply and cooperate with the constructive enforcement of the Anti-Trust Laws as the only alternative to a government-controlled industrial economy.

Government and defense counsel summed up their cases in the passport racket trial yesterday before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard, who this morning will charge the jury and direct it to consider a verdict.
A further upturn and trading flurry in local traction issues was the only feature in an exceedingly dull session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

The speeches with which our World's Fair was opened were not marred by the complacency which is the bane of such occasions. The President, the Governor, the Mayor, the president of the Fair, as well as Chairman McAneny of the Fair's board of directors, and President Lawrence of the State Chamber of Commerce, who spoke at the Subtreasury exercises, all found a good deal to be thankful for.

The World's Fair did honor to the world's foremost tennis player yesterday, when J. Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., received the Golden Laurel for the outstanding contribution in the world of sport in 1938.

The National Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America has awarded three gold honor medals and eight certificates for heroism to Boy Scouts who saved the lives of others at personal risk, Daniel Carter Beard, National Scout Commissioner and court chairman, announced yesterday.

Two of this season's successful plays will end their Broadway runs after the performances of Saturday. Oldest of them is "Oscar Wilde," the Leslie and Sewell Stokes biographical drama about Wilde, which will have played 246 times at the Fulton Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--If disaster is staved off in Europe, growth of the New Dealers' conviction that "the President must run again" may well turn out to be this month's most significant development. Coming from men who commonly, though often prematurely, reflect the President himself, the statement that he "must run again" is of vast potential importance.

The city of New Haven, represented by 6,000 men and women led by Governor Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut, yesterday celebrated New Haven Day at the World's Fair, the first of a series of functions at the grounds planned to compliment municipalities.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 1.-- Twenty-seven more corporations agreed today to pay one-fifteenth of approximately $7,500,000 in personal property taxes sought by Jersey City for 1937, 1938 and 1939. The city accepted the compromise offer, which totals $506,220.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1.-- The Rev. Dr. Walter Huntington Rollins, superintendent for the last seventeen years of the 344 Congregational and Christian Churches in New York State, died last night at his home here. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 1.--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 26:

LONDON, May 1.--British hesitation today delayed the inclusion of the Soviet Union in the anti-aggression alliance, although events already have driven conservative Great Britain and Communist Russia into closer relationship than would have been imaginable a few short weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--An appeal to business men of the United States to employ the practical commercial methods available to avert war and consequent collapse of economic order was made tonight by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, to a group of business leaders gathered from all parts of the country.
Whether Pandora, the giant panda at the Bronx Zoo, will remain a spinster for the rest of her life will be determined in a few days. It all depends on Bimbo.

The nimblest fingers in the metropolitan area received recogniation at the Town Hall Club yesterday as Mrs. Lavinia Cervone, housewife, of 696 Melrose Avenue, the Bronx, won first prize in a contest to discover the speediest manipulator of the crochet needle in this city.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--Assertions that Communists not only dominated the Federal Writers Project in New York but that their influence extended to the WPA in Washington, were made today before the House Appropriations Subcommittee investigating the administration of relief.

A Negro porter at the medical display, the Hall of Man, turned away three early visitors, all women. "Sorry, ladies," he told them. "This show is for men only. Hall of Man; that's us." The ladies left. Late yesterday afternoon attendants were approached by three sailors. They frowned at the exhibits a few minutes, but seemed unhappy. One of them went to the official on duty.

Officers of the visiting Atlantic Squadron were warned last night at a dinner in their honor at the Hotel Commodore that the navy might be called upon at any time to defend the country and the principles for which it stands.
HOLLYWOOD, May 1 (AP).--Frank E. Woods, one of the pioneers of the motion-picture industry, died today at his home after an illness of two months. He was 79 years old.

BERLIN, May 1.--In May Day speeches today Chancellor Adolf Hitler assailed the boycott of German goods in the United States, appealed to labor for national unity and increased production and denounced the "warmongers and panic-makers" of the democracies.

Operating costs at the completed low-cost housing projects erected by the New York City Housing Authority under the Wagner-Steagall act, thus far have been considerably lower than was originally figured, Frederick L. Ackerman, technical director of the Authority, declared yesterday.
IT seems that April is not Joe DiMaggio's lucky month. But generally he's healthy and happy and a big help to the Yankees through June, July, August, September and the early part of October.

Even though the amusement and foreign sections of the Fair will not be in full operation for some time a tour of the great corporate and public buildings yesterday showed the scientific exhibits on which industry depends to shape the "World of Tomorrow" are in thoroughgoing operation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1.-- Derbytown perked up its ears tonight as the vanguard of the annual crowd heading for this racing capital to see the sixty-fifth Kentucky classic began to pour in from all sides.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 1.--May Day here was marked by a parade through the central section of the capital of nearly 50,000 workers, members of political parties and supporters of the Popular Front government.
The fees and expenses entailed in the reorganization of railroads have provided a not too bright aspect of railroad history in the past.

BALTIMORE, May 1 (AP).--Mrs. Anthony Pelleteri's Old Rosebush, a star of last Winter's racing at New Orleans, picked the $2,500added Baltimore Spring Handicap as the spot to collect his first purse of the Maryland season. The 5-yearold son of Infinite stepped six furlongs over a good track in 1:13 1-5 to leave Sun Egret, Rough Time ...
The most sweeping order ever issued by the Police Department in its efforts to curb permanent parking was announced yesterday by Commissioner Valentine.
Within an hour yesterday Oscar of the Waldorf qualified as a diplomat of sorts as well as a famous chef, establishing something of a local precedent in international amity and good-will.

Four Long Island properties were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Queens County Savings Bank. Ernest G. Ihnken purchased the dwelling at 148-18 Laburnum Avenue, Flushing; Hyman Gershuny bought the two-story dwelling at 104-27 Forty-ninth Avenue, Corona, ...

Price reductions ranging from $100 to $300 were announced yesterday by the Packard Motor Company in Detroit which thus bids for a larger share of the popular-priced automobile field.

On the opening day of the World's Fair 278,000 persons used the subway, elevated, railroad, trolley and bus facilities that serve the Fair, according to compilations made from figures obtained yesterday from the New York State Transit Commission. The Transit Commission received reports from all public carriers in New York City except the taxicabs.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 1.-- Lost on Long Island Sound after its departure last midnight from a pier at the World's Fair Grounds, a 35-foot cabin cruiser being used in ferry service between this village and the Fair circled back and forth on the wind-swept water until 6 A.M. today when the pilot found his bearings and manoeuvred his craft into the harbor here. Ten passengers were aboard.

George Washington's inauguration as first President of the United States was commemorated with exercises at the Sub-Treasury Building in Wall Street again yesterday, this time in the midst of a noonday throng that contrasted with the quietness of the financial district during the ceremonies Sunday.

The visible supply of raw silk has sunk to the lowest level since records have been kept in the present form, according to importers here yesterday, and stocks at warehouses here, as reported by the Commodity Exchange, Inc., for May 1 are the lowest since April, 1922, at 20,738 bales.
The World's Fair will bring a gradual climb in retail trade here, with main-floor departments likely to prove the most sensitive in reflecting the early gains, store executives said yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, May 1.-- Ten thousand persons participated in colorful mass gatherings and parades tonight to mark the first of a series of scheduled monthly meetings of the citizenry in connection with the National Spiritual Mobilization Movement.

Lack of night illumination and of electrical power for several of the big "rides" made the World's Fair amusement area--open, though not to be officially dedicated until May 13--a quiet place yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, May 1.--Edward L. Schneider, associate of and key witness against Thomas J. Pendergast, indicted local political boss, vanished today, leaving suicide notes behind him, a few hours after Pendergast had been arraigned in Federal court on a second income tax indictment.

The second royal couple to visit the World's Fair within two days of its opening, Crown Prince Frederik and Crown Princess Ingrid of Denmark, will formally open the Danish Pavilion in the Hall of Nations this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock. They will go to the pavilion for the ceremony from the Terrace Club, where Grower A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, will give a luncheon in their honor.

Section 2 of the Neutrality Act expired yesterday, and its expiration leaves us in a strange position. It was this section that gave the President discretionary power to apply the "cashand-carry" plan in time of war: that is, to forbid the export of war materials unless they were paid for in cash and carried in a foreign vessel. That discretionary power has now ceased to exist. But there still remains on the ...

The gigantic police organization arrangements for the World's Fair, which placed all of the 18,000 members of the Police Department on emergency duty, was discarded late last night and at midnight tonight the force will return to its normal schedule.
The report of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $27,175,079.

Although gulls have long been recognized as friends by the saltwater fishing fraternity, freshwater anglers have accused the birds of a variety of crimes, ranging from theft of game fish to the transmission of parasites to bass and trout.

LONDON, May 1.--The permanent policy the British will impose on Palestine was discussed at this morning's Cabinet meeting, but no decision was taken. However, it is expected announcement of the new policy will be made soon.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 1.-- The Long Island Professional Golf Association inaugurated its 1939 season today when twenty-four amateur-pro combinations turned out for the initial one-day event on the Garden City Country Club course.

A steadily diminishing supply of free cotton exerted yesterday a strengthening influence on old crop deliveries on all three domestic cotton exchanges and July contracts here touched 8 cents a pound, the highest price since November.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--The first attempt of Congress to commit the United States to the "cash and carry" principle in commerce with belligerents in time of general war passed into the scrap heap today with no effort made to save it. Midnight tonight is the hour when Section 2 of the Neutrality Act expires, but both houses of Congress adjourned much earlier today without even considering extension of the law.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP).-- Johnny Rizzo's bat and effective pitching by Truett (Ripper) Sewell snapped Pittsburgh's eight-game losing streak today as the Pirates beat the Reds, 2 to 1. The defeat dropped Cincinnati from first to second place, a game behind the Bees.

The annual award of the prizes in letters and journalism established under the will of Joseph Pulitzer was announced yesterday after noon by the trustees of Columbia University after they had acted on the recommendations of the advisory board of the Graduate School of Journalism.

With the television industry's public appearance in the country only two days old, inquiry at various metropolitan radio and department stores yesterday disclosed a "surprising interest" on the part of the public to inspect the sight and sound receivers. Those who visited the showrooms to see the magic of pictures through the air were said to be impressed by the clarity and definition of the reproduced images.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 1.--Dan Galgano and his amateur partner, Ray O'Brien of the Green Meadow Country Club, won the opening oneday pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. today by scoring a seven-under-par 64 at the Dunwoodie Country Club.
WASHINGTON, May 1.--A bill to grant Federal aid to eliminate pollution from inland waters of the United States was passed by the Senate today without a roll-call.
Jimmy Jones, 160, Baltimore, earned the decision over Mohamed Fahmy, 159 , Egypt, last night in the main attraction of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 2,500 persons.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP).--With only one dissenting vote, the House approved today a bill to increase or start paying pensions and benefits to nearly 90,000 World War veterans and 50,000 widows, orphans and dependent parents. The vote was 359 to 1.

The joint subcommittee of softcoal miners and operators resumed negotiations yesterday in a renewed effort to break the deadlock that has kept the industry idle for more than a month.

The long controversy between the trustees of the Alleghany Corporation bond issues and the management of the railroad holding company over the disposition of the free cash held behind these issues as collateral probably will reach the courts today or tomorrow, it was indicated last night.

KANSAS CITY, May 1.--After more than an hour of discussion, the 900 delegates to the Methodist Uniting Conference today voted to open the first General Conference of the new church, with its almost 8,000,000 members, on the last Wednesday of April, 1940, in a city yet to be named.

Poland regards Germany's demands for sovereignty over Danzig and a German route across the Polish Corridor to East Prussia as inspired by a desire to rob Poland of her economic and political independence and she will never yield to them, Count Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to Washington, said yesterday in a formal statement.

A nation-wide advertising campaign to acquaint the public with the $100 to $300 price reductions in Packard motor cars will break today in newspapers and later in magazines, according to Young Rubicam, Inc., which handles Packard advertising.

BERLIN, May 1.--In conjunction with the presentation today of "German National Prizes" for literature and cinematic arts Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels made a violent attack on "democratic culture."

Ernest E. Norris, president of the Southern Railway, received $50,658 from the system in 1938, a company statement to the Securities Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday. H.A. DeButts, vice president, received $25,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2.--Technician, the main hope of the West to stop the East's Johnstown in the Kentucky Derby, was defeated in the Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs today by Viscounty, who now looms as a dark horse for the $50,000 added mile and a quarter test on Saturday.

In an attempt to unseat the present leaders of the New York College Teachers Union, eleven educators, headed by Professor George S. Counts of Teachers College, Columbia University, announced yesterday the formation of their independent slate and their statement of policy calling for union reforms.

MIAMI, Fla., May 2 (AP).--Negroes ignored warnings issued during a spectacular demonstration by paraders in Ku Klux Klan regalia and cast a record vote today in a city primary election. The total was estimated at 1,000.

BURGOS, Spain, May 2.--Although the victory march scheduled here today was cancelled, a big peace parade may be reviewed by Generalissimo Francisco Franco at Valencia this week, possibly tomorrow.

ALBANY, May 2.--The Republican-controlled Senate voted today, 36 to 11, to confirm Miss Frieda Miller as Industrial Commissioner. The snarl over the administration of unemployment insurance was further cleared when the official Republican program for revising the law became known.

DETROIT, May 2.--Life insurance at low cost will soon be available for all Ford Motor Company employes who have worked more than two years for the company, it was announced today. ALBANY, May 2.--The Senate passed today with little opposition the Nunan bill extending the moratorium on mortgage foreclosures until July 1, 1940. The present law expires on Jan. 1, so the effect is to defer decision on a "tapering-off" program until the next session of the Legislature.

The vacant plot 213 by 136 feet on the southeast corner of Hering and Lydig Avenues, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Clearview Homes, Inc., Philip Rosen, president, and will be improved with eight one-family homes, Joseph Howard Katz, attorney for the purchasers, announced yesterday.
The Brodhead is normal, the flies are hatching, and Analomink Charley is smiling from ear to ear, according to Jim Deren, who just returned from some fishing in Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 2.--President Roosevelt indicated today that his Administration would remain officially neutral on proposals of Congressional and Treasury spokesmen for elimination of levies called "business deterrents."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2.-- Twelve, newspaper men, chosen from 209 applicants in thirty-nine States, have received awards of Nieman Fellowships for study at Harvard University during the next academic year.

An experimental camp program for 110 New York City public school children will be undertaken this Summer, Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the Board of Education's instructional affairs committee, announced yesterday.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 2.--District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York declared tonight in an address accepting the Newman Award for 1938 from the Newman Foundation, University of Illinois, that the extermination of organized crime was gradually progressing from city to city.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2.--Francis Chapman, dean of the Temple Universtiy Law School for the last thirty-two years, lawyer and author, died in Jefferson Hospital today, after a long illness, in his seventieth year.

Receipts of foreign gold here yesterday amounted to $27,106,000, according to the daily statement of the Federal Reserve Bank, which now includes all foreign central bank and Stabilization Fund transactions as well as commercial shipments. The enlisted men of the Atlantic Squadron were entertained at a ball by the Mayor's Naval Committee at the Hotel Astor last night. This was the largest function arranged so far by the committee, with an attendance estimated around 5,000.

Leaders of athletics on both sides of the Atlantic joined with the Sportsmanship Brotherhood yesterday in doing honor to John Francis (Jack) Moakley, track coach at Cornell University for the past forty years and former coach of the American Olympic team.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,568,200 barrels, compared with 3,526,700 in the previous week, an increase of 41,500, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Accounting for ten hits and drawing fifteen passes, the St. John's University team captured a onesided game from Manhattan at the latter's diamond yesterday, 16--2.
It might be expected that in retiring from Hunter College Dr. Blanche Colton Williams was planning to write a book. But this turns out to be not quite true. She has in view not one book but a dozen.

An appeal to youth to labor first for the sanctities of life in building the world of tomorrow was made yesterday by the Rev. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church, in an address dedicating the Y.M. C.A. Building at the World's Fair.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2.--Rudolph Blaschka, German artist in glass, maker for more than fifty years of the glass flowers of the Harvard University Museum, died yesterday at his home in Hosterwitz, Germany, at the age of 82, acccording to word received at the university late today.

LOS ANGELES, May 2.--George Palmer Putnam, publisher and husband of the late Amelia Earhart, the flier, will wed Mrs. Jean-Marie Consigny James of Beverly Hills some time after next May 18, it became known today.

A vigorous defense of advertising and a plea to sales executives to begin an aggressive campaign against its detractors marked the luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

A survey of food prices at the World's Fair indicates that, while a few of the concessionaires have maintained the level of their intown restaurants, or only slightly exceeded it, others have prepared menus that make eating at the Fair expensive.

Two more auditors for the State Insurance Fund were arrested yesterday on charges of taking bribes to help employers cheat on workmen's compensation insurance and five Brooklyn employers were seized on accusations that they had defrauded the fund.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it had won an important National Labor Relations Board decision affecting its relations with three tanker operating companies, none of which is involved in the present tanker strike.

Ridgewood, one of the oldest sections of Queens, and the "gateway" to that borough, as one official described it--was honored on the Queens Calendar of Events yesterday at the Fair. It was Ridgewood Day.

In a militant attempt to eliminate fouling as much as possible, the National Basketball Committee of the United States and Canada yesterday put sharper teeth into the penalties on fouls at its annual rules meeting at the Hotel McAlpin. The new and altered code will go into effect for the 1939-40 season.

In line with the spirit of the day, the People's Chorus of New York dedicated its twenty-third anniversary concert, given last night at Carnegie Hall, to the World of Tomorrow. As usual at these concerts, a large audience was present.

The engagement of Miss Anne Vivian Stobie, daughter of Mrs. Harold R. Stobie of Pelham Manor and the late Major Stobie of Edinburgh, Scotland, to Ewing Pope Shahan has been announced by her mother.

An early advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried old crop contracts into new high ground for the movement when a combination of hedging and foreign selling orders left the list 7 points lower to 7 points higher.

DETROIT, May 2.--Lou Gehrig's matchless record of uninterrupted play in American League championship games, stretched over fifteen years and through 2,130 straight contests, came to an end today.

ROME, May 5.--The Italian air force is now independent of America and the rest of the world for fuel, General Giuseppe Valle, Under-Secretary for Aviation, told the Chamber of Fasces and Corporations today in a talk that was singularly frank about Italy's part in the Spanish war.
The Giants, it seems, are still bent on trying to win ball games the hard way, but yesterday they overreached themselves at the Polo Grounds.

The Polish Government has made a straightforward reply to the question put to it a week ago by Hitler in his Reichstag speech. It will discuss with the German Government any problems whose solution would improve relations between the two countries, but it will not yield to an ultimatum and it will not enter into any negotiations except on a basis of equality.

LONDON, May 5.--The Foreign Affairs subcommittee of the Cabinet met today to consider the Russian proposal for a military alliance. French comments on the plan have been received and the British reply will be forwarded to Moscow tonight or tomorrow.

PARIS, May 5.--In a hearing before the Chamber of Deputies Finance Committee, Finance Minister Paul Reynaud stated today that the Treasury had enough money to carry on until the end of this year, barring war.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--The Wagner-Rogers bill to authorize the admission of 20,000 German refugee children into the United States in the next two years was reported favorably today by a joint immigration committee of the House and Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--President George F. Zook of the American Council of Education said today that it was time to get quicker and more effective consideration of the findings and conclusions of important educational studies and researches.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--The Hobbs bill providing for the detention of criminal aliens who had been ordered deported but whose native countries refuse to admit them was passed by the House today, 286 to 61, after a debate in which the measure was criticized as a thinly disguised attempt to establish concentration camps.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--Supply contracts valued at $5,385,859 were awarded during the week ended April 29 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Wagner's "Das Rheingold" will be presented tonight at 8:30 o'clock at the Metropolitan Opera House as the third opera of the World's Fair season, with Mmes. Thorborg, Burke, Doe, Browning and Votipka, and Althouse, Schorr, List, Laufkoetter, Gabor, Beattie, Witte and Wolfe. Artur Bodanzky conducts.

More than 400 delegates to the convention of the New City Federation of Women's Clubs, representing 236 separate organizations, voted unanimously yesterday for an increase in the number of policewomen in this city and also for their promotion to high rank and salaries.

The New York State Bar Association announced yesterday the appointment of a committee, headed by Ignatius M. Wilkinson, to study the present system of reporting decisions of the courts and the publication of laws annually passed by the State Legislature.

The photographers who have been puttering around Little Siberia, as the Amusement Zone has come to be called, are not the usual candid camera addicts. They were hired by Midway concessionaires to take shots of craters in Midway streets, of mud conditions after rains and of the dark that engulfs the concessions after nightfall.

Two separate investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the affairs of the Breeze Corporations, Inc., maker of airplane parts, are nearing completion, it was learned yesterday. Moreover, the company and five individual defendants named with it in an action in the New Jersey...

WASHINGTON, May 5.--Department store sales were 6 per cent higher in the week ended April 29 than for the corresponding week a year ago and 1 per cent higher for the four-week period ended April 29 than for the same period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

KANSAS CITY, May 5.--The body of Edward L. Schneider, 46-year-old business associate of T.J. Pendergast, the Kansas City political boss, and a key witness for the government in the investigation of Mr. Pendergast's affairs, was taken from the Missouri River this morning about thirteen miles down

ROME, May 5.--The Italians tonight do not feel that Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, has completely closed the doors to agreement with Germany and so Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, will leave for his talks with Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, in a moderately hopeful frame of mind.

ROME, May 5.--Today's annual report of the Institution for Industrial Reconstruction, commonly called "IRE," through which the State controls 25 per cent of all Italian industry, shows a profit for 1938 amounting to 21,000,000 lire.

NEWARK, N.J., May 5.--Lord Britain, upstanding and attractive thoroughbred, virtually clinched the title in the hunter group of the nineteenth annual Newark Horse Show when he won the hunter stake tonight. He triumphed in the closest competition of that division in the three nights thus far of the exhibition.

The first flight in the air-mail service to be operated across the Atlantic by Pan American Airways, Inc., is expected to take place from New York via Horta in the Azores and Lisbon, Portugal, to Marseilles, France, it was announced yesterday by Postmaster General Farley.
WASHINGTON, May 5.--The speech of Colonel Josef Beck, the Polish Foreign Minister, is considered here to be excellent, both in substance and from the tactical diplomatic standpoint.

A call on Rumanians to play their historic role in Europe and "resist tha barbarians" was made yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at the official opening of the Rumanian Pavilion and the "Rumanian House" at the World's Fair.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP).--Steeplechasers held the spotlight at Pimlico today with the twenty-seventh running of the Green Spring Valley Handicap and it was Gordon F. Perry's Wilfrid G. who finished on the front end by two and a half lengths.

MOSCOW, May 5.--A session of the supreme Soviet--bicameral body outwardly resembling the United States Congress and theoretically the highest political authority in the Soviet Union--was called today by its Presidium, of which President Mikhail Kalinin is chairman. The session will open in the Kremlin Great Palace May 25.

Following the fractional gains recorded for total advertising in March, April ad volume was generally estimated yesterday as having extended this increase, with all media registering rises over the like month of 1938, for the first time this year.

CLEVELAND, May 5 (AP).--Cleveland's 58-day reign as ten-pin capital of the world ended tonight with a Detroit team, two Chicagoans and a Steubenville, Ohio, pair holding the principal championships of the American Bowling Congress.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 5.-- The New Jersey Women's Golf Association's second one-day tournament was held on the Essex County Country Club's east course today. The weather was perfect and ninety-two started, with Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring carrying off low gross honors for her card of 43--40-83.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, May 6.-- If Japan has decided not to enter a military agreement with Germany and Italy against the democracies but only to agree to join against Russia, it will mean a considerable amelioration of the plight of American, British and French interests in China, diplomatic observers here believe.

CLEVELAND, May 5.--The Yankees' triumphant march through the West was checked today at League Park after three straight conquests when a double by Hal Trosky drove Pitcher Al Milnar home with the run that gave the Indians a victory over the world champions, 2 to 1, in eleven innings of stirring play.

The Cunard White Star liner Britannic sails today for England and France. Among her passengers are: Countess Margaret Pecorini, Mrs. James E. Brown Jr., Fleming H. Revell, Charles F. Noyes, Miss Anita de la Vega, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edwards, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Spencer and Miss Rosalind Benson.

The 150th anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as first President of the United States will be commemorated by a solemn high mass at noon Wednesday in St. Peter's a Roman Catholic Church, Barclay and Church Streets.
BERLIN, Saturday, May 6.--The rift in German-Polish relations appeared to have widened this morning following Polish Foreign Minister Josef Beck's speech in the Sejm yesterday.

Joseph Hiestand, the Hillsboro, Ohio, farmer who is one of the nation's leading clay target shooters, won the amateur doubles championship as the thirty-fourth national trapshooting tournament got under way yesterday at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $4,612,217 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. WASHINGTON, May 5.--The Commerce Department announced today that it has started a program of discussions, looking to better trade relationships, with various foreign business groups who are now in this country or expected in the next two weeks to visit the New York World's Fair.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP).-- The Pirates chalked up their fourth straight victory today, but it took their veteran relief pitcher, Mace Brown, to quell a ninth-inning rally by the Phillies and save the game. The score was 10 to 7.

A group of thirty-two leaders in the American world of sport, in a joint statement yesterday, started a national campaign for "moral rearmament," which begins tomorrow with "MRA Week" in New York City.

Alarmed over the threatened "dismantling" of the New York City school system, parents' groups began yesterday a concerted campaign for restoration to the State budget of the $9,710,000 for education that recently was slashed from it. A series of mass meetings, demonstrations, conferences, radio talks and trips to Albany are being mapped.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--Amid scenes of unusual military pageantry, General Anastasio Somoza, President of Nicaragua, was welcomed to the United States today in a manner similar to the greetings given to President Roosevelt on his visits to Latin-American republics.
It is very apparent that many anglers are confusing the word "sport" with "sportsmanship" these days, and this fact was brought out very clearly at a recent luncheon of anglers we attended.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--A bill to compel the purchase of United States bonds, in time of war or emergency serious enough to call for drafting of men into the military service, on a sliding scale graduated according to "net wealth," was reported to the Senate today without a dissenting vote by its Military Affairs Committee.

The possibility of transforming the lower East Side from a slum area into an attractive residential section was described by Guy E. Greer, Director of Finance, Rental Housing Division, Federal Housing Administration, at the sixth annual luncheon meeting yesterday of the Mortgage Conference of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

The stoppage of work in the soft coal industry, which has now brought a curtailment of rapid transit service in this city and a paralysis of industrial activity over a wide area, is the product of a disagrement between management and trade union leadership solely on one point.

A squad of the Treasury's customs guards, usually alert for the kind of smuggler who skulks around pier sheds or hides narcotics in a deep cranny of a ship, held their noses and seized the bridle of the horse hauling the garbage cart of William Maxwell of 530 West Forty-sixth Street yesterday morning.

Four suggestions to get parked cars off the street, revolutionary alongside former plans to solve the city's traffic problem, were made yesterday by civic association leaders at a conference to organize recommendations for submission next Friday at a hearing of the City Council traffic committee.

NORFOLK, Conn., May 5.--Mrs. Ellen Battell Stoeckel, who, with her husband, Carl Stoeckel, who died in 1925, was widely known as a patron of music and founder of the Norfolk Annual Music Festival, died here late tonight at her home, Whitehouse, after a long illness. She was 88 years old.

United States Government securities rose yesterday to new high levels, while the remainder of the listed bond market settled back slightly in light trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Transactions in all bonds on the Exchange declined to $4,915,125 from $5,259,000 on Thursday.

MOUNT LOCKE, Texas, May 5. --The McDonald Observatory with its eighty-two-inch reflecting telescope, the second largest in the world, was dedicated here today as a new "Olympian station" from which to explore the mysteries of the universe.

Professor Ladislas Kun, Hungarian composer and conductor, who had conducted the National State Symphony Orchestra of Budapest at the court of the late Emperor Franz Josef, died on Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a year's illness. Professor Kun, who lived at 801 West End Avenue, was 65 years old.

LONDON, May 6.--The British people are making a state occasion and holiday of the departure of the King and Queen tomorrow for the first visit of a reigning Sovereign to a Dominion and the United States.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $17,069,483, to be represented by forty-six municipalities, compared with $43,812,190 for this week, the latter figure including the $35,700,000 New York City offering. WASHINGTON, May 5.--The Ways and Means Committee completed action today on amendments to the Social Security Act which may effect payroll tax savings of $200,000,000 or $300,000,000 a year, and every indication pointed to House action week after next.

ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP).--Manager Connie Mack returned Sam Chapman to the line-up today and the young center fielder responded by hitting a single, double, triple and home run to lead the Athletics to a 10-to-5 victory over the Browns.

ALBANY, May 5.--The Saratoga Credit Corporation, 142 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, has notified the State Banking Department of its intention to change its place of conducting a licensed lender business to 2,059 Fulton Street after May 26, the department bulletin announced today.

With a salary of $100,000, M.W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was the highestpaid railroad executive in the East in 1938, the company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. J.F. Deasy, vice president of operation, received $55,000.

John Frazier Vance of 360 East Fifty-fifth Street, editor and publisher of the Upper Income Group of New York Hotel magazines and vice president of R.L. Johnson, Inc., died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital of complications following an appendectomy. He was 38 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--Without explanation the Navy Department canceled today the cruise of the midshipmen's practice squadron to European waters. It is known, however, that the reason for the cancellation was the European situation.

The State of New Hampshire will be in the market on Wednesday with $2,000,000 of permanent highway bonds bearing interest at the rate of 1 1/8 per cent. The issue will mature serially in one to ten years.

Amano, head of several important business enterprises in Latin America, here to find a way for Japan to sell without buying.

CHUNGKING, China, May 7.-- Chungking is still removing bodies from the buildings destroyed in the Japanese air raids Wednesday and Thursday. Estimates of the dead range from 3,000 to 10,000.

PARIS, May 7 (AP).--Informed sources said today that the Duke of Windsor's broadcast tomorrow night from Verdun, in the heart of the World War battlefields, would be "an appeal to reason in the light of world conditions."

Another veteran competitor gained a place among the champions yesterday, when 52-year-old John D. Rigg of Conshohocken, Pa., captured the national amateur distance handicap trapshooting title at the New York A.C. range on Travers Island.

VIENNA, May 7 (AP),--Germany, the favorite to win the European zone Davis Cup competition this year, easily passed the first barrier today, winning the doubles match from Switzerland and clinching the first-round series, three matches to none.

Asleep while his mattress was afire, John Szarbalo, 45 years old, died of suffocation and burns at 5 o'clock yesterday morning in the bedroom of his three-room apartment on the second floor at 527 East Thirteenth Street. Firemen, summoned by neighbors who smelled smoke, confined the blaze to the apartment. Szarbalo was believed to have fallen asleep while smoking a cigarette.

PARIS, May 7,--The Bourse here again lacked animation last week. On Monday quotations were lower but on Tuesday there developed a recovery ascribed to a batch of unconfirmed rumors. On the two following days prices weakened, but by Friday there was a slight hardening.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 12.--Miss Sheila Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Potter, was married to Sheldon Ellsworth Prentice, son of Bernon S. Prentice of New York and Holmdel, N.J., and the late Mrs. Clare Ellsworth Prentice, this afternoon in the garden of the Potter estate here.

C.E. Denney, president and trustee in bankruptcy of the Erie Railroad, had his salary reduced from $57,500 annually to $30,000 annually on May 8, 1938, the report of the company to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday. The salaries of R.E. Woodruff and D.L. Gray, vice presidents, were reduced from $27,000 to $21,600 on July 1.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 12.--The news of the conclusion of an AngloTurkish agreement, to be followed by a similar arrangement between Turkey and France--coming on the...

ALBANY, May 12.--The battle over the constitutionality of the budget adopted by the Republican Legislature began today, as Governor Lehman allowed the budget to become law without his signature as a means of obtaining a court test, while the Republicans named...

The State and municipal financing scheduled for next week aggregates $11,605,607, to be represented by fifty-seven municipalities, compared with $23,676,972 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date stands at $20,507,240.

WASHINGTON, May 12, --The Federal Trade Commission announced today that Procter Gamble Company of Cincinnati has entered into a stipulation to cease advertising that its Camay soap will keep the skin young, that no other soap can compare with Camay for cleaning the skin ...
ROME, May 12.--The way for Premier Mussolini's speech at Turin Sunday is being prepared by violent press attacks against France.

MINEOLA, L.I., Saturday, May 13.--Vernon E. Oldaker, 42-yearold handyman, was found guilty of second-degree murder by a jury in Nassau County Court this morning for the hammer slaying of Miss Anna Louise McKee, 57, of 15 Roslyn Road here last March 6.

GENEVA, May 12.--All members of the Council of the League of Nations agreed to Russia's request to postpone for one week the opening of the 105th Council session. Now it is scheduled to commence at noon, May 22.

Some of the 3-year-olds who did not quite make the grade for the Derby and Preakness will have a trial of their own today in the Swift Stakes, which will feature the first week-end card at Belmont Park. This and the Fashion Stakes for 2-year-old fillies will be the main attractions for a crowd that probably will exceed that of opening day.

Two residential parcels and a business building in downtown Manhattan were sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank in three separate deals reported yesterday. One of the properties covers an entire blockfront on the lower East Side.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 12 (AP). --Mrs. Emil Denemark's Swahili scored his second consecutive Narragansett triumph today when he took the Concord Purse, a mile and 70 yards, by two lengths from Mrs. P. A. Shaw's Holluschickie.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--Optimism as to the prospects of railroad relief legislation at this session of Congress was expressed by President Roosevelt today at a press conference, coincident with action by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee in reporting favorably a detailed bill to establish a "bankruptcy court" for railroads.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--Secretary Hopkins plans to ask Congress soon for money to enable the National Bureau of Standards to set up commodity performance standards to guide consumers, a witness told the Temporary National Economic Committee today.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--The official visit to Brazil of General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the army, who is on the way to Rio de Janeiro, was said by Secretary Hull today to be one of courtesy and not to presage a military alliance.
Mother's Day will be celebrated tomorrow in Protestant and Catholic churches and it will be celebrated today in Jewish synagogues. In some churches flowers will be given to the oldest mother present.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Hofstadter approved yesterday a referee's report holding that the theatre ticket code, promulgated by the League of New York Theatres, was legal. He declared that the limitation on brokerage fees imposed by the code was an effort at self-restraint that should be encouraged by the law.

Spring, belated and coming at last with a rush, seems to have compensations this year in the area of metropolitan New York, by bringing us an exceptionally large bird population. In one outdoor living room not twenty miles from Times Square more than a score of species were observed in an hour before twilight the other day.

One mile out from the little college town of Wooster, Ohio, there lives a woman of 80 who drives her own car to her appointments with church and Sunday School folk, missionary organizations and the local civic improvement groups.

For the thirty-fifth consecutive year, Daniel Frohman was elected president of the Actors Fund of America yesterday at the annual meeting of the fund at the National Theatre. The session was enlivened by the reading of the treasurer's report in the best Robert Benchley manner.

After the discovery that one of the German-American Bund members under investigation by the city already had sailed quietly for Germany, Mayor La Guardia telegraphed yesterday to Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, asking him to withhold approval of the passport...

Mr. Lewis has won a substantial victory for the C.I.O. in the terms of the coal agreement which were accepted by negotiators for both sides yesterday. The agreement will provide that as a condition of employment in the bituminous coal fields of the Appalachian area "all employes ...

A flat prediction that unless there "is a war overshadowing all our domestic issues, the result of the 1940 election is already determined," was made last night by Representative Bruce Barton, in an address before a banquet of the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Many business firms and employe groups that did not take part in last year's appeal of the Greater New York Fund for supplementary donations for 380 voluntary health and welfare services are sending in contributions this year, Paul Felix Warburg, vice chairman of the 1939 campaign, reported yesterday.

Blithe as school children on vacation, members of Congress and their families scattered through the grounds of the World's Fair yesterday for as energetic a day of sightseeing as any single group has yet experienced.

At the direct order of Police Commissioner Valentine, First Grade Detective Francis J. (Red) Crimmins of the East Fifty-first Street station was ousted yesterday from the detective bureau and returned to uniformed duty in the West 123d Street station.

CHICAGO, May 12.--Prices of wheat held within relatively narrow limits today and fluctuated in an erratic manner. The volume of business was well below that of yesterday. Scattered reports of showers early had a depressing effect for a short time, but the offerings were ...
In the House of Commons yesterday Prime Minister Chamberlain announced the important addition of Turkey to the antiaggression front that Britain is forming.

VIENNA, May 12.--Baron Louis Rothschild, a prisoner of the Gestapo [secret police] in Vienna since April, 1938, was released this morning and left by plane for Zurich, Switzerland, early this afternoon.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 12.-- The estate of Mrs. Ernest H. Wilkes at Indian Harbor, made an ideal setting for the fourth annual flower show of the Green Fingers Club this afternoon. Greenwich society attended in large numbers.

Advances in the type of hospital service from the present curative stage into a "protective health service" were predicted yesterday by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, at the annual meeting of the women's committees of that organization in the Hotel Biltmore.

WARSAW, Poland, May 12.-The Polish capital, mourning Marshal Josef Pilsudski on the fourth anniversary of his death, learned today that the Danzig Senate had prohibited a Pilsudski ceremony in the Free City.

Only the opposition of a group of Southern soft coal operators stood last night between John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers and the achievement of its demand for a "union shop" agreement covering 320,000 miners in the Appalachian district.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 12. --The Green Meadow women's golf team, playing over the beautiful Quaker Ridge course, today became the new champion in the Westchester Division of the Women's Metropolitan Class A interclub tournament, shutting out Fairview and Bedford to add 10 points to its previous tally of 15 for a grand total of 25 points.

Mayor La Guardia brought a new weapon into play yesterday against Frank A. Erickson, bookmaker, when he placed the gambler's finances under scrutiny by the investigating agents of the Federal and State income tax units.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--Now that the bituminous coat situation has been adjusted, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor is awaiting a call from the Congress of Industrial Organizations for resumption of the peace parleys which broke up without result on April 4.

While nearly 500 persons watched, Ella Gulbrandsen, a 17-year-old skijumper, who came from Norway for exhibitions at the Sun Valley exhibit in the World's Fair, suffered a leg injury yesterday in trying to avoid crashing into a backstop at the bottom of the jump.

LONDON, May 12.--Sir Louis Sterling, 60-year-old Americanborn gramophone and radio pioneer, has resigned the managing directorship of Electrical and Musical Industries, Ltd.--a concern with a capital of 3,000,000--owing to a divergence of views on the company's internal policy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11.-- Ninety Yale juniors, including twenty-one from New York City, were elected today to the senior societies in the traditional Tap Day exercises held in Branford College Court.

MADRID, May 12.--Generalissimo Francisco Franco today predicted an immense air force for Spain, as he reviewed his aviation forces and gave decorations to the Germans and Italians who had been conspicuous in his flying services.
Albany, May 12.--A bill returning to localities control of the administration of home relief was introduced in the Assembly today by Irving M. Ives, Republican majority leader.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, made it known today in Washington that if Philadelphia officials requested it, they might have the aid of the technical facilities and personnel of the bureau in pursuing the investigation of the arsenic murder conspiracy.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 12. --With the publication today of the text of the Anglo-Rumanian trade agreement a more optimistic view is taken toward it in Rumanian circles, although disappointment is still expressed at the meagerness of the credit that Britain was willing to grant.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 12. --Four New York City youths, the oldest 19, were arrested on charges of robbery and possession of pistols when their automobile, which had been stolen, crashed into a bridge on the Bronx River Parkway early this morning after a three-mile ...

NEWARK, N.J., May 12.--Essex County Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld today requested County Judge Daniel J. Brennan to instruct the grand jury to take notice of a statement by City Commissioner Joseph H. Byrne Jr. in which he called for a municipal clean-up and wanted to know if there was an "invisible government" in control of Newark.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--The Yankees will resume their steamroller campaign through the American League tomorrow when they open a three-game series with Connie Mack's Athletics. They will return to the Stadium on Tuesday for the beginning of their first long home stand of the season.
It would be unfair as well as a waste of time to criticize companies for switching their securities from the New York Curb Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange.

Too much taxation and regulation by both Federal and State agencies were blamed yesterday for the stagnation of capital and commerce by Henry R. Kinsey, retiring president of the National Association of mutual Savings Banks, in an address at the World's Fair at the conclusion of the association's three-day conference.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 12.--A grand field made brilliant competition today in the $1,000 Hunter Stake, one of the many striking events of the second day of the annual Wilmington Horse Show, and Kingvulture continued to make good his challenge for the hunter championship of this outstanding exhibition by annexing the test.

A formal dinner to prominent Belgians and Americans, with former President Herbert Hoover among the guests of honor, was given last night in the restaurant of the Belgian Pavilion at the World's Fair by Dr. Joseph L. Gevaert, Commissioner General for Belgium.

PARIS, May 12.-Unanimous yesterday in support of Premier Edouard Daladier's prepardness policy for the defence of democracy and national independence, the Chamber of Deputies was yet divided today, 375 to 230, on how that policy could best be financially sustained.
WASHINGTON, May 12.--Reorganization of the Coast Artillery Corps units stationed within the continental limits of the United States was announced today by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--In an announcement that took naval circles by surprise, President Roosevelt said today that he would soon send to the Senate the nomination of Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, to be Governor of Puerto Rico, succeeding Governor Blanton Winship.

PRAGUE, May 12.--Hitler Elite Guards, swooping down on the police station at Brno this morning, seized twenty-one Czech policemen, some of whom tried to commit suicide. An armed guard was placed over the station.

Billy Conn, Pittsburgh's sharpshooting light-heavyweight, turned in a masterpiece of boxing in defeating Solly Krieger of Brownsville in the feature bout of twelve rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

Being restless at the moment, Guthrie McClintic, who staged Maxwell Anderson's "Saturday's Children" for the Actor's Theatre in 1927, is considering a revival of the play with Ruth Gordon in her original role and Burgess Meredith in the cast. This would arrive when the Empire is available.

Mrs. Skinker Matthews of New York and St. Louis gave a luncheon yesterday on the St. Regis Roof for Lady Decies. Other guests included Prince and Princess Irbain Khan Kaplanoff, Prince and Princess Vladimir Koudacheff, Mrs. Pierre C. Cartier, Mrs. Robert Morris ...

Backstage at Town Hall yesterday afternoon a dark-eyed young Brooklyn housewife nervously gulped water while six other girls, all unmarried, preceded her in the finals of the World's Fair young soprano contest arranged by the New York State Federation of Music Clubs.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--Supply contracts valued at $6,801,607 were awarded during the week ended May 6 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--President Roosevelt placed responsibility for any business-encouraging tax revisions squarely on Congress today. Specifically, he declared that he would have no objection to repeal...

TORONTO, May 12 (AP).--Backed by Mike Meola's four-hit pitching, the Maple Leafs today snapped a three-game losing streak with their first home victory of the International League season, a 10-4 decision over Newark.

SHANGHAI, May 12.--The landing of Japanese marines at Kulangsu, their declaration of martial law and their patrolling of the streets today put Japan in full possession of a small island in Amoy harbor, which hitherto ranked as an international concession almost like that at Shanghai, 600 miles north.

Fritz Kuhn, individually, and as president of the German-American Bund, charged he was libeled and damaged to the extent of $5,000,000 by the motion picture "Confessions of a Nazi Spy" in a suit filed yesterday against Warner Brothers...

WASHINGTON, May 12.--The Administration intends to preserve its attitude of "hands-off" impartiality over the details of revising the Neutrality Act, Representative Bloom of New York, acting chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee,...
VIENNA, May 12.--Catholic Church authorities were notified today that all changes in the personnel of the clergy in the future would be subject to the approval of the National Socialist party.

An audience which shouted and cheered attended the performance of Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" given last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association as part of the music season of the New York World's Fair.
In two daring, well-planned holdups yesterday in Queens, gunmen took a total of more than $13,000.

YARMOUTH N.S. May 12.-- Forty-seven fishermen, all but one man of the crews of two New England schooners which sank after a collision 100 miles at sea early Wednesday, were safe in port tonight after rowing open dories toward land for two days and a night.

With only one full and two half sessions left to complete engagements in May cotton, shorts became aggressive buyers yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended 10 points higher to 4 points lower. Trading in the May ceases at noon on Tuesday.

ST. LOUIS, May 12.--The development of a specific anti-hormone that may offer a new clue for the diagnosis of cancer in its early stages, as well as a possible new avenue of approach to its treatment, was reported here today before the twenty-third annual scientific session of the Association for the Study of Internal Secretions by Dr. K.W. Thompson of the Yale University School of Medicine.

Sufficient and properly trained teachers of dental hygiene eventually coul virtually wipe out tooth decay, Dr. C.J. Hollister of Harrisburg, Pa., told the closing session of the Dental Hygienists Association, meeting yesterday in the auditorium of the Medical and Public Health Building at the World's Fair.

Mayor La Guardia had been able to keep down the budget for his own office through the use of employes from other departments, Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, said yesterday at a public hearing on the proposed 1939-1940 budget before the members of the Finansce Committee of the City Council.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 12. --John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in a speech interpreted as warning to the "Old Guard" that it could not control the 1940 national convention, declared here today that the party must choose a Presidential candidate who would inspire pride among its workers.

With all the pomp and ceremony of a British court occasion and with Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, to give the official touch, United Kingdom Day was celebrated at the World's Fair yesterday. The climax of the day was the official opening of the pavilions of Great Britain, the Commonwealth of Australia, the Dominion of New Zealand and the British Colonial Empire.

The German steamship lines the North German Lloyd and HamburgAmerican, have withdrawn from a subsidiary agreement within the North Atlantic Passenger Conference under which cabin class tariffs were established and mutually maintained.

Minor price fluctuations and listless trading marked yesterday's bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Although the trading pace was stepped up slightly from Thursday--transactions amounting to $4,824,050, compared with $4,679,100--the market ...
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 12.--Barter arrangements now being negotiated between Bolivia and Germany threaten to decrease Amercan export trade to South...

The need for additional Federal aid to carry on the fight against syphilis was stressed yesterday by Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Commissioner of Health, who saw a nation-wide program as the only solution to control of the disease.

Emphasis will be placed upon health and personality, in addition to scholarship, in the selection of future New York City public school teachers, Dr. Louis Marks, chairman of the Board of Examiners, disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, May 12.--As the first stage in the formation of a public corporation to merge Imperial Airways, Ltd., and British Airways, Ltd., and thus obtain unity in state control of civilian aviation, the British Government today offered unexpectedly generous terms to the shareholders of these leading operating companies.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 12.-- Miss Jean Frazier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Frazier of this place, was married this afternoon to Allyn Phelps Evans, son of Mrs. William Walz Evans, also of Englewood, and the late ...

BERLIN, May 12.--With an estimated 1,500,000 men under arms, the German Army at present is engaged in a series of regional manoeuvres designed to cover both troop movements and concentrations under the cloak of "routine."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12.-- Joan Crawford's next picture for Metro will be "Park Avenue Models," by Jerry Horwin and John Larkin, the studio announced today. The film is expected to go before the cameras about June 15, following completion of "The Women," Miss Crawford's current vehicle.

BOSTON, May 12.--There was far too much chill in the Boston atmosphere and too much heat in the Boston bats for Luke Hamlin and the Dodgers today, so the Bees beat Leo Durocher's athletes by 7--5 and pulled even with them and the Reds to share second place in the National League.

JULY 14, this year, will mark the 150th anniversary of the fall of the Bastille. We shall probably have a good many articles appraising the century and a half influenced by that symbolic event (some of these might, interestingly, contrast it with the century and a half before 1789) and, perhaps, a number of books.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 12.-- Pounding three pitchers for fifteen hits, Cornell defeated Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game today. The score was 13--2.

HOLYOKE, Mass., May 12.--Miss Marlynn Perkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Perkins of Holyoke, was married here at noon today in the Skinner Memorial Chapel to Peter Greene Morison, son of Professor and Mrs. Samuel Eliot Morison of Boston.

With Mayor La Guardia and Grower A. Whalen on horseback acting as volunteer barkers, and an electrical eel from the Zoological Society providing the juice for the starting signal, the World's Fair amusement area at 9 o'clock tonight will be officially reclaimed from the doldrums that blighted its early days and noisily dedicated as the liveliest spot of the World of Tomorrow.

Condemning the low pay of dentists in city service as "unfair discrimination," the Dental Society of the State of New York adopted a resolution at the closing session of its seventy-first annual meeting yesterday calling for the ...

CHICAGO, May 12.--The bases were filled with Indians when Clint Brown, star emergency pitcher, came to the rescue of the White Sox in the ninth inning today. Two putouts quickly ended the game, the Sox winning, 4 to 3.
At sea--The great ship pitches over swirling gray hills, a leviathan of the deep acting like a bucking bronco. Far away on the eastern horizon Europe has disappeared in a blur of rain and fog.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12. --Pledges of aid in the eradication of slums, the erection of decent housing for low-income groups and adoption of a program to protect investments in real estate were made here today at the Central Atlantic regional conference of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman's departure from his present home at Newton Center, Mass., on May 21 to assume his new duties as head of the Archdiocese of New York the next day will be marked by the utmost simplicity, it was announced here yesterday by Mgr. J. Francis A. Mclntyre, chancellor of the archdiocese.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP).--After seven years of failure, Europe's amateur boxing stars defeated a team of Golden Gloves fighters tonight, The margin was 5 to 3 for the Europeans before 20,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.

MEMPHIS, May 12 (AP).--Chuck Fenske of the University of Wisconsin, running unattached, outdistanced Archie San Romans, famed Kansan, by a yard tonight to win the featured E.H. Crump Mile at the Cotton Carnival track meet.

Trading in some classes of non-kosher meats showed improvement but others continued only fair to slow, in local markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs and lamb were lower; fresh pork cuts weak to lower; other classes steady. By a vote of more than four to one the Senate gave its approval yesterday to the new farm appropriation bill. Not a single item in that measure, as passed by the House a month ago, was reduced during the debate in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--The West Texas Utilities Company of Abilene, Texas, a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $18,000,000 ...
Mayor La Guardia issued a statement yesterday praising national Hospital Day as a means of emphasizing the importance of a great social institution.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--President Roosevelt's second reorganization plan was made proof against Congressional veto today in quick, friendly action engineered by Senator Byrne, chairman of the special Senate Committee on Reorganization.

In recent years practically every public library in the United States has had less money than it could profitably use. Municipal appropriations have dwindled, while endowments have brought in a smaller income.

BALTIMORE, May 12.--With Johnstown scaring rivals to the tall timber, the forty-ninth and richest Preakness will be run at Pimlico tomorrow. Seven have been named, two of them stable-mates of the sensational colt who made such a walkaway of the Kentucky Derby.

Councilman Robert K. Straus, Manhattan Fusionist, told the members of the City Council's Subcommittee on Traffic Regulation yesterday at a hearing in City Hall that the complete elimination of parking in the mid-Manhattan area was the only solution to the present traffic congestion.

After some ditch-digging, work on the Florida canal was abandoned in 1937, supposedly for good. Now the enterprise is to be reconsidered by Congress. One reason is a hundred per cent increase in Atlantic-Gulf traffic.

Although held to two hits, Power Memorial Academy strengthened its hold on first place in the Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A, race by halting St. Peter's High, 6--3, at Goodhue Oval, Staten Island, yesterday. The triumph was the sixth straight in the league for Power.

Appointments to the board of senior proctors for next year have been made by the student council at Barnard College and student elections for executive positions in the classes of '40, '41 and '42 have been completed.
Five men who listed their occupation as jewelers were arrested yesterday on charges of receiving stolen property and locked up at Police Headquarters.
Lulled into a dullness which apparently will require a shock of major proportions to overcome it the stock market gave yesterday one of the most listless performances of the last month.
LONDON, May 12.--The British Government today offered the entire interior of British Guiana for settlement by Jewish refugees.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 12.-- Miss Mary McNamara, who was a teacher and principal in the public school system here for fifty-two years until her retirement in 1936, died this morning of a heart attack in her home. She was 73 Years old.

Months of negotiations, entailing changes in zoning regulations and an involved property-purchase plan, culminated yesterday in the beginning of construction work on a suburban garden apartment center on part of the old Iselin estate near New Rochelle, Westchester County.
The popular notion that the Giants had seen the last of last place in the National League apparently was based on a belief that had a false bottom.
AMHERST, Mass., May 12.-- Roger Moore led the Williams track team to a Little Three title today as the Purple scored an 81-to-54 victory over Amherst.

Several hundred members of New York's nursing corps, in the crisp white uniforms of their profession, ranged themselves yesterday as a background for the tributes to Florence Nightingale that featured the observance of Hospital Day at the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP).--Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, expressed optimism today regarding prospects for settlement of the controversy between his government and United States oil companies whose properties were expropriated in March, 1938.
Mrs. Henry B. Plant of 684 Park Avenue will give a small dinner dance tonight at the River Club for her daughter, Miss Mary Ellen Plant, and some of her young friends.

New York University finally gained a baseball victory over Boston College at Ohio Field yesterday. Coach Bill McCarthy's pupils lashed hits of every dimension to all corners of the lot and capitalized on misplays for a 13-to-3 verdict, the first attained by N.Y.U. in seven meetings with the Eagles.

The Bankamerica Company of San Francisco won yesterday the award of $2,577,489 of registered warrants of the State of California at 2 per cent, plus a premium of $8,945. The warrants, dated May 16, will be due on or about Feb. 27, 1940.

Sean T. O'Kelly, Vice President of the Executive Council of Eire, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington to officiate at the opening of the Irish Pavilion at the New York World's Fair today in place of Premier Eamon deValera.

The rowing program for today is featured by the renewal of the oldest short-distance race the sport holds, the Childs Cup regatta, started in 1879, with Columbia, Princeton and Pennsylvania competing on the Harlem River.

Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and former Governor Alfred E. Smith sent official greetings yesterday to the Jewish Palestine Pavilion at the World's Fair, which will be opened to the public at 8 o'clock tonight and will be formally dedicated on May 28.

LONDON, May 12.--The stock markets here generally were quiet and uncertain today until Prime minister Neville Chamberlain's statement on the Anglo-Turkish pact helped sentiment in late trading. Movements in the gilt-edge issues were small and downward, but some maintained the overnight levels.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--The Senate, undeterred by accusations of extravagance and budget wrecking, today passed by a vote of 61 to 14 an appropriation bill for the Department of Agriculture carrying $1,218,666,572.
