The local talent in track and field circles, with one eye on the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships a fortnight later, will tune up its equipment at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today in the seventh annual metropolitan intercollegiate title meet.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12.--A demand for a neutrality act which would "distinguish" between aggressor nations and their victims was made to the General Federation of Women's Clubs today by Mrs. Gustav Ketterer of Philadelphia, chairman of the organization's department of legislation.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 12.--The marriage of Miss Althea Pardee, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold E.B. Pardee of 770 Park Avenue and Lawrence, L.I., to William A. Evans Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Greenwich, Conn., took ...

QUEBEC, May 12.--For the first time in the 180 years that have passed since Wolfe's victory over Montcalm on the Plains of Abraham made Canada part of the British Empire, this vast Dominion prepared today to play host on Monday to a reigning British sovereign and his consort.
MIAMI, Fla., May 12 (AP)--S. Mortimer Auerbach, noted speedboat driver, was injured today when his record-holding Emancipator VIII overturned while racing an estimated ninety-three miles an hour.

CINCINNATI, May 12 (AP).--The Cardinals strengthened their National League lead with home runs today, defeating the Reds, 8 to 7, with an attack led by Johnny Mize and Pepper Martin, who between them accounted for seven tallies.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters (Broadway, between 155th and 156th Streets) will open with a private view this afternoon the special exhibition it has arranged as one of New York's many added World's Fair attractions. It opens to the public tomorrow and will continue all Summer.
The Chicago Opera Company opens its season at the Hippodrome tonight with "La Traviata," conducted by Fulgenzio Guerrieri. The cast will be headed by Norina Greco, Sydney Rayner and Claudio Frigerio.
ALBANY, May 12.--The resignation of Thomas H. Murphy as warden of Clinton Prison at Dannemora since 1931 was announced today by John A. Lyons, Correction Commissioner.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP).--In one of the best-pitched games of the young season Rookie Jack Kramer held the Tigers to two singles today and topped his performance by driving in the only run, to give the Browns a 1-to-0 victory.

Price movements yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange were sluggish and the session was the second dullest of the year. Total sales aggregated $2,080,400, against S2,139,425 for the preceding Saturday. Changes at the close were without especial significance.

The Indians won all the field events save one. Dartmouth swept the hammer throw, high jump and low hurdles.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 16.--The board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association went on record today in next to the last session of the conference here with a formal plea to the United States Treasury Department for a balanced budget.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--At a session dominated by appeals for early peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the constitutional convention uniting the Textile Workers Organizing Committee and the United Textile Workers of America denounced ...

Current enforcement of the Wheeler-Lea amendments to the Federal Trade Commission Act, "instead of protecting the manufacturer has swung far to the other side," Dr. Fred F. Cullen, Washington representative of the Proprietary Association, said yesterday ...

LONDON, May 16 (AP)--Exports of crude rubber will be increased slightly during the third quarter of the year, the International Rubber Regulation Committee decided today. It fixed export allowables at 55 per cent of standard tonnages, compared with the 50 per cent which has been maintained so far this year.

A novel process of producing textiles from the protein of the soy bean, a part of which process is on display in the exhibit of the Ford Motor Company at the World's Fair, is on the way to perfection in the Dearborn laboratories of the company after a year and a half of research, it was announced by officials yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 16.--Retail credit men at the annual convention of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Cleveland today heard a prediction of an upturn in business during June and July from C. W. Harvey, credit manager of the Gilchrist Company, Boston, and retiring chairman of the division.

Charles Donnelly, president of the Northern Pacific Railway, received $42,000 salary in 1938, the company's report to the Securities and Exchange Commissioin disclosed yesterday. B.W. Scandrett, vice president, received $30,000; W.E. Coman, vice president, $25,000; H.E. ...

Foreign gold in the amount of $30,384,000 arrived here yesterday, most of it from England. According to the daily gold statement of the Federal Reserve Bank, the imports consisted of $30,296,000 from England, $76,000 from Mexico and $12,000 from Guatemala. No exports of the metal were reported.

Turning in one of the best performances of his college career, Tom Ananicz, star southpaw of the St. John's University nine, allowed Manhattan College only two singles as the Redmen scored a 7-0 shutout over the Jaspers at Dexter Park yesterday.

CHUNGKING, May 16.--The Chinese asserted today that the situation in Northern Hupeh and Southwestern Honan had been stabilized as a result of Chinese reoccupation of Sinyeh and Tangho, in Southwestern Honan, combined with unyielding Chinese resistance along ...

Although the temperature may be misleading, the theatre never fails. It is the perfect guide to the seasons. The mercury may be shrinking in the glass, but that old Spring feeling has captivated Taylor Holmes in a comedy labeled "Day in the Sun" and stuck on at the Biltmore last evening.

An increase in the exchange of products and ideas between France and the United States, as an aid to the maintenance of world peace, was urged last night at a dinner given by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and the French Chamber of Commerce for ...

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,402,500 barrels, compared with 3,580,900 the previous week, a decline of 178,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Soviet Russia took the spotlight it the World's Fair yesterday and will hold it again today. Several hundred invited guests were entertained yesterday afternoon and last night at a cocktail party and reception in the U.S.S.R. pavilion, an inspection of the exhibits and a dinner party.

A strike of all the skilled mechanics and construction workers at the World's Fair who are members of American Federation of Labor unions was threatened yesterday by a representative of the union of ground maintenance men who have been on strike since last week, as a protest against the alleged use of strike-breakers by the Fair.

Facing a maximum prison term of 640 years, Elias Garrow, lawyer and self-confessed member of a disability insurance racket, complained bitterly yesterday that his services as an informer were not being recognized in the twentymonth sentence dealt him by Federal Judge John C. Knox.

Back on their home grounds at the Stadium after a most successful tour of the hinterlands, the Yankees started a two-week stand in the Bronx yesterday and, although the opposition perked up somewhat in the ninth inning, the McCarthymen bagged their sixth straight victory at the expense of the Browns. The score of this latest conquest was 7 to 5.
Samuel W. Reyburn, chairman of the board of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, was guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Hotel Plaza, celebrating his twentyfifth year with the corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP)--It took the Indians nine innings to solve the floodlights tonight in the American League's first nocturnal baseball game, but in the tenth they scored five runs for an 8-to-3 decision over the Athletics before 15,109 fans.

Two men were wounded at 6 o'clock last night on the lower East Side by a volley of shots fired from the street at a group in a candy store on Mott Street, just across from the play yard of Public School 21, and within a block of Old St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A machine that tears speech to pieces and remakes it in new patterns was demonstrated yesterday at the closing session of the tenth anniversary meeting of the Acoustical Society of America in the Hotel Pennsylvania. It is expected to have important commercial applications.

PARIS, May 16.--Contending that it has proved beyond a doubt the power of a democratically governed people to gather up its energies and face all issues in time of need, Finance Minister Paul Reynaud this evening issued a balance sheet for the first five months of his threeyear plan for the recovery of French prosperity.

The exhibit of the Irish Linen Guild of Belfast, which is seen by World's Fair visitors in the British Pavilion, is designed to reveal "the sentiment that lies behind the appeal of Irish linen," it was explained yesterday by Major Arthur C. Herdman, chairman of the guild.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16.--The incoming Essex County grand jury was charged today by Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan to investigate the implications in questions asked by City Commissioner Joseph N. Byrne Jr. pertaining to the possibility of an "invisible government" controlling Newark under the direction of underworld characters.

Most American youths consider economic security the basic problem of their personal lives, according to a survey of 20,000 young persons, the results of which were made known yesterday at the annual convention of the Boys Clubs of America at the Hotel Commodore.

An employer who had pleaded guilty to a charge of having defrauded the State Insurance Fund of $10,000 in premiums on his workmen's compensation insurance was sentenced yesterday to serve two months in the workhouse by Justices Salomon, De Luca and Wieboldt in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn.

Agreeing that there are insufficient data on which petroleum refiners and marketers may determine policies on the issuance of credit cards, the third annual conference of the Eastern Petroleum Refiners and Marketers Credit Groups named a committee yesterday to study all ...

CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP).--Directors of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad removed today Robert R. Young of New York as their chairman. They gave the position to George D. Brooke, who is president of the Nickel Plate as well as president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Pere Marquette Railroad.

After tuning up on the road since April 17, "The Brown Danube" arrives tonight at the Lyceum under the aegis of Helen G. Bonfils and her husband, George Somnes. This is Burnet Hershey's play as revised by Victor Wolfson and concerns the difficulties imposed by a totalitarian regime on a vanishing nobility ...

SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 16.-- A newcomer to the East, Miss Margaret Vance of Pomonok, formerly of California, playing in her first metropolitan tournament, won the Joseph J. Windle Challenge Cup by finishing 1 up to women's par over the upper course of the Baltusrol Country Club today.

Italy is spending so much for military purposes that she has to restrict once more the diet of her people. They have been ordered to cut their consumption of coffee "to a minimum" so that the gold exported for its purchase may be used to buy raw materials to be turned into guns, cruisers and planes.

Proposals for development of a merchandising and marketing program in the coat and suit field, by means of which the industry can "create its prosperity" featured the opening yesterday of the three-day annual meeting of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at the Hotel Astor.

The twenty-five men named by Coach Emil Von Elling to represent New York University in the sixtythird annual Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island on May 26 and 27 were announced yesterday. Howard Brill and James B. Herbert are the ...

BOSTON, May 16.--Henry I. Harriman, former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, tonight called for changes in the neutrality laws to permit the sale of goods, including munitions and arms, on a "cash and carry" basis, but with the provision that ...

Final trading in May contracts took place yesterday on the Cotton Exchange at 9 cents a pound after heavy covering had forced a rise of $1 a bale. This represented a gain of nearly $7 a bale from the quotations prevailing a month ago.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 16.--A sore mallet wrist that belongs to Mike Phipps postponed the assembling of the talked-of forty-goal American polo team today as the United States defenders played another test match at Phipps Field.

JERUSALEM, May 16.--British troops patrolled strategic points throughout the Holy Land tonight as part of extensive precautions to avert threatened disorders over the British Government's Palestine plan, to be published tomorrow.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP).--The Red Sox celebrated their return to Fenway Park today by going on a nineteen-hit rampage that overwhelmed the White Sox, 18--4, and gave freshman pitcher Woody Rich his third triumph of the season.

Plans for concentrating its executive offices and showrooms in downtown Manhattan were announced yesterday by the Payne Walsh Corporation, large sellers of new and used printing machinery, which maintains a warehouse in Long Island City.

The Chase National Bank headed a banking group that bought yesterday $4,375,000 of home relief, improvement and tax revenue bonds of Erie County, N.Y., on a bid of 100.098 for 1.70s. The bonds, dated May 1 and to mature on May 1, 1940 to 1949, were reoffered by ...

ALBANY, May 16.--An atmosphere of high-pressure political manoeuvring surrounded the Legislature today as many important measures became involved in activity on the part of Republican leaders to pass both the State-wide sales tax and the resolution to investigate the affairs of Albany County.

VIENNA, May 16.--In a Viennese home 12-year-old Rudolf was introduced to a foreign visitor. "This gentleman comes from Britain," said his mother. "Wouldn't you like to go there?" Rudolf's face clouded and he replied: "No, I am a Hitler youth and Britain is our enemy. My ambition is to become an aviator and drop bombs on our enemies."
